DOC.HEAD: For Raymond Buckey, Deadlock Marks End of 7-Year Ordeal
With PM-Preschool Molest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For Raymond Buckey, a jury deadlock marked the end of a seven-year ordeal _ five years of which he spent in jail convicted of nothing, but charged with the unspeakable crime of child molestation. ``I've gone from probably one of the most hated people you could ever mention to a point of where everybody that comes up to me now is very sympathetic, and they're saying `I always thought you were innocent,''' Buckey said after a mistrial was declared Friday. Buckey was retried on charges he molested children at the McMartin Pre-School. Prosecutors said they wouldn't try him a third time, bringing to a close the longest criminal case in U.S. history. ``I don't know if anyone can understand the feeling of waiting seven years for someone to decide your fate,'' Buckey said. During his first trial, Buckey was charged with dozens of molestation counts and acquitted of 40. Eight charges were refiled against him. In votes taken during 15 days of deliberation, jurors leaned toward acquittal on seven of the eight counts. The eighth was split, 6-6. On Friday, they said unanimous verdicts were impossible. The tall, square-jawed Buckey said the years in jail were tough _ ``it's like a war zone in there.'' But he acknowledged that the ordeal ``made me a very strong person.'' Buckey displayed some bitterness as he spoke of the cost exacted by his family _ the loss of their home, their once prestigious school in Manhattan Beach and the damage to their reputations. He blamed those who would not let the case go away and those who ``played a political game with my life.'' ``It was Salem revisited,'' he said. ``It was McCarthyism one more time.'' Buckey, who began the case as a gawky, self-conscious 25-year-old, seemed to grow in stature as the case progressed. He is now 32, and appears confident, articulate and well-groomed. Once he left his glib attorney, Danny Davis, to talk to reporters. Toward the end, he faced the TV cameras himself with direct, thoughtful answers that made him his own best spokesman. He took the witness stand, sunburned from his return to the seaside he loved, and told jurors he never molested any children. ``I'm innocent,'' he said after the jury had deadlocked. ``There was the presumption of innocence at the start of this. ... I was innocent coming in and I'm still innocent because I wasn't found guilty.'' Buckey said he hoped society would gain from his case but also predicted the public would forget it in time. ``They'll remember the McMartin phenomenon,'' he said. ``But given time something else will come along (to make headlines) and I'll be anonymous and that's what I want.'' Asked what he would do with the rest of his life, Buckey said, ``I would like to be just left alone. I'd like to move out of the city and find a little fresh air. This is not the kind of life I would have planned out.'' He added with a smile, ``I'll have to get a job now.''

DOC.HEAD: Pesticides Poisoning Leaves Over 100 Dead, 2,000 Ill
DOC.TEXT: Improper use of pesticides has killed more than 100 Chinese farmers and sickened 2,000 others in the coastal province of Jiangsu this summer, according to news reports. Because of hot and humid conditions in the region, peasants use large quantities of pesticides and often do not observe safety procedures, the official People's Daily said Friday. The report said that more than 100 people had died because there was no effective antidote for the pesticide poisoning. It called for better management to prevent more deaths but did not provide further details about the poisoning.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats, Doctors Wonder if Envoy Stricken by Chernobyl Fallout
DOC.TEXT: Doctors believe the leukemia that has hospitalized Czechoslovakia's ambassador might have been caused by radioactive fallout from the 1986 Soviet nuclear accident at Chernobyl, a Czech embassy official says. Ambassador Rita Klimova, 59, is in Johns Hopkins Hospital in nearby Baltimore, where she faces perhaps four weeks of chemotherapy treatment, the Czechoslovak Embassy said Friday. The ambassador's son, Vladimir Mlynar, visiting her from Prague, said his mother ``feels quite good,'' and said she is ``slightly optimistic,'' according to Embassy official Laco Mravec. Mrs. Klimova's leukemia, cancer of the white blood cells, was diagnosed earlier this month at Walter Reed U.S. Army Medical Center in Washington, where President Bush's physician arranged for her to be examined, said Miroslav Chrobok, embassy charge d'affaires. ``Two doctors at Walter Reed suggested it might be one of those funny cases of leukemia we have in Eastern Europe ... it might be a Chernobyl thing,'' Chrobok said. He said the Army doctors told him they meant cases of the sometimes-fatal blood disease that have appeared with no apparent cause of leukemia except exposure to air or water contaminated by radiation over a wide region of Europe and Scandinavia after the April 1986 nuclear power plant explosion at the Ukrainian city of Chernobyl. ``Certainly there is nothing certain'' about the cause, ``it's just a possibility,'' Chrobok said. At least 31 people perished during and after the Chernobyl explosion and thousands were evacuated from the area of heaviest contamination. Since then, numerous cases of blood-related illnesses around Europe have been attributed to Chernobyl and officials are urging a wider evacuation. Dr. Robert Gale, the Los Angeles physician who treated some of Chernobyl's worst radiation cases, has said Chernobyl fallout could increase cancer deaths by as many as 30,000 worldwide in the next half century. Chrobok said Gale is among numerous well-wishers who have messaged the ambassador, and has offered to assist on her case. Dr. Klimova, a newcomer to diplomacy, arrived in Washington last February as her country's first new envoy to the United States after the peaceful revolution that ended 40 years of Communist rule last December.

DOC.HEAD: Emigres Continue Fleeing To Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: Nine Albanians illegally crossed into Yugoslavia in the past two days, bringing the total to 47 so far this month, the official Tanjug news agency reported. Police in Montenegro, the southern Yugoslav republic that borders Albania, said the average age of the refugees is 23, Tanjug reported Friday. Most of the Albanians have said they were fleeing harsh living conditions and the policies of their government, the last hard-line Stalinist country in Eastern Europe. This year, 89 Albanians have fled to Yugoslavia, 10 times the number for all of last year. Albania announced a series of reforms in May and said border guards would no longer shoot to kill if they spotted fleeing Albanians. Tanjug said all Albanian refugees receive 30-day jail terms for illegal entry into the country. They are then usually handed over to the United Nations High Commission for Refugees in Belgrade, which arranges for their resettlement in another country. About 4,500 people who packed foreign embassies in the Albanian capital of Tirana were allowed to leave the country this month.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Would Use Northrop Despite Justice Department's Recommendation
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon's chief procurement official says he would not prohibit Northrop Corp. from building weapons for the military despite the Justice Department's belief that the company should be barred. ``I'm not anticipating any debarment procedure,'' John Betti, undersecretary of defense for acquisitions, told reporters during a break in a six-hour hearing by a House Energy and Commerce panel on charges of fraud and mismanagement at Northrop. Justice Department officials described how Northrop falsified reports on the air-launched cruise missile and conducted improper tests on the Harrier AV-8B jet. The company's action led to its guilty plea in February on 34 charges of fraud and a fine of $17 million, the largest criminal fine ever imposed on a defense contractor. The last witness before the panel, a former Northrop employee who has filed a false claims lawsuit against the company, charged that the Air Force adjusted the budget targets on the B-2 bomber when it realized the program was financially out of control. ``We paid Northrop $26 billion to build a new type of paper airplane that carried this nation's debts to new heights,'' Jean-Francois Truong, who worked as one of eight financial comptrollers for the 14,000-man B-2 work force in Pico Rivera, Calif., and blew the whistle on Northrop, told the panel. Northrop is still the target of federal grand jury criminal investigations, and Justice Department officials were reticent about discussing specifics.
DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Would Ban Radar Detectors on Trucks
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Appropriations Committee has approved a $29 billion transportation spending bill that would ban radar detectors for trucks and require state courts to suspend the driver's licenses of drug offenders. The bill also includes $125 million to speed passenger rail service between New York and Boston by electrifying rail lines between Boston and New Haven, Conn. Except for increased Amtrak funding and the radar-detector provision, the bill allocates funds in roughly the same manner as the House-passed appropriations bill. The House bill also includes an amendment to require states to suspend the licenses of drug offenders or suffer cuts in federal transportation dollars. The bill covers transportation spending for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The Senate bill sets aside $13.85 billion for highway construction, maintenance and repairs; $8 billion for aviation, including operations at the Federal Aviation Administration; $785 million for Amtrak; and $3.3 billion for mass transit. Committee Chairman Frank R. Lautenberg, D-N.J., said electrifying the New England line will encourage more rail travel between New York and Boston, decreasing the burden on airports.
DOC.HEAD: House Subcommittee Approves Military Support Cuts
DOC.TEXT: A House Armed Services subcommittee is paring more than $5 billion from the Pentagon's budget by continuing a hiring freeze for civilians and slashing maintenance funds for overseas bases, congressional sources say. The panel on readiness cut force structure support costs by $5.9 billion from President Bush's original proposal of $79.3 billion to meet levels set under a House budget resolution approved on May 1. Friday's action came in advance of Tuesday's session of the full House Armed Services Committee, which is expected to craft a 1991 military budget of $283 billion _ $24 billion less than President Bush sought in January. The lawmakers approved a $1.09 billion reduction in pay for the Pentagon's civilian work force, which currently numbers around 1 million people. They also approved continuing the hiring freeze that was introduced earlier this year by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney ``as a means of reducing the civilian work force,'' said the congressional source, who spoke on condition of not being identified by name. This would mean 60,000 to 65,000 fewer jobs for the civilians who work for the military during the next fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, the source said.
DOC.HEAD: Government Rewrites Economic History
DOC.TEXT: The government has rewritten a slice of economic history, reporting that the total economy grew at a slower pace last year than previously thought. The Commerce Department said Friday the gross national product _ the nation's broadest measure of economic health _ grew by 2.5 percent in 1989, instead of the 3 percent growth rate estimated earlier. That put growth at its slowest pace since the recession year of 1982, when the GNP actually shrank by 2.5 percent. Government statisticians blamed the error on mistakes made in estimating wages and salaries, which were overstated by $57.9 billion for 1989. The correction changed not only the government's economic estimates but also its forecast for tax revenues over the next several years. The Office of Management and Budget was forced to slash its estimate for tax revenues by $195.5 billion over the next five years. The drop in expected tax revenues along with the weaker economic growth were two major factors forcing President Bush to reverse his stand on taxes as part of negotiations with Congress to come up with an acceptable deficit reduction plan. While the Commerce Department's initial assessment of wages is based on a partial sample of businesses, the July update takes into account more complete data gathered from the country's roughly 6 million businesses.
DOC.HEAD: Panel Urges Removing Social Security Surplus From Deficit
DOC.TEXT: A Department of Health and Human Services advisory panel recommended removing Social Security from the calculation of deficit reduction targets to focus public attention on the ballooning deficit. The Advisory Council on Social Security also recommended Friday continuing the payroll tax rate at the current level to build reserves as a cushion for the retirement of 75 million baby boomers, which will begin around 2010. The council said in its interim report that maintaining a strong Social Security system depends on having a healthy, growing economy and that large deficits in the federal budget weaken the economy. ``The Council believes that the growing Social Security reserves should not routinely be used simply to offset large operating deficits in the rest of the federal budget,'' the panel said. The panel's report said the financial soundness of the Social Security trust funds is not affected by whether the trust funds are included or excluded in calculating deficit reduction targets. But ``taking Social Security out of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings calculations will help federal policy-makers and the American people focus on the fundamental importance of reducing the deficit and moving toward a surplus in the overall federal budget,'' the council said. The council also opposed changing the Social Security program's financing to a ``pay-as-you-go'' system, in which payroll taxes would be set at a rate sufficient to raise enough revenues to cover current expenses and maintain a contingency reserve.

DOC.HEAD: Gun Owners Sue Florio Over Assault Weapon Ban
DOC.TEXT: Gun enthusiasts made good on their threat to take Gov. Jim Florio to court over his statewide ban on military-style assault weapons. The National Rifle Association, the Coalition of New Jersey Sportsmen and the Congress of Racial Equality filed a federal lawsuit Friday seeking a temporary restraining order against the law signed by Florio in May. The law bans the sale and severely curtails the possession of a wide range of semiautomatic weapons in New Jersey. California is the only other state to ban assault weapons. Supporters of the New Jersey bill call the New Jersey ban tougher because it does not exempt current owners of the weapons. The groups hope to obtain a court hearing date next week, said Ira Mallowe, treasurer of the Coalition of New Jersey Sportsmen. The lawsuit takes aim at two provisions in the law _ one restricting possession of certain gun magazines, the part of the gun where ammunition is stored, and the other banning air guns and BB guns. ``The law specifically prohibits individuals from possessing magazines capable of holding more than 15 rounds of ammunition, but it also prohibits disposing of those magazines,'' said Richard Manning, the NRA's New Jersey liaison. Mallowe said gun owners ``were made instant felons with no way to cure the problem.'' The lawsuit also said the state ban pre-empted federal law, which allows ownership of air guns and BB guns. Under the law, current gun owners have one year either to sell their guns out-of-state or turn them over to police. Collectors can keep their weapons if the guns are rendered inoperable by the removal of firing pins or bolts. Gun owners can also register their guns if they join a target shooting club within seven months, but only if the guns are models sanctioned for use in U.S. Army shooting competitions. Those arrested for illegal possession of the firearms face three to five years in prison and a fine of up to $7,500. Using an assault weapon in a crime can bring up to 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: High-Tax States Decry Plan to Limit Deductions on Local Taxes
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's plan to raise money by limiting deductions on local taxes could cripple the ability of high-tax states to run schools and provide services, opponents say. Taxpayers would be limited to a $10,000 deduction for state and local income taxes under the plan, which is supported by Republican congressional leaders. State officials feared the plan also might drive residents from high-tax states to ones where income taxes are lower or non-existent. ``If the state loses its income tax, which it relies on, then you have to use the other taxes,'' Gov. Mario Cuomo said Friday. ``Or would you stop feeding the poor people?'' Cuomo, a Democrat, was a key player in the successful 1985 fight to save deductibility. ``I don't think it helps the states at a time when the federal government is bailing out of responsibilities,'' said New Jersey Gov. Jim Florio. Cuomo and other officials say a loss of deductibility would put pressure on them to reduce state and local income taxes at a time when they are already hurting for tax revenue. A loss of deductibility would magnify every state and local income tax increase for upper-income taxpayers because they would lose the ability to deduct those taxes on their federal returns. That, say critics of the plan, amounts to double taxation. Edward Farrell, executive director of the New York State Conference of Mayors, said the practical effect would be states and localities turning to more regressive taxes, such as sales or property taxes. But those taxes are harder to increase, largely because of the potential for taxpayer revolts. That means towns and cities might be forced to sacrifice police, firefighters or other services, he said. Poor school districts in New York, which rely heavily on state income tax revenue, would ``find it impossible to maintain their education,'' predicted Board of Regents Chancellor Martin Barell. Restrictions also could encourage residents of high-tax states to move, thus decreasing the tax base, said Chris Zimmerman, chief economist at the National Conference of State Legislatures. ``A rich person in New York would get hit, but a rich person in Texas wouldn't,'' he said. ``People don't migrate to Canada or Mexico because the tax rate went up, but they might go to Connecticut.'' Connecticut has no income tax and Texas has no state income tax, but some local income tax.

DOC.HEAD: Land-Hungry Peasants Take Over Sandinista Cooperatives in Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The peasants came out slowly from behind the cement-block barricade, making sure the approaching strangers weren't Sandinistas trying to force them off the collective farm they took over. ``They were shooting automatic weapons into the air all night long. We couldn't sleep,'' said Edwin Velazquez, apologizing for the cool greeting. The anti-Sandinista peasants in La Concepcion and other areas of Nicaragua share similar complaints about the conservative government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, which replaced the leftist Sandinistas in April. The peasants say the new government has not responded quickly enough to demands for land distribution, and that it is afraid to press ahead decisively with handing out state-owned lands because of a possible violent Sandinista reaction. But this year's planting season is halfway over, and some peasants have taken matters into their own hands. On July 13, Velazquez and two dozen peasants armed with machetes walked onto the 62-acre Sandinista collective farm and took it over. They didn't meet much resistance. The farmers of the Gaspar Garcia Laviana collective live in another area, and only the caretaker was present. A week later, a second group of peasants took over another Sandinista cooperative near La Concepcion. A third cooperative, farther away, had been taken over in early July. The peasants' impatience is shared by large landowners, such as Ramiro Gurdian, president of the Nicaraguan Union of Agricultural and Cattle Producers. Many feel the Sandinistas, although voted out of office in February, still call the shots. Gurdian said a perception that Mrs. Chamorro's government is not firm enough has scared away investment, especially in agriculture. A cotton grower, Gurdian said that only half of 250,000 acres destined for cotton this year will be planted with the export crop. ``We're going to lose $30 million (in export earnings) we had been counting on, and that's just in cotton,'' Gurdian said. The government is trying to change its image as timid and fearful of crossing the Sandinistas. Minister of the Presidency Antonio Lacayo, son-in-law of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, recently went on television to touch on comments heard often lately. Lacayo, considered the real power behind his mother-in-law's presidency, denied there was a ``secret pact'' with the Sandinistas and defended the government's cautious attitude. ``This is very difficult because this is a very polarized society,'' he said, adding that the government's policy ``is simply to impose dialogue to resolve any crisis.'' Agrarian Reform Minister Gustavo Tablada said there has not been enough time in the three months since the new government took over to resolve the disposition of the 3,500 cooperatives nationwide. He said he failed to understand the land takeovers in La Concepcion. ``The thing here is to have a lot of patience so as not to make mistakes that later will have negative effects. ... We have to use persuasion,'' Tablada said. Velazquez, however, is not waiting for the government to act. With the other men looking on and nodding, Velazquez said most of the peasants occupying the farm do not have enough land. He said the Sandinistas had abandoned the cooperatives and own additional land elsewhere, while he and his neighbors had been forced to plow plots too small for survival. Velazquez said his group had filed written requests for land with the Agrarian Reform offices in the cities of Masaya and Granada, at least two hours' drive away. ``We have never gotten a reply. That's when we decided to do this,'' he said. ``Maybe these actions are illegal, but through pressure we can achieve something.'' The peasants have gone one step further. They have sent word to the Sandinista farmers to have a parley and settle the dispute. ``They have land and we don't,'' Velazquez said. ``They are peasants and so are we. The government hasn't even sent anybody down to talk to us. I think we can reach an agreement, among us. All we want to do is work.''

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Longest Criminal Case Ends After Second Mistrial
LaserPhotos LA13, LA16 of July 27
DOC.TEXT: The longest and costliest criminal case in U.S. history ended when jurors deadlocked in Raymond Buckey's retrial on charges he molested three girls at McMartin Pre-School. The judge declared a mistrial, and prosecutors said they would not try Buckey a third time, closing a case that began seven years ago. Amid initial allegations involving more than 100 children and suggestions of satanism and animal torture, the case prompted national concern over molestation. ``I think there is reason to say `enough' at this point,'' District Attorney Ira Reiner said after Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg declared a mistrial Friday. ``There has been a mighty effort and there is no verdict,'' Reiner said. The judge set a hearing for Wednesday to dismiss charges against Buckey, 32, who spent five years in jail. The case cost Los Angeles County more than $13.5 million. ``We gave it our best shot,'' said the trial prosecutor, Deputy District Attorney Joseph Martinez. ``These kids cannot be McMartin kids for the rest of their lives. It's been a horrible experience,'' Martinez said. Buckey said he believed it had been a witch hunt from the outset: ``It was Salem revisited,'' he said. ``It was McCarthyism one more time. ``I've gone from probably one of the most hated people you could ever mention,'' he said, ``to a point of where, everybody that comes up to me now is very sympathetic, and they're saying `I always thought you were innocent.''' The saga began in August 1983 when a mother reported to police that her young son had been molested at the prestigious Manhattan Beach preschool. Hysteria followed after police asked parents to check their children for signs of molestation. Hundreds of parents reported their children were victims and tots were rushed to therapy center for interviews. Therapists decided more than 100 probably had been molested. Children gave investigators accounts of ``naked games,'' satanic rites and animals tortured to frighten the youngsters into silence. Seven defendants were arrested and charged with molestation: Buckey, the only male, his mother, sister and aged grandmother, along with three other women teachers. Reiner dismissed charges against all defendants except Buckey and his 63-year-old mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, for lack of evidence after an 18-month preliminary hearing. The Buckeys were accused of molesting 11 children during a five-year period. After a trial lasting nearly three years, a jury in January cleared Mrs. Buckey of 12 charges and absolved her son of 40 charges but deadlocked on 13 counts against him. Reiner decided to retry Buckey on eight counts involving three girls. Jurors who spent three months hearing evidence in the retrial and three weeks deliberating said they believed no jury would ever agree on Buckey's guilt or innocence. The girls, now adolescents, testified about dim recollections of events alleged to have happened as long as 10 years ago when they were toddlers. The panelists divided their votes differently on the eight counts, seven times leaning toward acquittal. The splits ranged from 6-6 to 11-1. ``I don't think that you can get 12 people to reach a verdict in this case,'' said juror Lloyd Isaacson. Several jurors said the prosecution's least effective evidence was a series of videotapes made by Childrens Institute International, in which therapists interviewed toddlers about whether they were molested. Isaacson said he believed the children made claims they were molested only after being told that their friends had revealed ``yucky secrets'' and were urged by therapists to do the same. ``I feel a child is just going to go along with the adult to say what they want them to say,'' he said. Reiner said because parents wanted to resolve the case he did not regret retrying Buckey. Defense lawyer Danny Davis, asked if the parents would ever accept Buckey's innocence, said: ``I don't think they can.'' Buckey said he wouldn't start making plans for the future until charges are officially dismissed. But he said with a smile, ``I'll have to get a job now.''

DOC.HEAD: Crude, Gasoline Prices Seen Rising After OPEC Show Of Unity
DOC.TEXT: Oil analysts predict crude prices and the cost of gasoline will rise later this year as a result of the OPEC agreement to curb output. Price-depressing overproduction by Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates is less likely after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's intimidation campaign aimed at making the countries honor their OPEC-set output quotas, analysts said. Under the agreement reached Friday by the 13 ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, gasoline prices are expected to rise up to 10 cents a gallon by December. The OPEC members agreed on a new overall production cap of 22.5 million barrels a day through the rest of the year. The figure is 400,000 barrels above the previous ceiling but will require OPEC to cut its actual production, currently estimated at 23 million barrels a day or more. The ministers also agreed at their two-day meeting to raise their minimum target price, to $21 a barrel from $18, for a basket of crudes monitored by OPEC. Because of an oil glut, the actual price recently has been about $16.25 per barrel. ``These agreements are a display of the complete unity of OPEC, which are unprecedented in the recent history of the organization,'' said Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh. Prices of energy futures settled slightly lower after initially rising on news of the OPEC pact. Some traders blamed technical factors and profit-taking from a price increase in anticipation of the OPEC meeting. If members don't cheat on their allocated quotas, analysts said, OPEC could reach its price by the end of the year, when the northern hemisphere winter will push up oil demand. Nauman Barakat, an energy specialist at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, predicted the accord's bite will be felt in the fall. ``It won't do anything for the market in August and September. But I think in the fourth quarter, if demand is 24.4 (million barrels a day for OPEC oil) as the cartel is saying and they're going to be producing at 22.5, they'll be drawing nearly 2 million barrels out of the market.'' ``That could make the fourth quarter, especially the tail end of the year, very strong.'' At the gasoline pump, he predicted an increase of ``at least 6 cents or even more _ say a dime _ by the end of the year.'' Paul Mlotok, head of energy research at the New York investment firm Morgan Stanley, said OPEC could get close to its target price, ``assuming they stick closely to their quota levels.'' He said this could add about 5 cents a gallon to gasoline prices by December. Michael S. Rothman, energy analyst at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, said Friday's accord sent an unexpectedly strong signal. ``The agreement is more bullish than what we've been looking for,'' he said. OPEC had not changed its benchmark price since December 1986. The increase signaled the once-dominant group's resolve to regain more influence over world prices, and it bore the stamp of Iraq. Producing above quota means more revenue for the country involved, but it undermines efforts to keep prices high. That problem was behind Saddam Hussein's recent belligerence and his call before the OPEC meeting for a $25 benchmark, widely considered a bargaining tactic rather than a real goal. The Iraqi leader last week threatened to use military force against overproducing OPEC members, saying their policies were forcing down prices and cost his war-ravaged economy billions of dollars in oil revenues. Iraq said Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates were largely responsible for the current oil glut, and Iraq reportedly massed 30,000 troops along the Kuwaiti border before the OPEC meeting. While diplomats say the forces are being withdrawn, Baghdad has vowed to press claims over oil production and land in proposed talks with Kuwait. OPEC efforts to prevent cheating on quotas via a special committee have not helped much. Analysts say that may change now. ``We do have a monitoring committee, but with a membership of one: Saddam Hussein,'' Barakat said. ``There's likely to be better production discipline due to the political developments in the gulf,'' Rothman said. Algerian Oil Minister Sadek Boussena, OPEC's newly elected president, opened the meeting Thursday with an appeal for halting overproduction. He said low prices threatened to bring OPEC countries to the brink of economic collapse. While other members may not agree with Iraq's methods, they privately welcome moves to stop cheating, Barakat said. ``They were totally perplexed how they could make U.A.E. and the Kuwaitis stick to their quotas,'' he said. ``There is certainly a lot of sympathy for Iraq trying to force the cheaters to come back into the fold.''

DOC.HEAD: Barr Defends Caterwauling Version of National Anthem
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Roseanne Barr admits she can't carry a tune but refused to apologize for a caterwauling version of the national anthem sung before booing baseball fans. Even President Bush showed his displeasure Friday. ``I'm sorry I didn't sing so good,'' the star of the top-rated ABC-TV comedy ``Roseanne'' said of her screeching rendition Wednesday night before 30,000 fans attending a doubleheader in San Diego's Jack Murphy Stadium. ``What else do I have to say? I figured everybody knew I wasn't the world's greatest singer.'' Barr said she nearly left the field in mid-song as fans of the San Diego Padres and the Cincinnati Reds bombarded her with boos. To top it off, it was ``Working Woman's Night'' at the ballpark. Barr, whose show chronicles the triumphs and struggles of a blue collar wife and mother with three kids, denied she was disrespectful. ``I represent a certain part of America that probably nobody else represents,'' she said. ``And I came out of someplace and got someplace, and I've got a right to sing the song.'' She recalled how in the first few notes of ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' she knew things were going wrong. ``Then everybody started booing me and I went into this panic thing,'' she said at a raucous news conference Friday at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. ``It took all the guts I've got in my life to finish singing.'' More than 2,000 phone calls about the unmelodious performance had come into the Padres switchboard by midday Friday. Barr said she had the best of intentions. She refused to apologize, although she used the word ``sorry'' several times. ``I'm not going to apologize for doing it,'' she said. ``But not anybody anticipated that it would be this negative.'' She capped her solo by grabbing her crotch and spitting _ actions she described as a parody of a baseball player, not a response to the boos. ``I probably should have waited a while before I scratched myself and spit,'' she said. ``But I wanted to get out of there.'' The news conference became as chaotic as her TV family on ``Roseanne'' when her husband, Tom Arnold, ordered police to eject a tabloid photographer. Photographer Kip Rano of American Photo Syndicate was led from a meeting room of the hotel after police warned he would be handcuffed and arrested if he refused to leave. In a Hollywood twist, Rano was escorted out by police Officer Paul Kramer _ the same motorcyclist who arrested and was slapped by actress Zsa Zsa Gabor last year. Barr said she had Rano expelled because ``I'm not going to talk to the tabloids. I'm suing them.'' Rano said his firm sells photos to ``everyone,'' including tabloid newspapers. He called the expulsion a publicity stunt by Arnold and Barr. Barr said her planned lawsuit against the National Enquirer would not be filed until next week. President Bush joined a chorus of boos for Barr's rendition of the anthem. It was ``disgraceful,'' Bush said while flying to Kennebunkport, Maine, for the weekend. ``That's the way I feel about it and I think a lot of San Diego fans said the same thing.'' Told of Bush's comment, Barr replied: ``I'm sorry I didn't sing so good. I'd like to hear him sing it.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Investigating Deaths of Young Boys During Filmmaking
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf `Scotland Yard...' with 1 graf to RECAST to CLARIFY. Pickup 3rd graf `Detective Superintendent...'
DOC.TEXT: Police are investigating the deaths of young boys who reportedly were killed during the filming of pornographic movies in London, Scotland Yard said. Scotland Yard said Friday that it is looking into news reports that up to a dozen young boys were sexually abused and slain in videos being sold by child pornography rings in Britain, Europe and the United States. Detective Superintendent Michael Hames, head of Scotland Yard's child pornography squad, said his investigators have not found any such films. ``To date we have not discovered any snuff movies,'' he said. ``We don't say they don't exist but we have not seized any. We don't know if they are being done here.'' Conservative lawmaker Geoffrey Dickens, who has been leading a 10-year crusade against child pornography, called on Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to ``publicly warn all parents to become busybodies about the whereabouts of their children.'' A Scotland Yard statement said a special squad of East London detectives was ``investigating the disappearance of a number of young boys dating back over a period of six years. The squad are also investigating the deaths of young boys during the making of films made in London and dating back to 1984.'' Detectives are believed to be studying the files of 20 missing boys, media reports said. Scotland Yard appealed for witnesses ``who may have been involved in the making of these films, who may have suffered sexual abuse or have any information.'' Police sources said the investigation has been under way for more than a year. Scotland Yard said an unidentified prisoner will appear in court Monday on charges of killing 6-year-old Barry Lewis, who vanished from near his south London home in September 1985. His body was found two years later in a shallow grave. Police still are investigating the boy's death and are looking into the activities of a number of other people in connection with the murder, Scotland Yard said. Police sources said some of these people may also be serving prison sentences.

DOC.HEAD: Veto Override Now Up to Legislators
LaserPhoto NU1
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers maneuvered to override Gov. Buddy Roemer's second veto in a month of legislation that would have made Louisiana the toughest anti-abortion state. ``Where I stand now reflects the majority of the people of this state,'' Roemer said. ``That does not mean it reflects the majority of the Legislature. That's to be determined and that's fair.'' The bill Roemer vetoed Friday would have prohibited abortions except to save the life of the mother and in cases of aggravated rape and incest reported to police and a physician no more than a week after they occurred. On July 6, Roemer vetoed an even tougher bill lacking the exceptions for rape and incest. Two-thirds majorities in both legislative chambers are required to override a veto; an override of the earlier veto passed the House but fell three votes short in the Senate. No Louisiana governor's veto has been overriden this century. Now, the 144 state legislators will be sent ballots next week to determine if they want to call a special override session in August. ``We ask every woman and man to stand with the governor, to urge the Legislature not to come back,'' said Teri Bartlett, director of Planned Parenthood of Louisiana. ``Enough is enough. This bill has embarrassed our state, terrorized our women and families.'' Rep. Woody Jenkins, a Democrat who leads the anti-abortion group, said he would try again to override Roemer's July 6 veto. The measure vetoed Friday was thrown together by the Legislature _ which has only three women members _ the day before its regular session ended July 9. Roemer said the bill was insensitive to women. ``It might serve us well, legislators and governors, who tend to be predominantly male, to take time to listen to the viewpoint of women,'' Roemer said. ``One of the most burdensome things about the bill that I vetoed today is that it did not listen at all,'' Roemer said. Roemer said ``rape is treated unevenly and unfairly,'' and said only aggravated rape would be excepted under the bill. It did not protect victims of simple rape, defined in Louisiana as sexual intercourse when a woman is incapable of resisting, such as when she is drunk, unconscious or afraid of the rapist. ``It's like simple rape was non-existent. It was like if a woman was mentally retarded she had no right and was fair game. How insensitive can you be?'' If the bill becomes law, doctors who perform abortions could be sentenced to 10 years in prison and $100,000 fines. The bill was designed to challenge the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion. Athough Roemer declared he remained ``pro life,'' anti-abortionists branded him an abortion-rights governor. ``We are going to override this governor,'' said Sue Fontenot, a city council member in Eunice and a member of Louisiana's Right to Life organization. ``He's betrayed the pro-life majority that elected him,'' said Nancy Myers, spokeswoman for the National Right to Life Committee in Washington. ``He's using phony excuses to hide the fact that he doesn't care at all for unborn children.'' Abortion-rights advocates said they were heartened. ``Governor Roemer's decision to veto the anti-abortion bill was a rational and reasonable decision,'' said Joy Gilmore, president of the state chapter of the National Organization for Women.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Seek Federal Aid for Possible Refugee Influx
DOC.TEXT: State officials called for federal cooperation if Cubans decide to take seriously a remark by President Fidel Castro for the United States to accept another wave of refugees similar to the 1980 Mariel boatlift. ``We cannot tolerate another Mariel. There is no way the community can absorb it,'' said Dade County Manager Joaquin Avino. More than 120,000 Cubans fled to Florida over a five-month period in 1980. Miami area leaders say they would need help in resettling refugees as well as federal controls on the numbers of visas to avoid another chaotic exodus. ``One can hardly oppose the free emigration from Cuba of people who are seeking freedom,'' said Miami's Cuban-born mayor, Xavier Suarez. ``We need the usual safeguards and guarantees so we wouldn't get people from jails. There should be a plan with people going to other parts of the country, and not all people into one community.'' Asylum-seekers packed the Peruvian Embassy in Havana in 1980, prompting the boatlift from the Cuban port of Mariel. A ragtag armada of Cuban-Americans sailed across the Florida Straits believing they were picking up relatives, friends and political prisoners, but some were forced to return with convicted criminals and vagrants. Today, most experts agree that fewer than 10 percent of the ``Marielitos'' were criminals. About 2,600 are still in federal custody, 173 were returned to Cuba and an estimated 4,000 are in various state and local prisons. In a speech Thursday on the 37th anniversary of the beginning of the Cuban revolution, Castro invited the United States and other nations to issue entrance visas and send boats to pick up refugees. In a sarcastic tone, Castro dared ``the Yankees'' if ``they want to receive these poor, persecuted citizens, let them send the boats and the visas.'' Cuban exiles in Miami said they believed the speech was solely intended to embarrass the United States. ``Fidel knows that the U.S. is in no position to issue tens of thousands of visas. What Castro is trying to tell Cubans is, `If you want to leave then leave, but they don't want you there,''' said Tomas Regalado, news director at WAQF-AM, a Spanish-language radio station. Under a 1984 agreement for orderly emigration, Cubans wishing to leave for the United States can go to the U.S. diplomatic mission in Havana and apply for visas. Last year, 10,046 Cubans were allowed to come here as immigrants, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said. INS spokesman Verne Jervis said the agency has a contingency plan for a Mariel-type refugee surge, and a change in the Cuban refugee flow might require a revision of the plan. ``But at the moment there is no reason to believe a boatlift situation is imminent,'' he said. Coast Guard spokesman Alastair Worden said there were no reports Friday of Cuban-Americans launching vessels to the island. So far this year, 216 Cuban refugees have been found this year in boats and home-made vessels floating toward Florida, said Worden. Last year, 390 Cubans were rescued by the Coast Guard.

DOC.HEAD: Losing Bid Offered Independent Check Of Mirrors, Documents Show
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasting lead to clarify, fixes typo in 2nd graf; picks up 3rd graf bgng The companies.
DOC.TEXT: In bidding to make the Hubble Space Telescope mirrors, Eastman Kodak planned independent tests that could have detected before its launch the focusing flaw that now cripples the $1.5 billion orbiting observatory, a company official says. Eastman Kodak planned to team with Itel Optical Systems to make two primary mirrors for the space telescope, according to documents released Friday by NASA in response to a Freedom of Information petition. The companies were to cross-check the accuracy of their mirrors to assure they were of the correct prescription and then one of the mirrors would be used on the telescope. NASA officials, however, awarded the contract in 1977 to Perkin-Elmer. The Danbury, Conn. firm, now known as Hughes Danbury Optical Systems, ground the mirrors itself and used its own personnel and equipment to check the mirror prescriptions. Perkin-Elmer's winning bid was $64.28 million. Kodak's proposal was for $99.79 million. Through overruns and delays, the cost of the Perkin-Elmer contract climbed to an eventual total of $451 million. The Hubble Space Telescope was launched in April and has been found to have a focusing flaw in either the primary or secondary mirror. This error, NASA officials have said, means the telescope is now able to capture images that are only about half as clear as those planned. Dick Wollensak, a vice president of Itek, which is now a subsidiary of Litton Industries, said that the losing Kodak-Itek bid called for a so-called ``end-to-end'' test that would have detected any flaw in the mirrors before the telescope was launched. ``We weren't going to build those things and then not test them after they were assembled,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``Between Kodak and Itek, there were facilities to test the assembled optical system without a major modification.'' NASA officials have said that the completed Perkin-Elmer optical assembly was not tested because it would have required a test facility that may have cost more than $100 million. As a result, the telescope was launched into space without ever being optically tested as an assembled unit. The focusing error was not discovered until the telescope was in orbit. Wollensak said the Perkin-Elmer design did not allow for the primary mirror to be tested after it was placed into the assembled telescope. He said the instrument was designed to work in zero gravity and the gravity of Earth caused the glass to sag slightly, which would have changed the focus. Kodak and Itel, however, had developed a way to prevent the sag and thus test the mirrors as an assembled unit, Wollensak said. Wollensak said he believes cost was a major factor in NASA selectinig Perkin-Elmer to make the Hubble optics. ``NASA had developed their own version of what it should cost and that was lower than the Itek-Kodak bid,'' Wollensak said. ``They felt that the Perkin-Elmer bid was low, but they though that the difference between the NASA expectation and the Perkin-Elmer bid would cover the overrun.'' As it turned out, the final, actual cost was seven times more than the Perkin-Elmer bid. Wollensak said the Kodak-Itel bid would have avoided many of the problems that led to the Perkin-Elmer overruns. A NASA committee investigating the flawed Hubble telescope plans to return to Perkin-Elmer's plan in Danbury on Aug. 15 for two more days of testimony and a review of documents and equipment related to the flawed optics. The committee met for two days this week in Danbury and an engineer who was there said it may take weeks to find the precise mistake that caused the flawed focus. The engineer, who asked for anonymity, said the investigation is like looking for a bookkeeping error. It will go on and on.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``It would have been good Perry Mason drama, L.A. Law drama, but I'm not about Perry Mason drama.'' _ Washington, D.C., Mayor Marion Barry on why he didn't testify at his drug and perjury trial.

``I've gone from probably one of the most hated people you could ever mention, to a point of where, everybody that comes up to me now is very sympathetic, and they're saying `I always thought you were innocent.''' _ Raymond Buckey after the longest and costliest criminal case in U.S. history ended with jurors deadlocked on charges he molested three girls.

``Enough is enough. This bill has embarrassed our state, terrorized our women and families.'' _ Teri Bartlett, director of Planned Parenthood of Louisiana, reacting to the state Legislature's efforts to override Gov. Buddy Roemer's veto of a tough anti-abortion bill.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pleased With Reaction To Souter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 3-5 to add Thornburgh remarks; picks up 3rd graf pvs bgng The president.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he's pleased with the initial reaction his Supreme Court nominee has received from senators and says New Hampshire jurist David Souter seems to have ``broad support'' for the post. At the same time, the president said he has no comment on highly critical comments of both him and Souter by Justice Thurgood M. Marshall. ``I have a very high regard for separation of powers and for the Supreme Court. And thus, I think people can get along without a comment from me on this interview,'' Bush told reporters aboard Air Force One on Friday. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, however, told a Boston news conference he was saddened by Marhsall's remarks. ``I believe it is the first time any sitting Supreme Court justice has ever in our history criticized an appointment and indeed criticized the president who made the appointment,'' Thornburgh said. ``I don't believe that is a constructive attitude to have on the eve of consideration by the Senate of the nomination of a man possessed by extraordinary qualitites of intellect, integrity and character.'' The president is spending the weekend at his oceanside family vacation home. Marshall said in a television interview on Thursday that he had never heard of Bush's nominee and believed some one else should have been given the appointment. In the interview on ABC-TV, Marshall also said he considered Bush to be ``dead'' and that Chief of Staff John Sununu was ``calling the shots.'' Souter, whom Sununu appointed to the New Hampshire Supreme Court when Sununu was governor in the 1980s, hitched a ride on Air Force One on Friday. He and Bush parted at Pease Air Force Base in Portsmouth, N.H. Souter was expected to spend the weekend at his home in Weare, N.H., and return to Washington on Monday. Souter, who has a reputation as a man of a few words, wandered back to the press section of Air Force One by himself at one point and said: ``I don't want to ruin my reputation. I have two things to say. Hi and Goodbye.'' Bush said it's hard to gauge how the Senate will vote because ``a lot have not expressed their views.'' But, he said he had received upbeat assessments on Souter's chances from Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., the ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, and from Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., who is Souter's chief Senate sponsor. Bush conceded that Souter's position on many issues was unknown, but he said, ``I think he's not the most well-known figure in the country, but that's not why I selected him. So he'll be plenty well-known when he gets testifying and gets through this process, which I think he'll do with flying colors.'' Bush said that although he had not sought Souter's views on controversial subjects like abortion, he had not agreed to a condition against grilling the nominee on such issues. ``No. Nothing on my side on that,'' he said. Rudman, who was also aboard Air Force One, had said Souter had told him he did not want to come to Washington if it meant that the president or others in the administration would ask him questions on potential decisions. Rudman said he had relayed the concern to Sununu, who had told him ``that is not our policy.'' Rudman said he then passed along those reassurances to Souter. The taciturn Souter has been ``in a state of near shock'' for the past few days, but has come out of it, Rudman told reporters on Air Force One. Meanwhile, Bush, who has championed a constitutional amendment to prohibit flag desecration, said that he was unhappy by the rendition given to the National Anthem earlier this week at a baseball game in San Diego by comedienne Roseanne Barr. ``My reaction is, it was disgraceful. That's the way I feel about it, and I think a lot of the San Diego fans said the same thing.'' Asked if he would stop watching her television show, Bush said: ``What show?'' Asked if she would not receive an invitation to the White House, the president said: ``There's no change of plans in that.'' Bush managed to get in 18 holes of golf on Friday after arriving. He planned to go boating today, then to attend the wedding here of a distant relative. He returns to Washington late Sunday, with no public events scheduled.

DOC.HEAD: Two Marines Killed in Helicopter Crash
DOC.TEXT: A Marine Corps helicopter crashed in the desert while on a training mission, killing two of the five Marines on board, authorities said today. The three survivors were taken to a hospital, but the extent of their injuries was not immediately disclosed. The UH-1N Huey helicopter crashed at 9:25 p.m. Friday in the Chocolate Mountain Bombing Range, about 55 miles west of the Marine Corps Air Station at Yuma, said Lance Cpl. Lisa Rodriguez. The victims' identities were being withheld until relatives could be notified, Rodriguez said. The injured Marines were transported to Yuma Regional Medical Center, where they were in stable condition, Rodriguez said. Kris Ozuna, a nursing supervisor at the hospital, said the extent of their injuries was still being evaluated. The helicopter was assigned to the Medium Light Attack Helicopter Squadron 367, 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing at Camp Pendleton, Calif., Rodriguez said. The helicopter was carrying practice rockets and small caliber ammunition when the crash occurred, she said. The squadron has been at the Yuma air station for two weeks of training exercises that began July 20.

DOC.HEAD: Cause of Death Still Unknown for Grateful Dead Keyboardist
DOC.TEXT: Investigators said it could be several weeks before they know what killed Brent Mydland, keyboard player for the popular counterculture rock band Grateful Dead. Mydland, 37, was found dead Thursday at his home in the San Francisco suburb of Lafayette. He had returned home Tuesday night from a three-week national tour with the band. An autopsy Friday morning failed to show how Mydland died, said Sgt. Richard Terry of the Contra Costa County coroner's office. He said toxicological tests will take two to four weeks. There were no indications of foul play, Terry said. The Tribune of Oakland quoted law enforcement sources saying no drugs or signs of drug use was found in Mydland's house. The sources were not identified. Grieving fans and friends sent cards, faxes and flowers to the band, band spokesman Dennis McNally said. ``We've got many calls of sympathy _ thousands. A lot of love and a lot of caring,'' McNally said. ``Our audience does care about the band, and this is a great loss.'' McNally said he assumed the band would go on with concerts scheduled in August and September in California, Ohio, Pennsylvania and New York City and in October in Sweden, West Germany, France and England. The Grateful Dead formed in 1965. The band, which tours extensively, is known for songs including ``Truckin''' and ``Touch of Grey,'' and for its devoted fans, ``Deadheads,'' who follow the band from show to show. Mydland joined the band in 1979. He also sang and composed songs, including ``Far From Me.''

DOC.HEAD: Black Moslems Take Prime Minister and Cabinet Hostage
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ A black Moslem leader said his rebels captured Prime Minister Arthur Robinson and his Cabinet in the Parliament building Friday, and claimed to have toppled the government of this southern Caribbean nation. But government radio early today broadcast a condemnation of the uprising and said police had moved into the streets of the capital to bring order in this mainly Catholic and Hindu country. There were no immediate reports of casualties. The attack on Parliament came Friday as the capital's police headquarters was blown up and explosions and gunfire were heard in the direction of the government's television station, which the rebels seized. ``The government has been overthrown,'' leader Abu Bakr of Jamaat al-Muslimeen, Arabic for the Moslem Group, said on government television. He promised ``free and fair'' elections within 90 days in Trinidad and Tobago, a former British colony of 1.3 million people on two islands that lie off the Venezuelan coast. ``We will stop the incest, robbery, and drugs which there was no hope for the present regime to stop,'' he said. Bakr's group has an estimated 250 followers. The country has a 1,500-member army and a 5,000-member police force. British West Indies Airways and American Airlines canceled commercial flights into Trinidad Friday evening, but the Piarco International Airport remained under control of government security forces. The National Broadcasting Service's Radio 610, the government radio station, said Robinson and his Cabinet were being held in the Red House, the Parliament building across the street from the central police station. Radio 610 said the police station was blown up and burned out of control for hours. Announcer Dennis McComie said no one attempted to put out the fire and there were several explosions of what he assumed was ammunition in the station. Bakr first appeared on television at 6 p.m. to announce the uprising by Jamaat al-Muslimeen. In Washington, State Department Spokesman Dave Denny said, ``We would deplore any attempt to overthrow the democratic government of Trinidad.'' Denny said the U.S. Embassy had reported gunfire and explosions in the vicinity of the TV station, which is several miles northwest of the parliamentary building, but only a few blocks below the hillside Hilton Hotel. Denny said he had no word about the situation of Americans in Trinidad and Tobago. The smaller island of Tobago is a popular vacation site. Bakr said there was no plan for violence, looting or retribution against civilians. Acting President Emmanuel Carter told Radio 610 that people should pray for a solution to the situation. ``Stay at home and let the protected (police) forces do their jobs,'' he said. McComie said at 3 a.m. today that there had been some looting and police had moved into the streets for the first time since the country's leading officials were seized. Radio 610 broadcast a statement from David Coore, Jamaican foreign affairs minister, deploring the uprising. His comments were heard on Radio 610 on a relay from Radio Jamaica. ``We call urgently and directly on those responsible for this totally unacceptable situation to release the hostages unconditionally and pursue whatever complaints they have by the regular processes of constitutional democracy which are the hallmark of our Caribbean Community,'' Coore said. Caribbean heads of state and their ministers were to meet this weekend in the Jamaican capital of Kingston for the annual meeting the Caribbean common market. Trinidad Foreign Affairs Minister Sahadeo Basdeo is in Kingston. It could not be ascertained how many ministers were taken hostage with Robinson, 63, a veteran political leader, lawyer and economist. Bakr, in his mid-40s, is a former Trinidad policeman and has been arrested several times in the past on charges of contempt of court and illegal demonstrations. He lives with 200 to 250 followers, their wives and children in a commune on the western side of Port-of-Spain. Members of the sect, founded in 1980, are widely perceived in Trinidad as violent outlaws, though the group's rhetoric is highly moralistic. Abu Bakr has said he doesn't recognize ``man's law,'' only ``the law of almighty Allah.'' In November of 1988, police raided the sect's sanctuary and seized weapons and ammunition. Bakr said then he was waging a war against ``the menace of cocaine.'' The Moslem group is known to have connections to Libya that are said to include some funding. Trinidad published reports say Abu Bakr has visited Libya. Trinidad and Tobago gained independence from Britain in 1962. It is an English-speaking country with a large populace from India. About a third of the people are Roman Catholic and a quarter are Hindu. Only about 6 percent are Moslem, most of them East Indians. There is great tension between the black and Indian Moslems. The rebel group in the past year has been occupying some government land in western Port-of-Spain. Recently, the government had denied customs approval of a shipment of medical supplies donated to Bakr by Libya.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., ASEAN Discuss Formation of Cambodian Council
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker and Southeast Asian nations were at odds today over whether communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas should be included in a Cambodian transitional government. ``If we are serious about the objective of Cambodian self-determination, we need ... to urge the formation of a supreme national council and the holding of U.N.-organized elections,'' Baker said. ``That impetus can come from offering new diplomatic incentives, and from showing no tolerance for the Khmer Rouge's dialogue of death,'' he said at the annual meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or ASEAN. The Khmer Rouge, known for their brutal rule of Cambodia from 1975-78, are militarily the strongest rebel group fighting an 11-year-old war against the Vietnamese-backed Communist government in Phnom Penh. Two other rebel groups are non-communist. ASEAN comprises Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Brunei and Indonesia. They scheduled a series of meetings today in their annual dialogue with major trading partners _ the United States, Japan, Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the European Community. The association holds that a Cambodian national council would have to include ``all shades of political opinion,'' including the Khmer Rouge. Baker announced last week that the United States would withdraw recognition of the United Nations seat held by the three-member Cambodia resistance coalition because it includes the Khmer Rouge. The group is blamed for hundreds of thousands of deaths when it ruled Cambodia from 1975-78 and now threatens a military comeback. Baker said Washington would open talks with Vietnam and possibly Phnom Penh itself to try to end the fighting. ASEAN wants the Cambodian guerrilla coalition to form the council, which would occupy the U.N. seat at the next session of the General Assembly. The association expects former head of state Prince Norodom Sihanouk to play a key role. His non-communist followers plus anti-communists under former Premier Son Sann make up the weaker portion of the coalition. Sihanouk issued a statement from Pyongyang, North Korea, this week that said there would be no peace in Cambodia unless the Khmer Rouge were allowed to participate in a political settlement on an equal footing with other warring factions. A series of inconclusive peace talks since 1988 sponsored by ASEAN has included the representatives of the Khmer Rouge, Sihanouk, Son Sann and Premier Hun Sen's Phnom Penh government. As envisioned by ASEAN, the supreme council would be headed by Sihanouk and serve as a repository for Cambodian sovereignty until free elections could be held under U.N. auspices. In other developments at the ASEAN meeting: _ Baker on Friday said the United States had done its share in helping Indochinese refugees and that criticism of U.S. policy was unfair. The ASEAN has criticized the United States and Vietnam for opposing the compulsory return of people who do not qualify as political refugees and at the same time not providing alternate solutions. Baker countered that since 1975, the United States has resettled 900,000 of 1.7 million Southeast Asian refugees and taken 120,000 more from Vietnam alone. _ A senior U.S. State Department official said the sultanate of Brunei has joined Singapore in offering American armed forces access to its territory. Singapore and Washington are negotiating an arrangement for increased use by U.S. warships and planes of the island's facilities. ``Brunei is also prepared for an enhanced security relationship,'' said the U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The oil-rich sultanate on the north coast of Borneo is expanding its navy with new patrol boats and buying its first fixed-wing combat aircraft _ 16 British-built Hawks.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Begin to Rebuild Lives One Month After Fire
DOC.TEXT: One month after a wind-swept wildfire destroyed hundreds of homes in the hills above Santa Barbara, residents are festooning the streets with banners for next week's annual fiesta. ``After the fire, the community was struck by an incredible feeling of shock,'' said spokeswoman Diana Vandervort. ``We're hoping the fiesta will foster a spirit of community rebuilding.'' The June 27 blaze killed a woman, left hundreds homeless and wrought more than $250 million in damages in an area north of Santa Barbara. In the Los Angeles suburb of Glendale, an 350-acre arson fire destroyed 46 homes and damaged 26 others the same day. Damage there was estimated between $30 million and $40 million. ``We were wondering if we really still had anything to celebrate,'' said Peter Georgi, an insurance agent who is directing Santa Barbara's Old Spanish Days fiesta, the biggest tourism event of the year for the city of 300,000. The five-day celebration begins Wednesday. Georgi, who had 10 clients lose homes in the blaze, said he asked them what they thought as he handed out claim checks. ``They said to go ahead, that they didn't have anything else to look forward to,'' he said in an interview. Red, green and yellow flags already line the fiesta's main thoroughfare. Food booths and stages are going up for the 100,000 people organizers hope will attend. The parade starting the fiesta will be dedicated to Andrea Lang Gurka, 37, who died as she tried to flee flames roaring toward her canyon home. Those who were left homeless also will be remembered. Mrs. Gurka's husband, Michael, said he wants to help educate people about fire safety and raise $100,000 to disseminate information on such things as fire-retardant buildings and prevention of post-fire soil erosion. ``I'm trying to find some meaning in this,'' Gurka, 36, told viewers of a July 6 fire-relief telethon. ``If we can educate people about fire, then potential human life won't be lost.'' In the fire-ravaged neighborhoods, surviving homes topped with manufactured roofing materials stand stark amid the ruins. New city and county ordinances require shingles of clay, metal or cement. Wood shake roofs, which exploded in flames the night of the fire, are now banned. Santa Barbara County says 441 single family homes were touched by the blaze, and 427 were destroyed along with 98 individual apartments. But the Red Cross, basing its figure on the number of families who have registered with the disaster agency, estimates 630 residences were destroyed. The county, strapped by a $4 million deficit before the fire, lost $5 million in public buildings and 20 patrol cars. Tourism has dropped by 10 percent to 15 percent, said spokesman Michael Forbes of the city's Tourism and Information Bureau. But the area's 4,700 hotel and motel rooms are booked solid for the festival, he said. ``What people don't realize is that the city of Santa Barbara did not burn down,'' he said. ``All of the attractions, the hotels, the shops, the beaches, all the reasons why people come Santa Barbara _ none of that was affected.''

DOC.HEAD: Witness: Secord, Southern Air Sought to Hide Roles
DOC.TEXT: Richard Secord and a cargo carrier once owned by the CIA took pains to hide their involvement in the illegal supply of arms to the Nicaraguan Contras during the mid-1980s, according to testimony at a federal trial. The family of William Sawyer Jr. and Eugene Hasenfus, sole survivor of a October 1986 crash in Nicaragua, claimed Friday that Secord and Southern Air Transport misrepresented the supply mission and skimped on safety equipment. Sawyer died when the Sandinistas shot down the C-123 cargo plane as it ferried supplies to the U.S.-backed rebels. The incident helped unravel the Iran-Contra affair. In the trial of a federal damage lawsuit, attorneys for Hasenfus and the Sawyer family are seeking a preliminary estimate of $3.4 million, including expenses caused by the crash and lost income. Secord, a retired Air Force general who pleaded guilty to lying to Congress about Iran-Contra, and the Miami-based airliner deny they were legally responsible for Hasenfus and Sawyer. They also contend that the men knew the risks they were taking. Richard Gadd, who helped National Security Council aide Oliver North, Secord and Southern Air set up the operation, said in written testimony Friday that the use of Corporate Air Services and other companies was designed to hide who was behind the supply effort. Southern Air was once owned by the CIA and continued to do contract work for the U.S. government, Gadd said. Gadd and Southern Air President William Langton decided the effort ``should be treated as a clandestine or covert activity (so the) media could not attempt to trace it back to the owners and the United States government,'' the deposition said. Gadd said Secord directed the funds and made policy decisions in the enterprise, a major point for Hasenfus, who is trying to prove that Secord was his real employer. In another development, Gadd referred to comments by Langton that former CIA agent Felix Rodriguez had advised then-Vice President George Bush of problems with the supply effort. Rodriguez helped run the Contra supply operation out of El Salvador. Rodriguez testified Friday about equipment problems with the planes, especially in early 1986. In June 1986, he brought North a letter from crewmen complaining their navigational equipment was inadequate. Over the strong objections of Southern Air attorneys, Rodriguez testified that the only radar detection devices aboard were Radio Shack ``fuzz busters,'' designed to allow drivers to spot police patrol cars on the highway. But Rodriguez said that after he left the supply operation by September 1986, he understood that flights had increased and equipment had improved. The former agent left the CIA in 1976, and is credited with capturing Cuban leader Fidel Castro's close ally Ernesto ``Che'' Guevara in Bolivia. He also was a veteran of the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Attack City Center, Rebel Leader Claims Rival Government
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: This report is based in part on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia, including Associated Press correspondent Michael Goldsmith.

Rebels fought in the streets of the capital with troops loyal to President Samuel Doe, and one rebel leader claimed to have set up his own government. Doe, through a spokesman, maintained Friday he would never resign as leader of this West African nation and predicted his troops would defeat the rebels within two weeks. The spokesman, who was not identified, spoke in a radio telephone call to the British Broadcasting Corp. in London. Later Friday, Radio ELWA outside Monrovia broadcast a speech by rebel leader Charles Taylor in which he claimed to have established his own government. No details were given in the speech from the missionary station, which apparently had been taken over by Taylor's supporters. In a similar uprising in 1985, rebels took over a Liberian radio station and made a broadcast in which they claimed to have ousted Doe. The claim proved groundless. In Washington, State Department spokesman David Denny said U.S. officials were aware of Taylor's latest broadcast but that they had no indication the 7-month-old civil war was over. ``On the contrary, fighting continues,'' he said. He declined comment on specifics of what Taylor said. Troops loyal to Taylor, the National Patriotic Front president, remained blocked by government troops in Paynesville, more than six miles from the city center. The more than 300 rebels who invaded the center of Monrovia by two bridges Friday were supporters of rival rebel leader Prince Johnson. They took control of streets on the banks of the Mesurado River and told residents to leave by way of the captured bridges. Witnesses said hundreds heeded the order. Rebels have fought their way into the city on other occasions, but either withdrew or were driven out. This time, some government soldiers were seen stripping off their uniforms, throwing away their rifles and fleeing in civilian clothes as the rebels advanced. More than 100 government troops were sent to the waterfront area and heavy fighting ensued. Battles also broke out in the diplomatic quarter of Mamba Point and government troops sent heavy artillery to a hill overlooking the city center close to dipolmatic missions. Meanwhile, Doe remained in the executive mansion in a last-ditch attempt to prevent a takeover by rebels. Panicky soldiers carried out random arrests of civilians, accusing them of supporting the rebels. Responding to witness accounts of a spate of tribal killings by government soldiers this week, acting Information Minister Paul Allen Wie said such kilings were ``not government policy.'' A communique issued by five European Community ambassadors in Monrovia on Thursday condemned the summary executions of 100 Gio and Mano tribesmen. Many of the rebels come from those ethnic groups. The rebels also are accused of killing members of tribes that support Doe. Doe's defense minister, Boimah Barclay, went to the John F. Kennedy hospital in the city, where dozens of people were rounded up by soldiers Wednesday, and ``took action to prevent any further killing,'' Wie said. The rebels, who began their offensive in December, accuse the government of corruption and human rights abuses. At least 375,000 Liberians have fled the fighting into neighboring Guinea, Ivory Coast and Sierra Leone, the office of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees said in Geneva. The U.N. appointed a special representative Friday to coordinate relief operations.

DOC.HEAD: Queen's Lawyers Win Publication Ban on Ex-Employees's Memoirs
DOC.TEXT: A High Court judge has issued a temporary injunction banning a book that reportedly gives intimate details about Britain's Royal family. Justice Michael Wright on Friday banned author Malcolm Barker from publishing his book, ``Courting Disaster,'' anywhere in the world, but stayed the ban until 4:30 Monday afternoon, pending an appeal. The injunction also forbids Barker's publisher, Fleetwood Publications, from selling the book in Britain. Lawyers for Barker and Fleetwood Publications said they will appeal the part of the court order that bans Barker from publishing outside Britain. Barker worked from 1980 to 1983 as a lowly storeman-clerk to the master of the royal household at Buckingham Palace. The book makes disclosures that lawyers for Queen Elizabeth II claim breach a confidentiality agreement signed by Barker when he joined the palace staff. Royal staff are required to sign agreements not to disclose details of what they see and hear while in royal service as a legally binding contractual condition of employment. The injunction will remain in effect until the High Court hears an action, brought by the attorney general on behalf of the queen, to permanently ban the book and to direct any profits from the book to the attorney general. If Barker, who lives in the Canadian province of Nova Scotia but is currently visiting Britain, disobeys the order he could be jailed and face heavy fines for contempt of court. Angered by behind-the-scenes disclosures by former employees, the palace in recent years has increasingly reverted to legal action to suppress a succession of spicy memoirs. ``Courting Disaster,'' published by the Nova-Scotia based Fleetwood Publications, is on sale in Canada, the United States and Bermuda, said Barker's lawyer, David Fowell. Fowell said 20,000 copies of the book had been printed and magazine serialization rights had been sold to Australian, American and French magazines. Lawyers for Queen Elizabeth on Tuesday obtained an injunction against an eight-page excerpt of the book in the current edition of the French publication, Paris Match. The excerpt was removed from the 8,000 copies of the magazine sold in Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rain in Minnesota, Strosm from Texas to Kansas and Along East Coast
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms drenched Minnesota today after a night of pounding rain flooded roads and basements and backed up storm sewers. The National Weather Service said up to six inches of rain fell in the southern part of the state. Today's forecast called for heavy rain in Minnesota and other flood-ravaged states such as Iowa and Wisconsin. A band of thunderstorms also was expected from Texas to southern Kansas. Showers were expected along the Atlantic coast from the Carolinas to Maine. Hot, dry weather with temperatures in the 100s lingered over much of the desert Southwest and eastern California. The high temperature for the nation Friday was 113 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Last Citroen Deux Chevaux Rolls Off Production Line After 42 Years
LaserPhoto LIS2
DOC.TEXT: Automakers bade farewell to the legendary Citroen Deux Chevaux, conceived by its French designer as a ``four-wheeled sofa covered by an umbrella.'' The last car rolled off the factory line Friday after 42 years in production, and the finale took place in Portugal, where Citroen moved production after shutting down its Levallois assembly line near Paris. There were no public ceremonies at the Mangualde factory, ``just a little get-together for the workers who have been making them,'' said a Citroen Lusitania spokesman, Teixeira de Abreu. But Citroen fans worldwide will mourn the demise of the turtle-shaped Deux Chevaux _ named literally for ``two horses,'' or the horsepower produced by its chugging air-cooled engine. It was officially designated the 2CV and came with open-flap side-windows, mattress-like suspension and scrawny tires. More than 3.86 million were sold since the launch at the 1948 Paris Auto show for $650. Including a van, more comfortable Ami and Dyane versions, and even a four-wheel drive derivative, more than 7 million Deux Chevaux have hit the roads. Thousands of fans have set up about 300 owners' clubs worldwide. Citroen's hi-tech AX compact will substitute the 2CV at the Mangualde plant. But, according to Gavin Green, chief editor of Britain's Car Magazine, ``no car will replace it _ there's no successor in sight. It's the end of an era.'' He says most owners have an emotional relationship with their 2CV that, like the Volkswagen Beetle and the British-made Mini, has become a motoring legend. In 1935, Citroen boss Pierre-Jules Boulanger asked his designers to dream up a small, avant-garde car for all classes of folk that would be like ``a four-wheeled sofa covered by an umbrella.'' Boulanger demanded enough headroom for an opera-bound gentleman wearing a top hat, but also a car supple enough to transport at least two peasants with a basket of eggs across a ploughed field without smashing their fragile cargo. All that without using more than about 2.4 gallons of fuel for 60 miles. The first wooden mock-ups had one headlamp, a serrated hood that looked like a cheese grater. Functional interior appointments included a roll-back canvas roof, a hand-operated windshield wiper and hammock seats. When World War II broke out in 1939, Boulanger had all but one of the 250 running prototypes destroyed. He hid the survivor in a barn.
