Available only in gray at the 1948 Paris launch, the Deux Chevaux could manage a top speed of 37 mph. Sales soon rocketed and in 1950, the waiting list was six years long. Sales began to slacken in the mid-1980s. The 2CV can no longer meet emission laws in Switzerland and Austria, nor safety regulations in Sweden and Finland. But Green is convinced that life could have begun at 40 for the car that still has a loyal clientele in France, Britain, West Germany, Belgium and Ireland. ``Sales are only dropping because Citroen isn't advertising _ there's no genuine reason to kill the car. I think they're a bit embarrassed by it not fitting their hi-tech image.''

DOC.HEAD: Zsa Zsa Begins 3-Day Sentence: For $85 A Day, Her Own Cell And TV Dinners
DOC.TEXT: Zsa Zsa Gabor arrived at the city jail in a black Mercedes to serve a three-day sentence as part of her conviction for slapping a police officer. ``I looked around for a jail and thought El Segundo's would be appropriate,'' Miss Gabor's lawyer, Harrison Bull, said Friday. The actress is paying $85 a day to stay in the jail, avoiding having to do time with the general county jail population. Miss Gabor, 72, has a private cell of her choice and will eat TV dinners. ``It costs about ... the same rate as the Hilton nowadays,'' Bull said. Miss Gabor checked out of her $15 million Bel-Air mansion and into the city lockup in this gritty Los Angeles suburb known for oil refineries. She was convicted of three misdemeanors after slapping a Beverly Hills officer, Paul Kramer, in June 1989 when he pulled over her Rolls-Royce for expired plates. A judge enforced a three-day jail sentence this May after deciding she'd violated probation by failing to perform 120 hours of community service at a shelter for homeless women. ``She seemed to be a very pleasant lady,'' when she was booked into the jail about 1 p.m., said Fern Ruiz, a Police Department records clerk. She'll be a free woman again at 1 p.m. Monday, Ruiz said. ``I'll tell you one thing. I didn't do anything wrong,'' Miss Gabor said on her way to her 8-foot by 10-foot cell that has a metal-frame bed, toilet, sink and not much else. She'll be allowed to wear her own clothing. Ruiz said she'll spend her days doing clerical work. ``That's something she has expressed an interest in,'' Ruiz said. Beverly Hills Municipal Judge Charles Rubin also ordered Miss Gabor to pay nearly $13,000 in fines and restitution.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Leader Has Fought With Government for Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf, `Most East...' with 1 graf to CORRECT description of island's population. No pickup. Abu Bakr is pronounced AH-boo BAH-kuhr.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Trinidad-Uprising, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Abu Bakr, the Moslem leader whose rebels captured the prime minister and his Cabinet in a coup attempt, has been fighting with the government for years. Most recently, Bakr has been involved in a dispute over medical supplies and pharmaceuticals reportedly donated by Libya and prohibited by customs agents from entering the country. One of the first things Bakr did after taking the leaders captive was accuse the government of refusing to let him distribute free medicine to the poor people of Trinidad and Tobago. Members of his sect, Jamaat al-Muslimeen, have long been perceived by many Trinidadians as violent outlaws, although they proclaim moralistic motives for their actions. Bakr, in his mid-40s, founded Jamaat al-Muslimeen, Arabic for ``Group of Moslems,'' six years ago. He has said he does not recognize ``man's laws,'' but only ``the law of almighty Allah.'' On Friday, he said he understood ``the present suffering of the people'' and that Prime Minister Arthur Robinson had been overthrown by God. ``God has removed him,'' Bakr said on government television. ``No man, including me, has power. ... He gave us victory over the prime minister.'' Bakr, his 200 to 250 followers and their wives and children live on a commune in western Port-of-Spain. In 1988, police raided the commune, seizing weapons and ammunition and arresting 34 members of the sect on charges of larceny, robbery, illegal possession of weapons, rape and murder. Bakr, a former policeman, said then his vigilantes were waging a war against ``the menace of cocaine.'' On Friday, he said, ``We will stop the incest, robbery, and drugs which there was no hope for the present regime to stop.'' Moslems make up 6 percent of the population of Trinidad and Tobago, a former British colony just off the northeast coast of Venezuela. Of the nation's 1.3 million people, about 40 percent are of African descent and the same proportion is of East Indian descent. Most of the East Indians are Hindu. Most of the Africans are Roman Catholic or Protestant. The nation's small Moslem population is mostly East Indians with some Africans. But the black Moslem population has grown since the black power movement began 20 years ago, and Bakr's sect is the largest among them.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Killed, 127 Arrested in Scattered Violence
DOC.TEXT: Eight blacks were killed and 127 people arrested in township violence throughout the country, police said today. The most serious incident occurred in Khayelitsha outside Cape Town, where a mob stoned a private truck, causing the driver to lose control, police said. The vehicle crashed into a crowd, killing three women and a man. The bodies of four men who had been stabbed to death were found at three separate sites in black areas in the eastern part of the country, police added. Of the 127 people arrested, 74 were detained outside the southern city of Port Elizabeth, where demonstrators refused a police order to disperse, authorities said. The police unrest report also listed several incidents in which youths stoned homes, police and private vehicles and set them alight. The daily police report, which covers incidents from the preceding 24 hours, did not provide additional details. Black townships throughout the country remain wracked by violence despite plans by President F.W. de Klerk to dismantle apartheid and negotiate a black-white power-sharing agreement. The violence has included confrontations between activists and police as well as rival blacks groups battling each other for supremacy.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes on Crowded Tel Aviv Beach Injuring 15
DOC.TEXT: A pipe bomb exploded today on a crowded Tel Aviv beach, injuring 15 people, hospital officials said. No group claimed responsibility for the attack. Army radio said dozens of Arabs in the area were rounded up for questioning. The radio also said police were forced to protect Arab beachgoers from angry Israelis and that one Israeli was detained for attacking Arabs. Army radio said the pipe bomb was placed under the sand near a life guard stand. Dr. Dianka Ledderman, deputy director of Tel Aviv's Ichilov hospital, where the injured were taken, said one woman was in fair condition and the other 14 were suffering from slight wounds from shrapnel. It was the first bombing since July 1 when a letter bomb exploded inside a staircase mail box, slightly injuring three people. On May 28, one man was killed and nine injured when a bomb went off in Jerusalem's Ben-Yehuda market. Two Palestinian groups, the fundamentalist Islamic Jihad and a Syrian-backed dissident faction of the PLO, claimed responsibility for that attack.

DOC.HEAD: Another Republic Declares Sovereignty, Baltics To Negotiate With Yeltsin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs to UPDATE with Baltics saying they will not help rewrite a new Soviet treaty. Pickup 15th graf pvs, `Tass, reporting...'
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of the three Baltic republics said today they will not join negotiations to rewrite the treaty that created the Soviet Union, preferring instead to talk directly with Moscow about obtaining independence. On Friday, the three republics agreed to bypass the Kremlin by signing political and economic treaties with the Russian Federation. Also on Friday, another Soviet republic, Byleorussia, declared its sovereignty. Taken together, the three developments represent strong new challenges to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He seeks a new treaty with all 15 Soviet republics to transfer some powers from the central government to local authorities seeking more autonomy from Moscow. But today, the presidents of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia said they ``consider it impossible'' to participate in the rewriting of the treaty. They said it would ``be best'' if negotiations with Moscow ``were held on the basis of the three-plus-one principle'' _ that is, the three Baltic states plus the Soviet government. The statement was signed by Estonian President Arnold Ruutel, Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov and Vytautas Landsbergis, the president of Lithuania, which already plans talks with Moscow about its independence. On Friday, Baltic leaders urgently called for talks with the republic of Russia after meeting with its reformist president, Boris N. Yeltsin. The meeting came during Yeltsin's vacation in the Latvian beach resort of Jurmala. The presidents said the talks would be aimed at agreeing to treaties between each Baltic state and Russia on ``political, legal, economic, scientific and technical, cultural aspects of mutual relations, on relations between nationalities and citizenship.'' Their statement, carried by the Estonian News Service, said the treaties should be ready to sign within six to eight weeks. The Interfax news agency quoted Yeltsin as saying the first treaty must be ready to sign within 45 days. Tass reported early today that a Latvian delegation would go to Moscow, the capital of both Russia and the Soviet Union, on Monday to begin talks. Latvian sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the treaties would probably include Russian recognition of the Baltics' independence. Yeltsin was quoted as telling Latvian television he envisages the treaties as agreements between equal and sovereign states. Meanwhile, Byelorussia, a republic that borders Poland, became the ninth republic to take steps to distance itself from Moscow. The republic's Parliament Friday approved a declaration of sovereignty, saying its laws take precedence over national laws and that the republic has the right to run its own armed forces, Tass reported. Russia, the Ukraine and Uzbekistan have also declared their sovereignty, and the Ukraine claims the right to have its own armed forces. The Georgian Parliament has condemned the republic's annexation by the Soviet Union and called for negotiations on independence. Moldavia's Parliament this week codified its June declaration of sovereignty and approved a decree stating that all power in the western republic belongs to the people. Lithuania declared independence on March 11, and Latvia and Estonia both have declared their intent to follow at the end of unspecified transition periods. Lithuania said June 29 it would freeze its declaration in return for an end to a Soviet economic blockade and the start of talks on secession. Tass, reporting on the declaration approved in the Byelorussian capital Minsk, said: ``It was decided that the republic has the right to its own military forces, its interior forces, its organs of state and public security, under the control of the republic's Supreme Soviet.'' ``Byelorussia establishes the superiority of the constitution and laws of the republic on its territory and its independence in external relations,'' Tass said. ``From now on, the republic will officially celebrate its independence day on July 27.''

DOC.HEAD: Chopper Crashes Kill 5 Soldiers in Arkansas, 2 Marines in California
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to CORRECT description of terrain as hilly sted mountainous; move up reference to night training. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `In Southern...'.
DOC.TEXT: An Army helicopter crashed during night training exercises, killing five soldiers and injuring eight others, authorities said today. The Army UH-60 helicopter, known as a Blackhawk, crashed late Friday night in a remote, wooded area of Fort Chaffee, in west-central Arkansas just east of the Oklahoma state line, said fort spokesman Cecil Green. It was one of two fatal military helicopter crashes Friday night. The other, in California, killed two Marines. The Fort Chaffee chopper had been participating in routine night training maneuvers at the Joint Readiness Training Center when the crash occurred shortly before 11:30 p.m. about four miles south of Charleston, Green said. As for the cause of the crash, ``the only thing we know is that the helicopter was in radio contact with one of the team members on the ground,'' he said. The ground unit notified headquarters of the crash, he added. Five soldiers died and eight were injured, he said. Names of the victims and the conditions of the injured were not immediately released. Rescuers had to walk more than a mile to find the helicopter in the hilly region north of the Ouchita Mountains, he said. Other helicopters were used to get the injured to St. Edward Mercy Medical Center at Fort Smith. In Southern California, meanwhile, a Marine Corps helicopter crashed in the desert Friday night, killing two and injuring three others, authorities said. The UH-1N Huey helicopter crashed in the Chocolate Mountain Bombing Range in California, about 55 miles west of the Marine Corps Air Station at Yuma, Ariz., said Marine Lance Cpl. Lisa Rodriguez. The names of the two Marines killed were being withheld until relatives could be notified, Rodriguez said. The three injured Marines were in stable condition at Yuma Regional Medical Center, Rodriguez said. Kris Ozuna, a nursing supervisor at the hospital, said their injuries were being evaluated. The Huey was carrying practice rockets and small caliber ammunition when the crash occurred about 9:25 p.m. PDT, Rodriguez said. The squadron, based at Camp Pendleton, Calif., has been at the Yuma air station since July 20 for two weeks of training exercises.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Militias Clash in South, 16 Killed, 30 Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 19 grafs to UPDATE casualty toll, ADD details, CORRECT overall death toll in 3-year Shiite clash. Pickup 15th graf, `Amal calls...'
DOC.TEXT: Fierce fighting raged today between rival Shiite Moslem militias backed by Syria and Iran, leaving at least 16 combatants dead and 30 wounded, police said. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said artillery clashes first broke out between the Syrian-backed Amal militia and the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, at 3:30 a.m. on the northwestern edge of Iqlim al-Tuffah, the Apple Province. He said by the afternoon fighting raged across an eight-mile, V-shaped front in the disputed province. ``The whole front is on fire,'' the spokesman said. He said at one point artillery shells were falling at the rate of 20 per minute. The thud of exploding shells echoed across the region and could be heard in Sidon, a provincial capital 25 miles south of Beirut. Hezbollah said an hour after the shelling started that Amal fighters, backed by guerrillas of Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat, launched an attack on its positions in the village of Kfar Milki. Police said the fighting left at least 16 combatants dead and 30 wounded. Kfar Milki, six miles southeast of Sidon, is a strategic hilltop village that Hezbollah overran in a major attack across the Apple Province in January. The police spokesman said the PLO guerrillas sealed off the region west of Kfar Milki, preventing policemen and reporters from watching the confrontation. He said, however, that ambulances evacuated four dead Palestinian guerrillas and took 23 wounded to hospitals in nearby Sidon. ``The Palestinians are obviously involved in the fighting, but we can't establish whether they are taking part in ground attacks or just participating in the shelling duel with Hezbollah gunners,'' the police spokesman said. A force of about 1,000 guerrillas, drawn mainly from Arafat's mainstream Fatah faction, mans a narrow buffer separating Amal and Hezbollah positions in the disputed region. The buffer extends from Kfar Milki at the region's northwestern edge to the village of Arab Saleem on the southwestern flank. The Palestinian deployment blocked Hezbollah's advance west toward the Mediterranean coast and south toward the main Shiite cities. A Hezbollah statement issued in Beirut said the Amal-Palestinian attack was crushed. ``The attackers lost many casualties and withdrew west,'' the statement said without further elaboration. The police spokesman, however, said no changes in positions were reported. Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia, said a Hezbollah source stressed that its fighters were willing to accept a cease-fire to allow the Red Cross to evacuate casualties. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting on and off for more than three years for control of the 1.2 million Shiites, the largest sect in Lebanon. Nearly 1,200 people have died in the clashes and more than 4,000 have been wounded. Amal calls the Hezbollah attacks an ``Iranian invasion,'' charging that the 2,000 Iranian Revolutionary Guards contingent in Lebanon was involved. The command of the Iranian contingent, in a rare statement, defended its role saying it was aimed only at ``fighting the Zionists and defending the Moslems.'' The disputed area is adjacent to the self-designated ``security zone'' Israel occupies in southern Lebanon. The Iranian statement, published by the leftist newspaper As-Safir, called on Amal and Hezbollah to ``end the fighting among brethren and unite your guns against the Zionist enemy.'' The Iranian guards came to Lebanon in 1982 with the declared objective of taking part in confronting Israel's invading army. They set up headquarters in the eastern Lebanon town of Baalbek and have since trained most of Hezbollah's fighters.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Splits into Two Branches
DOC.TEXT: A breakaway branch of Solidarity today formed a new party to rival the faction that backs Lech Walesa. The new party, the Citizens Movement for Democratic Action, includes many heroes of Solidarity's successful struggle against Communist rule in the 1980s. Its founding congress today drew more than 1,000 delegates from around the country. Organizers said they want the party to offer support to Solidarity Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who is frequently criticized by Walesa. A pro-Walesa party, the Center Alliance, was formed two months ago. Zbigniew Bujak, a Solidarity leader during the years the movement was banned, acknowledged the formation of the two parties reflects ``polarization'' within Solidarity. But he said that ``does not have to be bad.'' ``A democratic country is a country of different proposals. We will have to forget about the otherwise comfortable structure in which the picture was black and white ... just us against them,'' he told the new party's members. In its first political move, the congress voted nearly unanimously to endorse a constitutional amendment mandating a popularly elected president. Currently, the president is chosen by the two chambers of Parliament. The new party's members include many of Walesa's longtime advisers and allies in Solidarity. Among them are Adam Michnik, Solidarity theoretician and editor-in-chief of Gazeta Wyborcza, Poland's largest daily; filmmaker Andrzej Wajda; Henryk Wujec, secretary of the Solidarity parliamentary caucus; Andrzej Wielowieyski, deputy speaker of the Senate; government ministers Aleksander Hall, Jacek Kuron and Witold Trzeciakowski; and several deputy ministers. Forty-two parliament deputies and senators have joined, along with up to 5,000 ordinary citizens who signed up nationwide. ``We want to build a wide consensus of all those in favor of democracy. We do not want to be left-wing or right-wing,'' Michnik told the group. ``We want to get it together in our own new way.'' The new party and the Center Alliance, loyal to Walesa, clash on several key points. The Center Alliance calls for electing Walesa president by the current parliament this fall, urges immediate privatization of the economy and the faster ouster of holdover Communists from positions of authority. It warns that the Mazowiecki government should speed up political and economic reforms and emphasizes Polish patriotism. The new party wants early presidential elections but not by parliament, arguing that the current chamber is tainted by the 1989 political deal that set aside a portion of seats for Communists. It generally supports the policies of the Mazowiecki government, and says Poland should move closer to Europe and ``overcome backwardness.''

DOC.HEAD: Mild Earthquake Hits Northern Japan
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook northern Japan on Saturday afternoon, but no damage or casualties were reported, officials said. The Central Meteorological Agency said the quake had a preliminary reading of 5.7 on the Richter scale and was centered 18 miles under the seabed off Fukushima Prefecture (state), 150 miles northeast of Tokyo. Local police officials said there were no immediate reports of damage or casualties from the undersea quake. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded by seismographs. Every increase of one means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of 5 on the Richter scale is considered ``very strong, a 6 ``severe,' capable of widespread damage near the epicenter.

DOC.HEAD: Peruvians Left Thirsty, Dirty and Sick By Severe Drought
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hancco Ccama in 1st graf cq
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Peru, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Every morning, Natividad Hancco Ccama walks half an hour across brown sand to fill two buckets with dirty water. Mrs. Hancco steps carefully as she returns to her thatch house on a barren hill. The daily ration of two buckets is all the water she and her two small children have for drinking, cooking and bathing. ``We live worse than animals,'' she said, holding her son's scab-covered hand. ``Sometimes I cry all day from anger.'' Until early this year, trucks brought water to Mrs. Hancco's house in a shantytown outside Lima. Now, with Peru suffering its worst drought of the century, the trucks are delivering water to richer neighborhoods that have gone dry. Most of Lima's 7 million people are affected. Even upper-class neighborhoods go entire days without water. Clothing, dishes and food cannot be washed. Toilets are not flushed. Bathtubs are covered in dust. The poor suffer most. ``People are dying out here,'' said Dr. Rafael Medina, one of three doctors who care for the 22,000 people living in or near Cruz de Motupe. Like the rest of the shantytown's dusty buildings, Medina's clinic has no electricity or telephone. Slogans scrawled in red paint by members of the Maoist guerrilla group Shining Path cover its cinder block walls. ``These people don't even have enough fuel to boil the water, and the water is filthy,'' Medina said. Intestinal disease has risen 52 percent this year in Cruz de Motupe, and similar increases had been recorded in Lima's many other shantytowns, according to Camelia Pflacker, a Health Ministry official. Peru already has one of the world's worst rates of infant mortality _ 81 per 1,000 _ mostly due to intestinal disease. Thousands of poor people recently marched through downtown Lima to demand water. ``Water is a right and not a privilege,'' many of their banners said. The government says there is little it can do. Lima is in the middle of a desert, and rain is rare. Most of the city's water comes from the Rimac River, which is fed by mountain streams, and a drought in the southern Andes has left the streams nearly dry. According to the Meteorological Service, the drought is caused by a change in the winds that usually bring moist sea air to the mountains. Decades of neglect of Peru's infrastructure make the situation worse. Not only has the water supply been cut in half, the city water company said, but 48 percent of that seeps into the ground or spills into the ocean through broken pipes. Other other basic services also have collapsed because of the drought. Lima's power comes from five hydroelectric plants. It is being rationed, and the daily outages in turn affect the water company's ability to move water and operate wells. Reservoirs built to run the hydroelectric plants during the dry season now supply much of the capital's water. An emergency well-digging program has helped, but ground water levels are dropping rapidly. The water company says many wells will go dry within a few months, and the power company says its reservoirs hold only enough water to operate its plants until the next rainy season, in November. Peru is poorly prepared to deal with the drought's effects. It is in the grips of its worst economic crisis, inflation exceeds 3,000 percent a year, four of five people lack steady work and the government is bankrupt. President-elect Alberto Fujimori issued a plea for emergency food aid even before taking office Saturday. For now, a few hundred water trucks must serve Lima's thirsty millions. ``It's not an easy job,'' said Santiago Guttierez, who is in charge of 100 trucks. ``We have 250,000 more people to bring water to than last year.'' He pointed at a 30-year-old Ford, its tank leaking from at least 20 holes, and added: ``And we don't have the best equipment.'' Many residents of Cruz de Motupe complain about the men who drive the trucks. They say the price is 35 cents for 20 gallons of water, but the drivers often charge more. The same amount of water delivered by pipe to an upper-class home costs a fraction of a cent. ``We have no choice but to pay,'' said Rosalia Diez, who is 29 and has four children. ``At least my husband has a job. Some people just can't afford the water. It's really terrible.'' Yellow and red flowers bloom in front of the Diez shack, nourished by the family dishwater. Nelly Gonzalez lives where the water trucks rarely go. The plants in front of her house are dead. She has seven children. Her husband makes shoes. ``To have money and not to have water for the babies . ... It's absurd. It's tragic. I hope the rains come soon, because if they don't, I think it means we're not supposed to live.''

DOC.HEAD: Philippines Faces Major Challenge in Earthquake Recovery
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The July 16 earthquake has silenced President Corazon Aquino's opponents temporarily, but sets the stage for deeper crises if her government is not effective in handling the recovery. The quake, which killed more than 1,600 people, also may affect the outcome of talks on the future of the six U.S. military bases in the Philippines. The government relied heavily on U.S. resources in the first critical hours. ``Some governments have turned disasters like this to their advantage,'' a Western diplomat said on condition of anonymity. ``This could be an opportunity for them to show they're a functioning government, but it easily could turn into a real mess.'' Because of the earthquake, Mrs. Aquino appears to have gained a respite from political problems in Congress and challenges both from Marxist insurgents and military dissidents responsible for six coup attempts. Before the temblor, the executive and legislative branches were heading for a collision over her establishment of a new political movement, Kabisig, aimed at bypassing political parties. Congress set aside those differences and quickly approved administration requests for $440,000 in emergency funds. In turn, the Aquino administration accepted congressional demands that debt relief be sought from foreign creditors. Temporary unilateral truces were announced by the communist New People's Army and the dissident Reform the Armed Forces Movement. Relief operations appear to have improved, but serious problems persist two weeks after the quake. Many foreign relief shipments were tied up in customs awaiting clearance and payment of duty. Reporters who visited affected areas said local officials delayed deliveries by repacking relief supplies in order to take credit for them. Under the best of conditions, the Philippines faces a massive recovery that, by some estimates, could take more than a decade. Bridges on major transport arteries collapsed. More than 80,000 buildings were damaged or destroyed. More than 110,000 people were left homeless. Officials of the Public Works Department says the commercial district of Dagupan, a city of more than 100,000, needs to be relocated because it sank by about nine feet. The emergency dramatized all theadministrative weaknesses for which Mrs. Aquino has been criticized since taking office in the 1986 ``people power revolution'' that ousted the late President Ferdinand Marcos. Filipino and foreign analysts question the government's ability to manage recovery and curb public discontent if the deficiencies are not corrected. Government rescuers did not reach some devastated areas of Nueva Vizcaya province until four days after the quake. Local officials found themselves trying to cope with a major disaster without cranes, medicine, transport or trained medics. It was the private sector, not the government, that responded best immediately after the quake. Commercial radio stations alerted rescuers to areas of greatest need. Cadets of the Philippine Military Academy carried out the first rescue operations in Baguio, where nearly 400 people were killed. The cadets were helped by gold miners who heard radio reports of the devastation and walked miles over steep mountains to volunteer. Diplomatic sources said the government was slow in requesting foreign help. A U.S. rescue team was in the air from Andrews Air Force Base before a formal request for assistance was received. Richard Gordon, mayor of Olongapo and a Red Cross official, approached the U.S. Navy at Subic Bay for help. Gordon used a commercial radio station to coordinate aid with the mayor of Cabanatuan, where a school collapsed, killing more than 130 people. Delays in asking for American help led to the suspicion that officials feared an active U.S. role would pressure the government into extending the bases beyond the lease expiration in September 1991. Talks on a new agreement resume next month. Cardinal Jaime L. Sin, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Manila and the nation's most prominent cleric, alluded to that in the comment: ``How can we forget the shortsightedness of ... officials who tried to stop the Americans from doing their humanitarian work because they were afraid the Americans' assistance would be tied up with the bases issue?'' Administration officials played down the U.S. contribution after the quake, and none attended the memorial for an American pilot killed when his aircraft crashed during relief operations. U.S. and Philippine officials say the aid was not tied to the bases issue, but it seems clear the American response will affect the talks. For weeks, American soldiers had been restricted to their bases for fear of attacks by communist rebels. After the quake, U.S. military convoys drove through rebel-controlled territory at night to reach affected areas. American aid also underscored the Philippines' reliance on the bases during natural disasters. The Americans have the cranes, helicopters, search craft and other resources otherwise unavailable to a poor country. ``The extensive and highly visible American aid makes a new treaty for the U.S. bases a surer thing than ever before,'' columnist Antonio Abaya wrote in The Manila Chronicle.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says 24 Parliamentarians Worked for Hated Secret Police
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with second newspaper carrying a similar report, party official denying both. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: More than 20 members of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's party in Parliament once worked for the hated and now-disbanded secret police, two newspapers reported today. A top party official said the reports were inaccurate. The East Berlin newspaper Der Morgen said 24 members of the Christian Democratic Union faction in the parliament had formerly worked for the Ministry of State Security, known in German as Stasi. The ministry, which spied on all aspects of life in East Germany, was disbanded after East Germany's Communist regime fell. Since then, many people have been accused of having worked in some capacity for the Stasi. The newspaper did not name the 24 Christian Democratic Union members in question. It said they received a letter from the faction chairman, Guenther Krause, in which he asked them not to take on any ``important political mandate'' in a future all-German Parliament. A respected Munich-based newspaper, Sueddeutsche Zeitung, carried a similar report today. It didn't name the accused party members either. East Germany's Christian Democrats are the largest party in a coalition government. The Christian Democrats govern in West Germany, led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The parties plan to merge before all-German elections in December and the unified party is expected to do well in the balloting. Der Morgen said the letter followed background checks on all parliamentarians for possible Stasi connections. The Christian Democrats have not commented on the reported reproach, but many high-ranking party leaders confirmed the existence of the Krause letter, the newspaper said. Krause said the claims were not true. He said there was ``no cause'' for such a letter and added that the reports may have been based on a ``misunderstanding,'' prompted by another letter to faction members for unrelated talks.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Investigating Near-Collision Involving Airliner With 127 Passengers
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of an American Airlines jet carrying 127 passengers was forced to take evasive action to avoid a student pilot's plane heading into its flight path, authorities said. The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating the incident, which occurred at about 11:45 a.m. Thursday shortly after the MD-80 took off from the Long Beach Airport for Dallas. There were no injuries. In a report to the FAA, American Airlines pilot T.R. Pollizi said the single-engine Cessna came within 400 feet of his jetliner. Airline officials said Pollizi was forced to level off his plane to avoid a collision. Flight 216 continued on to Dallas, said airline spokesman Tim Smith. A student pilot flying the Cessna was practicing takeoffs and landings when the incident occurred, said FAA spokeswoman Elly Brekke. She declined to identify the pilot. Brekke said a preliminary investigation ruled out error by air traffic controllers. Pollizi reported that moments after takeoff he saw the Cessna about a mile to his left and 200 feet above his altitude. The Cessna passed within 400 feet to the left and 100 feet above his jet as he leveled at 700 feet, Pollizi reported.

DOC.HEAD: Presidents Nominate Justices, Then They're on Their Own
DOC.TEXT: It wasn't long after Theodore Roosevelt named Oliver Wendell Holmes to the Supreme Court that he wished he hadn't. Holmes cast an important vote against Roosevelt's trustbusting efforts. ``I could carve out of a banana a judge with more backbone,'' sputtered Roosevelt. Maybe it is an omen that David H. Souter, the appeals court judge from New Hampshire selected last week by President Bush for the Supreme Court, is said to emulate the values and philosophy of Holmes. At Harvard, his senior thesis was on Holmes' judicial philosophy. Souter still follows a course of reading laid out by his fellow New Englander. Over the years, Supreme Court justices have shown an independent streak unforeseen by their presidential appointers. The truth is that presidents can nominate justices, but can't dominate them. Once on the bench, jurists sometimes cause dismay for their sponsors. Dwight Eisenhower regretted that he'd named two justices who became liberal activists, Earl Warren and William J. Brennan. After leaving office, Ike was asked if he had made any substantial mistakes. Yes, he is supposed to have said, two _ ``and they are both sitting on the Supreme Court.'' How was he to know when he appointed Warren that his chief justice would lead the court into overthrowing segregation in public schools _ an earthquake of a decision and one that Eisenhower never gave any sign of being happy about? Nor could Ike have foreseen Brennan's forceful liberal impact. Brennan had been an obscure member of the New Jersey Supreme Court. Eisenhower picked him because his first choice, the chief justice of that court, was too ill and recommended Brennan instead. ``Nobody knows how a judge is likely to turn out until the judge actually sits on a bench,'' said Bernard Schwartz, a law professor at New York University and author of a new book about the Warren Burger court, ``The Ascent of Pragmatism.'' His best example of a justice who surprised his sponsor is Felix Frankfurter. Frankfurter, he said, was ``so radical he was almost considered a red'' when Franklin D. Roosevelt appointed him. Once in robes, Frankfurter became a leader of the judicial restraint camp. One of the nation's leading civil libertarian lawyers turned into a thorn to libertarian causes. Of the eight justices on today's Supreme Court, four _ Byron White, Harry Blackmun, John Paul Stevens and Sandra Day O'Connor _ turned out different than expected, some more than others. Of the four, Blackmun's the shocker. President Richard Nixon had been humiliated by the Senate, which rejected his first two nominees _ both conservative southerners _ on ethical grounds. So he chose Blackmun, a little-known appeals court justice. Blackmun was a lifelong friend of Nixon's ideologically predictable chief justice, the solidly conservative Warren E. Burger. Both were Minnesotans. For a time they marched in judicial lockstep; wags called them ``the Minnesota twins.'' But the liberal Brennan took Blackmun under his tutelage, and Blackmun evolved into a more-often-than-not liberal. He wrote the Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion, and once said with a sigh he supposed that was what they'd put on his gravestone. White was nominated by President John F. Kennedy, his close friend. ``He pretty much has been a New Frontiersman on civil rights,'' said Schwartz, ``but on other issues he has trended away from the persuasion that got him his appointment.'' Mark Tushnet, a law professor at Georgetown University, dissented. ``If we could ask John Kennedy whether Byron White has worked out as he expected, I would guess the answer would be yes,'' Tushnet said. Stevens was appointed by President Gerald R. Ford to take the seat of the foremost liberal, William O. Douglas, whom Ford, as a congressman, had tried to have impeached. Stevens, a court maverick, has evolved into sharing the court's middle-to-liberal ground with Blackmun. O'Connor is in the middle-to-conservative bloc with White. She turned out to be much more of a centrist than Reagan's three other choices _ William Rehnquist, whom he elevated to chief justice, and Antonin Scalia and Anthony Kennedy. Tushnet thinks justices surprise their nominating presidents ``only occasionally.'' But Lawrence Marshall, who teaches constitutional law at Northwestern University, said that in the past two or three decades ``a good third of appointees have disappointed their appointers with respect to major issues.'' Marshall has a theory: ``Presidents get surprised when they pick nominees on non-ideological grounds. ... ``When their agenda is ideology _ as it was when Reagan picked Scalia and Rehnquist _ I think the surprises are a lot less frequent,'' he said. He cites O'Connor and Warren as examples. Reagan chose O'Connor not for her ideology but because he had promised in his campaign to pick a woman. Eisenhower promised to name Warren to the court at the Republican convention in 1952, where Warren, then governor of California, was competing with him for the presidential nomination. ``There was something else going on other than an attempt by the president to choose ideologically,'' said Marshall. What does that say about Souter's likelihood to surprise? Marshall's hunch is that Bush deliberately did not scrutinize Souter on ideological grounds, opting for an unknown quantity _ and getting a nominee who, on the court, is capable of surprises.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi President's Words _ And Threats _ Influenced OPEC Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Although not sitting at the bargaining table, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein wielded enormous influence over OPEC's decision to limit oil production and set its target price sharply higher. Indeed, some believe it will be Saddam _ and not OPEC _ who will make sure no one cheats on the new accord and forces prices down again. ``He'll be breathing down their neck,'' said Nauman Barakat, first vice president in the energy department at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York. Iraq's oil minister, Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi, denied his country would play the role of enforcer. ``I have no police uniform,'' he told reporters after Friday's agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Later in an interview, he said, ``We're not considering ourselves as a policeman nor as a watchdog.'' But Saddam's strong words _ and even military threats _ against countries pumping too much oil did not go unnoticed. Midway through the meeting, one minister said the conflict in the volatile Persian Gulf region was not hindering work. ``On the contrary, it has created a new atmosphere of willingness to work together,'' said the official, demanding anonymity. ``People know now that deterioration within OPEC causes great harm to some countries,'' he said. ``It's a serious matter.'' Another ministerial source, also demanding anonymity, said, ``From now on, every country must understand that any unilateral action to lower prices could affect the economic interests of the others.'' At the end of two days of bargaining, all 13 ministers signed an accord limiting their output to 22.5 million barrels a day for the rest of the year. Their current output is estimated at about 23 million barrels a day, although it was much higher earlier in the year. The ministers, for the first time since December 1986, raised their target price, pushing it up $3 to $21 a barrel. If, unlike in the past, the cartel curtails output, crude prices could rise several dollars a barrel by year's end, analysts said. Gasoline prices at the pump could go up as much as a dime a gallon. Saddam's blast of rhetoric was aimed squarely at Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, chronic and open violators of their OPEC supply quotas. He blamed them for flooding the market with oil and depressing crude prices, causing a $14 billion loss in revenue for Iraq, which is trying to rebuild from its costly eight-year war with Iran. Chalabi said in the interview that the price decline _ OPEC's marker tumbled from $20.46 in January to $13.64 in June _ amounted to an ``oil shock for the producers.'' ``We had to put an end to it,'' he said. ``We cannot just let anybody do whatever they like ... We had to defend ourselves and defend the interests of OPEC.'' Chalabi acknowledged that ``unfortunately ... we had to be a little bit hard on others.'' In doing so, Iraq appeared to have nailed down pledges from Kuwait and the U.A.E. to scale back output by hundreds of thousands of barrels a day. ``We are all sure and confident that it is now the policy of the governments of Kuwait and the U.A.E. to fully abide by the contents of the agreement,'' said Chalabi. Kuwait, which has been pumping more than its supply quota of 1.5 million barrels a day, had argued lower prices would help the cartel hold on to its share of the world oil market. The U.A.E., which has produced more than double its old quota of 1.1 million barrels a day, just accepted a cap of 1.5 million, said another oil minister, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``All those factors are somehow linked to the political problems in the gulf,'' he said. But the Iraqi president's more bellicose words were frightening _ and unwelcome. ``All the delegations were really worried about the outcome of this meeting,'' said one minister. There was concern, he said, that an outbreak of trouble in the strategic oil-producing gulf region would lead to an oil shock, sending crude prices soaring wildly. ``At the beginning,'' he said, ``it was a very tense meeting.'' But he said there was never any mention of the confrontation in the formal sessions, although there was some discussion in the corridors. Even so, it appears the political actions were instrumental in helping solve some of the cartel's economic problems. ``The events that have taken place within the last few weeks had their impact _ for sure,'' Chalabi said.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Struggle Marks Latest in Long Series of Tribal Conflicts
DOC.TEXT: This West African city was once a lively capital, a buzzing hive of business activity. Lebanese and Indian traders mixed with American and European technicians in its once-bustling streets. Now those streets are deserted by civilians _ and are the battlegrounds of rebels and government troops. Crocodile-infested mangrove swamps have always limited access to Monrovia, which is home to half a million people _ one-fifth of Liberia's population. Now the swamps are an ally of embattled President Samuel Doe as he struggles to hold off the rebels besieging his capital. The insurgents made consistent headway for seven months and closed in on Monrovia several weeks ago. However _ contrary to predictions of Western governments who expected his speedy fall _ Doe has held on, holed up in a beachfront fortress. But the civil war, accompanied by bloody tribal conflict, is a bitter irony in a nation whose very existence was meant to be a celebration of freedom. Liberia was founded in 1847 as black Africa's first independent republic, created by freed American slaves who were brought back to the coast of West Africa by humanitarian societies. But the newcomers were cut off from their African roots by generations of slavery, and had no region or tribe would recognize them. Even Liberia's state motto _ ``The love of liberty brought us here'' _ refers to the freed slaves and their descendants, and ignores the very existence of 90 percent of its population. With the arrival of the ``Americo-Liberians,'' a deal was struck with local chiefs for land where they could settle. The newcomers dominated the new nation, while the African tribes living in the interior were virtually forgotten in their own homeland. Over the years, the social, cultural and economic gap between the local tribes and the American-Liberians widened. The descendants of the freed slaves formed all-powerful masonic groups nd monopolized political power. In 1980, however, a group of non-commissioned officers from the remote inland Krahn tribe staged a coup. They killed President William R. Tolbert and for the first time established a government of Liberians without any American links. Master Sgt. Doe, leader of the tribal rebellion, was initially hailed as a liberator. But he ruled his country like a tribal chief: members of his Krahn tribe, and their allies, the Mandingos, were given special advantages. On several occasions, opponents _ usually traditional tribal enemies _ tried to overthrow Doe. Hundreds were killed. Charles Taylor, descendant of Americo-Liberians and Africans, launched an invasion from neighboring Ivory Coast on Dec. 24, 1989. Taylor, as head of the Liberian government's general service office, had been accused of absconding with $900,000 in government money. Doe's acting information minister, Paul Allen Wie, remained defiant in the face of rebel gains. ``As long as the capital and the head of the nation have not been captured, Taylor has not won the war,'' Wie said. Doe may have been helped by the fact that the rebels are not united. While Taylor's forces were blocked on the eastern outskirts of the capital, a rival rebel leader, Prince Johnson, fought his way into the city. Johnson is the son of a Gio hunter and a former army lieutenant, but little is known about him. But he has quarreled with Taylor, who has reportedly threatened to kill him. So even as the rebels fight to topple Doe, the Taylor-Johnson rivalry sets the stage for another clash between Americo-Liberians and African peoples.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0507 to fix cycle designator
Two Pentagon Contractors Sentenced in Secrets Probe
DOC.TEXT: Two employees of major defense contractors are to serve six months in a halfway house and pay $5,000 fines for conspiring to trade in sensitive Pentagon reports on long-range weapons plans. The sentencings in U.S. District Court on Friday closed out the criminal cases arising from Operation Undercover, an investigation into the network of corporate workers who traded in secret Pentagon reports for more than a decade. U.S. District Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr. sentenced Frank J. Caso, 58, and John R. Kiely, 65, to two years imprisonment, but suspended all but six months. Caso was a marketing analyst with Hughes Aircraft Co. and Kiely was a former marketing manager with Raytheon Co. They were convicted last month following the 15-month government investigation into the use of Defense Department secrets by contractors. Prosecutors say the companies sought the long-range military budget proposals for each of the military branches to gain an edge in seeking contracts for huge Pentagon weapons. Michael J. Costello of the Defense Criminal Investigative Service, which handled the investigation, said circulation of the documents may have cost taxpayers millions of dollars by tainting the procurement process. Six people have been sentenced in the cases and fines of $14.9 million were levied against five corporations, including Hughes, a subsidiary of General Motors and Raytheon. The longest sentence in the investigation was a two-year jail term given Richard Lee Fowler, a former Boeing marketing analyst convicted of 39 criminal counts arising from documents he illegally obtained, copied, distributed and destroyed.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Forces Halt to Search for Quake Survivors at Hotel
With AM-Quake-Aquino, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fire and heavy rains on Saturday forced rescuers to suspend their search for survivors in a collapsed hotel where two people were earlier saved more than a week after an earthquake left 1,600 dead. Rescuers said they found the pair Friday after following a housefly buzzing in the ruins of the Hyatt Hotel. Rescuers and spectators cheered as Luisa Mallorca, a 20-year-old cleaning woman, and Arnel Calabia, a 26-year-old security guard, were pulled from the debris. Calabia's father, Dominador, said he had lost hope of ever seeing his son alive again. ``We did not expect that he could be recovered alive 11 days after the earthquake,'' Dominador Calabia told reporters in Manila. ``I felt unimaginable happiness as a father to hear that my son was alive.'' Doctors said Calabia and Miss Mallorca suffered from dehydration and other injuries but were in suprisingly good condition after their ordeal. They were to be flown to Manila, 130 miles to the south, as soon as the weather cleared in Baguio after torrential monsoon rains. Miners worked through the rains Saturday to try to find more survivors, but were forced to halt their efforts after a fire, touched off by acetylene torches used in the search, spread through the ruins. More than 20 people are still believed buried beneath the debris. The U.S. Embassy said 12 Americans, all of Filipino origin, were believed among the missing there. Foreign rescue teams gave up searching last week, convinced no survivors would be found. The Hyatt was one of eight hotels which collapsed in the July 16 quake. Local miners and other volunteers vowed to keep looking until all the missing were accounted for. Calabia said he, Miss Mallorca and a male employee were on the third floor near the elevator when the quake struck. All three dived under tables ``and then the ceiling fell in,'' he said in a radio interview. ``We recovered consciousness later and we called out to each other,'' Calabia said. The three lay in the dark, talked to each other and prayed, Calabia and Miss Mallorca said. The other man, William Tan, was badly hurt and died about surviving almost a week under the rubble. Doctors at Baguio General Hospital said Calabia and Miss Mallorca both suffered cuts, bruises and severe dehydration. Calabia told reporters his right hand was injured and nurses told him three fingers might have to be amputated. Baguio, a mountain resort about a mile above sea level, was one of the cities hardest hit. Nearly 400 people died in the town. According to the latest figures, the earthquake left at least 1,653 people dead, 1,000 missing and presumed dead, 3,000 seriously injured and 110,000 homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Black Moslems Take Prime Minister and Cabinet Hostage; Claims Coup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with state of emergency, buildings on fire, some ministers reported freed, comment from Bush spox. Abu Bakr is pronounced AH-boo BAH-kuhr. Pickup 10th, `Bakr, a...'
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ A group of black Moslems who kidnapped the prime minister and some Cabinet members in a coup attempt said today the captives may be harmed if the government moves against a rebel-held TV station. One report said three people were killed in the first hours of the rebel strike, which began Friday on the former British colony of two islands that lie off the Venezuelan coast. ``The government has been overthrown,'' the coup leader, Abu Bakr, said on government TV Friday evening after the station was seized by his followers. But government radio said today that a state of emergency had been declared and that police were moving into the streets of the capital of this southern Caribbean nation to restore order. Gunfire was heard in the direction of the television station, located in northeastern Port-of-Spain about two miles from the Parliament building and the main police station. Buildings also were burning in eastern Port-of-Spain. Education Minister Clive Pantin said on government radio that he had not been captured by the rebels and that the mutineers had already released two unidentified ministers and four civilians they had been holding. The Barbados-based Caribbean News Agency, or CANA, said three people had been killed as the coup attempt began with an explosion at the police station and rebels bursting into Parliament firing weapons. It said a news reporter had seen the body of a woman Parliament worker in the Parliament building, and it quoted witnesses as saying they saw two bodies in front of the building. In Washington, a State Department official said it appeared ``the active elements of the insurrection are limited to the television station and the parliament building.'' ``We understand there has been some looting'' in the streets, ``but nothing affecting the safety of our embassy or foreign nationals,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Trinidad's island of Tobago is a popular vacation site for Americans and others. In Kennebunkport, Maine, President Bush and National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft were ``following the situation carefully,'' said deputy press secretary Alixe Glen. She said the U.S. government had not yet received a request for international aid, but would consider it once it arrives. Bakr, a former policeman who heads a group called Jamaat al-Muslimeen, Arabic for the Moslem Group, has said he doesn't recognize ``man's law,'' only ``the law of almighty Allah.'' The Moslem group is known to have connections to Libya that are said to include some funding. News reports say Abu Bakr has visited Libya. Bakr's group has an estimated 250 followers. The mostly Hindu and Roman Catholic country of 1.3 million people has a 1,500-member army and a 5,000-member police force. The State Department said earlier that the United States would ``deplore any attempt to overthrow the democratic government of Trinidad.'' Prime Minister Arthur Robinson's National Alliance for Reconstruction won parliamentary elections in December 1986. The next elections are due in 1991. British West Indies Airways and American Airlines canceled commercial flights into Trinidad on Friday evening. Piarco International Airport remained under control of government security forces but was closed early today. When Bakr broadcast his claim of a takeover, he did not disclose the whereabouts of Robinson and the other captured officials. It was not known how many Cabinet ministers were taken hostage with Robinson, 63, a veteran political leader, lawyer and economist. But the news director at the captured government television station went on the air this morning and said the prime minister and the other officials were alive and being ``well treated.'' The news director, Jones Madeira, said some of the officials were being held at the TV station and others at the Parliament building, Red House. But he warned that the television station's signals were being tampered with and ``this could endanger the lives of those people being held.'' Roman Catholic Archbishop Anthony Pantin told government radio he had spoken to Madeira by telephone. ``He asked me to emphasize the request not to interfere with the television channels, because if they do something may happen,'' the prelate said. Several government ministers were seen on the rebel-controlled television. Government radio, the National Broadcasting Service's Radio 610, said the capital's police station was blown up and burned out of control for hours. It said no one attempted to put out the fire, and there were several explosions of what was assumed to be ammunition in the station. Bakr first appeared on television at 6 p.m. Friday to announce the uprising. He said his followers planned no violence, looting or retribution against civilians, and promised ``free and fair'' elections within 90 days. Government radio said before dawn today that there had been some looting and police had moved into the streets. Bakr, in his mid-40s, has been arrested several times in the past on charges of contempt of court and illegal demonstrations. He lives with 200 to 250 followers, their wives and children in a commune on the western side of Port-of-Spain. Members of the sect, founded in 1980, are widely perceived in Trinidad as violent outlaws, though the group's rhetoric is highly moralistic. In 1988, police raided the commune, seizing weapons and ammunition and arresting 34 members of the sect on charges of larceny, robbery, illegal possession of weapons, rape and murder. Bakr said then his vigilantes were waging a war against ``the menace of cocaine.'' ``We will stop the incest, robbery, and drugs which there was no hope for the present regime to stop,'' he said in Friday's broadcast. The rebel group in the past year has been occupying some government land in western Port-of-Spain. Recently, the government had denied customs approval of a shipment of medical supplies donated to Bakr by Libya.

DOC.HEAD: Charges of Communist Plot Throw Shadows on Black-White Talks
DOC.TEXT: Government charges of a Communist plot to seize power have cast a shadow over talks on ending white-minority rule and put pressure on the African National Congress' alliance with the Communists. The police claim to have uncovered evidence of a conspiracy by the South African Communist Party and elements of the ANC's military wing to seize power if talks on ending white rule fail. Newspapers, citing security sources, reported Saturday that the Communist Party has been working on plans to smuggle large quantities of arms into the country and establish guerrilla units. Police say they have found a number of arms dumps and have arrested some 40 militants, though no one has been charged. The allegations have created confusion, with the government trading accusations and denials with the ANC and the closely allied Communist Party. Police have not publicly presented evidence of their conspiracy claims, and some anti-apartheid activists believe the security forces are attempting to undermine black-white negotiations. Leaders on both sides are concerned the dispute could threaten efforts by the government and the ANC to clear the way for full-scale talks on sharing political power with the black majority. President F.W. de Klerk and ANC leader Nelson Mandela are scheduled to meet Aug. 6 to try to clear remaining obstacles to the talks, including ANC demands for the release of jailed militants. The government wants an end to the ANC's ineffective armed struggle and a cease-fire. De Klerk and other senior government leaders reportedly see the Communists as a major threat and want Communist leader Joe Slovo dropped from the ANC delegation to the talks. Police say the top ANC leadership is being duped by the Communists. Slovo is one of several Communist leaders who also hold top posts in the ANC. Local news reports say police findings include records of remarks by Slovo asserting that the Communists are not bound by a commitment signed by the ANC and the government in May to halt political violence. Slovo and other Communists were part of the ANC negotiating team in those talks. Mandela indignantly denies there is any plot to seize power. De Klerk presented him with details of police findings in a private meeting Thursday, but Mandela said he was not convinced. ``There is no plot as far as we're concerned,'' Mandela said. The dispute between the government and the ANC has refocused attention on the Communist Party and its plans and intentions. Slovo, the party's secretary-general, says the Communists are committed to democracy. He says the party will become the voice of the working class in a post-apartheid South Africa. The former lawyer insists the party has turned its back on its hard-line Marxist past and will seek power peacefully. The party derides claims that it seeks to impose authoritarian rule. Despite criticisms, the ANC has stood by its long alliance with the Communists. Mandela says he will work with anyone to end apartheid, and the Communists have long played a prominent role in that struggle. The Communist Party keeps details of its leadership and membership secret, making it difficult to assess its strength. It is thought to number just a few hundred militants, but many occupy leadership posts in the ANC, trade unions and other political groups.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Bertha Forms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to CORRECT that sustained winds were near 50 mph, sted gusts; and to UPDATE with noon coordinates. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Storm watches...'.
DOC.TEXT: The second tropical storm of the Atlantic hurricane season formed today off the Florida coast with sustained winds near 50 mph, meteorologists said. Tropical Storm Bertha was nearly stationary early today, but the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables predicted it would drift northward. Conditions also were favorable that it will pick up in strength by Sunday, the center reported. At noon EDT today, Bertha was located about 280 miles east of Cape Canaveral, near latitude 28.7 north and longitude 75.6 west. Maximum sustained winds were near 50 mph. On Friday, forecasters stopped issuing advisories concerning the remains of Tropical Storm Arthur as the system was reduced to a tropical wave. Arthur's sustained winds dropped from 70 mph to 35 mph Thursday, briefly building to 40 mph again, and then dropped below 39 mph for good. That's the minimum wind speed for a tropical disturbance to be defined as a tropical storm. Storm watches for the southern coasts of Puerto Rico and the island of Hispaniola, shared by Haiti and the Dominican Republic, were lifted by Thursday afternoon. There were reports of heavy rain, but no serious damage and injuries on the islands. Arthur, the hurricane season's first named storm, began forming Sunday in the open Atlantic. The season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Morgan Enthusiasts Motor to West Virginia Town
DOC.TEXT: Where else would dozens of drivers rendezvous in a cross-country rally for Britain's classic Morgan sports cars? More than 50 Morgans from the United States, Canada and Europe are expected in this northern West Virginia town Monday when drivers who left San Francisco July 11 join other Morgan enthusiasts for a two-week tour of the Northeast. ``This whole thing came about from a fantasy I've had since I was 6 years old,'' said 45-year-old Jeremy Harrison, a podiatrist from Liverpool, England, who organized the event. ``I've wanted to drive through a hole cut in a redwood tree since I saw a photograph of a car doing it. Now I've done it.'' He calls the rally ``Morgans Over America.'' Harrison's Morgan convoy rolled into Chicago on Friday. The itinerary calls for the cars, including two three-wheeled models built in 1933, to pass through Detroit and Ohio before arriving at Morgantown, about 75 miles south of Pittsburgh, Monday afternoon. Meanwhile, rally drivers from the East are gathering, with many planning to meet in Luray, Va., travel to North Carolina to link up with Atlanta area Morgan owners, and then head to Morgantown, according to Mark Braunstein, who arranged the rally's eastern leg. ``Morgantown just happened to be the right spot on the map for us to meet,'' said Braunstein. ``It's on the route and its name clinched it.'' Twenty-one Morgans, including cars from Germany, Sweden, Denmark and Scotland, were shipped to the United States for the rally, Harrison said. ``I had a terrible time with insurance,'' said Harrison, whose 1990 lilac Morgan Plus Eight is worth about $50,000. ``We had more than 200 refusals until an agent in Pennsylvania agreed to insure us for five weeks on the road and shipping for $13,000.'' Founded in 1909 in Malvern Link, England, the Morgan Motor Co. is the world's oldest privately owned automobile manufacturer. The company began fashioning handcrafted, wood-framed, open sports cars in 1936 after building its reputation on sports cycles and three-wheelers. The Morgan's long-louvered hood, leather interior, wooden dash and wind-grabbing shape have seen only minor alterations during the last 50 years. Mechanical changes, except for engine swaps, have also been slow in coming. ``There's still a button to push to lubricate the front suspension,'' Harrison said. ``That's been around since 1911.'' List prices for Morgans range between $23,000 and $38,000, depending on the model. An extensive list of options _ including a Rover V-8 engine _ can push the price much higher, Harrison said. Added to that cost is the wait: Only nine cars a week are built by the Morgan factory's 120 employees, so the waiting list for the cars is eight years, company officials said earlier this year. ``Customers are encouraged to observe their car being built,'' Harrison said. ``I asked to have mine painted on a Saturday so I could watch it being done.'' Mechanical problems, speeding tickets and rain have plagued the drivers on the trip's western leg, Harrison said during a rest stop in La Crosse, Wis. ``We've already had three speeding tickets and three breakdowns,'' Harrison said during a telephone interview. ``Two people have paid $90 speeding tickets and another driver was fined $120 in California. ``Morgans are light and have powerful engines,'' he said. ``They really go.'' Probably the worst mechanical failure so far, according to Harrison, occurred when the rear axle of a London man's Morgan froze up. ``He hadn't greased it in 10 years, he didn't know he was supposed to,'' said Harrison. ``That was stupid.'' Still, Harrison said: ``Everybody's thrilled.'' He brought his 21-year-old daughter along for the ride. And his group includes a mother-daughter team from England and ``a lady who just wanted to see Yellowstone and another person who wanted to see your Mount Rushmore.'' ``It's the trip of a lifetime,'' he said. ``There's already been some discussion of doing it again in five years.''

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Party Relinquishes Monopoly on Power
DOC.TEXT: Cape Verde's ruling Marxist party has relinquished its 15-year monopoly on power and renounced its role as the leading force in society, Portuguese news reports said Saturday. It was the latest in a series of democratic reforms in Africa's traditional one-party states. The decisions came at a four-day congress this week in the Atlantic island nation's capital of Praia, the Portuguese news agency Lusa reported. The African Party for the Independence of Cape Verde also elected Prime Minister Pedro Pires as its party chief, Lusa reported. The about 200 delegates party embraced multiparty democracy and renounced its constitutionally enshrined role as the ``leading force of the state and society,'' Lusa said. The delegates voted to eliminate their party's Marxist-influenced system of organization and uphold ``plurality of opinions,'' Lusa said. The party has ruled Cape Verde since the 10-island archipelago, 385 miles off the coast of Senegal, gained independence from Portugal in 1975. Pires, 56, who was the party's assistant secretary-general, will replace Cape Verde's president, Aristides Pereira, in the top party post. Pereira said he was leaving the party, which he founded 35 years ago as an underground force to fight Portuguese rule, to gain autonomy to prepare the country's transition toward democracy. The 66-year-old leader is expected to campaign for another term as head of state in elections scheduled for November, the first poll to be based on direct, universal suffrage. New electoral regulations assert presidential candidates cannot be party-based. Constitutional reform scheduled for September is due to legalize other parties. A new constitution to enshrine pluralist principles is expected next year. The ruling party has announced plans for a multiparty legislative ballot to follow November's presidential elections. A number of opposition groups have emerged recently, and according to media reports from Praia, walls around the capital were painted with opposition slogans in the past few days. The Movement for Democracy, headed by Carlos Veiga, an independent deputy in Cape Verde's national assembly, aims to unite opposition forces to face the ruling party.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia Invites Kuwait and Iraq to Meeting
With AM-OPEC, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia on Saturday invited Iraqi and Kuwaiti leaders to its summer capital to settle a border and oil dispute that has led to the mobilization of armed forces by both Baghdad and Kuwait. Diplomatic sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said oil, financial and legal experts from Kuwait and Iraq are expected to meet separately in the Saudi summer capital of Jiddah to work out an agreement. It was unclear when the meeting would be held. The diplomatic sources said Saudi Foreign Minister Prince Saud al-Faisal Saturday delivered invitations from King Fahd to Kuwaiti Crown Prince and Prime Minister Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah and Iraq's No. 2 official Ezzat Ibrahim for a meeting in Jiddah. Last week tensions flared between Iraq and Kuwait as Baghdad moved 30,000 troops to its border with Kuwait and demanded changes in that country's oil production. Iraq also demanded compensation from Kuwait for $2.4 billion worth of oil it said Kuwait pumped from the disputed Rumailah oil field which straddles the joint border. Diplomatic sources said Saturday the troops remained on the border. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein triggered the tensions earlier this month when he accused Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of costing his country $14 billion by exceeding their oil production quotas and driving oil prices down. During the crisis Kuwait's army of about 20,000 men briefly went on alert. Iraq has about 1 million men under arms. Faisal's mission was preceded by an official Saudi statement welcoming a ``bilateral meeting between representatives of Iraq and Kuwait in Jiddah over the coming few days, God willing, to thrash out all differences through fraternal and cordial dialogue.'' It said the Saudi government was ``deeply satisfied with the response of both Iraq and Kuwait to the goodwill efforts.'' Iraq has termed the upcoming meeting in Saudi Arabia a protocol step and has demanded that it is followed by working talks in Baghdad. Some of the Iraqi pressure on Kuwait has seemed to have already eased after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to try to reach a target price of $21 per barrel for oil. The increase was a long-standing Iraqi demand.

DOC.HEAD: Baltics Bow Out of Treaty Gorbachev Calls Vital
DOC.TEXT: The Baltic republics said Saturday they won't take part in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plans to negotiate a new treaty that would give the 15 Soviet republics more autonomy from the Kremlin. Instead, the presidents of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia said they will proceed with joint talks with the Soviet government for their independence. Their decision, reached at a summit Friday night, dealt a sharp blow to Gorbachev's plans to hold the splintering Soviet Union together as a looser confederation of sovereign states. There was no immediate reaction from the Kremlin. At a Kremlin meeting July 20, Gorbachev called the union treaty vital to Soviet government plans to transfer the nation to a market economy, saying it would ensure a single market-oriented system in which all components will complement each other. Gorbachev has long promised such a revamped treaty providing a measure of autonomy for the Soviet republics, but some are taking their own action to sever ties with the central government. The Baltic republics have made the boldest moves toward secession, and on Friday Byelorussia joined the Russian republic, the Ukraine, Moldavia and Uzbekistan in declaring sovereignty. Georgia has called for negotiations on independence. The Baltic statement _ signed by Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis, Estonia's Arnold Ruutel and Latvia's Anatoly Gorbunov _ said the three leaders ``consider it impossible'' to participate in the union treaty. ``It would be best if negotiations with the U.S.S.R. were held on the basis of the three-plus-one principle,'' they said, referring to their republics plus the Soviet government. The statement was released Saturday. The Baltic republics also said they had no territorial or other claims on each other, and asked the other 12 republics of the Soviet Union to come forward within a month with any territorial or other claims they might have on them. The republic of Byelorussia earlier this year made some territorial claims on parts of Lithuania. The Baltic leaders said Friday they had agreed to negotiate political, economic, legal and cultural treaties with the huge Russian Federation. Talks must start immediately, they said after meeting with Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin during his vacation in the Latvian beach resort of Jurmala. The press center of the Latvian parliament quoted Yeltsin as saying the political treaty between Latvia and Russia would recognize Latvia's independence. Yeltsin was quoted as telling Latvian television he sees the treaties as agreements between equal and sovereign states. The press center said a Latvian delegation would come to Moscow, the capital of both Russia and the Soviet Union, on Monday to begin talks. The Baltic republics were part of the Russian Empire, but gained their independence amid the turmoil of World War I and the Bolshevik Revolution. They were absorbed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Lithuania declared outright on March 11 that it was re-establishing that independence, and Latvia and Estonia followed with declarations that they would resume independence after unspecified transition periods. Gorbachev slapped a tough economic embargo on Lithuania on April 18, and on June 29, Lithuania said it would freeze its declaration in return for an end to the blockade and the start of negotiations with the Kremlin on secession. Those talks have yet to begin, although delegations are being formed.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Rips Through Bus Killing One, Injuring Nine
DOC.TEXT: A bomb ripped through a passenger bus Saturday in this eastern city, killing a child and injuring nine people, police said. Three of the injured were in critical condition, hospital officials said. The bomb was planted at the rear of the bus, parked outside the railway station, said police officials, speaking on condition of anonymity. No one claimed responsiblity, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Link Governing Party Members to Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-four members of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's party in Parliament once worked for the now-disbanded secret police, newspapers said Saturday. A key party official denied the reports. The East Berlin newspaper Der Morgen, in reporting on the alleged connection, said it based its information on a letter sent to 24 members of the Christian Democratic Union faction in the Parliament. Der Morgen said the 24 received a letter from Guenter Krause, the party's parliamentary faction chairman, in which he asked them not to take on any ``important political mandate'' in a future all-German Parliament. The newspaper said the letter followed background checks on all parliamentarians for possible Stasi connections. Der Morgen said several high-ranking party leaders confirmed the letter's existence. A respected Munich-based newspaper, Sueddeutsche Zeitung, carried a similar report Saturday. Neither newspaper named the 24 parliamentarians in question. The Christian Democrats won 164 seats in the 400-seat Parliament in East Germany's first free election on March 18, following a pro-democracy revolution. Krause said the claims were not true. He said there was ``no cause'' for such a letter and added that the report may have been based on a ``misunderstanding'' prompted by another letter to faction members for unrelated talks. The former Ministry of State Security, known in German as Stasi, had a pervasive hold on all aspects of East German life through its spying. It was disbanded after East Germany's Communist regime fell, but its coverage was so wide that many people are tainted by association with it. East Germany's Christian Democrats are the largest party but govern in a coalition. The Christian Democrats govern in West Germany, led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The parties plan to merge before all-German elections in December, and the unified party is expected to do well in the balloting. Leaders in both Germanys are trying to hammer out an agreement on how and when the countries will end 45 years of postwar division and unify. That requires agreement on the technicalities of electing a united Parliament. Last week, de Maiziere's governing coalition almost collapsed in a dispute over whether to merge before the elections and have balloting throughout the unified country or to hold elections in the separate states first, then merge. On Friday, the Social Democrats, the second-biggest faction, agreed to remain in the coalition after de Maiziere apparently backed down from insisting that East Germany remain a separate nation until after the Dec. 2 elections. The outcome of the dispute will determine the leadership of a united Germany by deciding how many votes each party needs for parliamentary representation. To win seats, parties will need to win more votes in an election for a unified nation than in separate East and West German balloting. West German law requires a minimum 5 percent showing for parliamentary representation, and the two sides are now trying to agree on whether the same minimum should apply in elections planned Dec. 2 that will unify the Germanys. One proposal would involve vote-counting separately in each of the 16 states of a unified Germany.
