Another suggestion put forward Saturday would allow smaller parties to appear on the same ballot as larger ones, thereby increasing their chances for representation. That practice is allowed in East German elections, but not for national elections in West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana: Laid-Back and Free-Wheeling or Marching with the Moral Majority?
DOC.TEXT: The Louisiana known for boozy Bourbon Street and the excesses of Mardi Gras has been obscured by a Legislature burning with bills to ban abortions, label ``bad'' records and allow a little head-knocking defense of the flag. The Legislature's morality quest may have surprised outsiders who picture Louisiana as free-wheeling and laid back. But naughty New Orleans notwithstanding, the religious right has a strong influence on Louisiana politics. The apple-pie issues also served as distractions from the state's fiscal woes. Lawmakers passed a strict anti-abortion bill that allowed no exceptions for rape or incest victims, even though Gov. Buddy Roemer warned them he'd veto it. They almost passed a measure that would have eliminated jail terms for people convicted of roughing up flag burners. Later, they gutted that bill and hurriedly substituted anti-abortion language to skip procedural delays and try to get around Roemer's veto. The new bill had rape and incest provisions, but Roemer said they weren't broad enough. He vetoed that bill Friday, 2{ weeks after the regular session ended. Roemer also vetoed a bill that would have required warning labels on potentially offensive recordings and could have sent retailers to jail for selling such records to children. The music industry had threatened to boycott New Orleans if that one became law and Roemer said he was convinced the bill unconstitutionally abridged free-speech rights. Lawmakers are talking about calling themselves into session in mid-August just to override Roemer's vetos. The state Legislature's stress on traditional morality really isn't new: _Louisiana has outlawed abortion since the 1800s, without exceptions for rape or incest. Only the Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision changed that. _In 1981, lawmakers passed a law requiring schoolteachers who teach Darwin's theory of evolution to also teach ``scientific creationism,'' an alternative theory that mankind was created and didn't evolve from lower animals. Federal courts found scientific creationism more religious than scientific and said public schools shouldn't be forced to give it equal time. _Astute politicians running for statewide office seldom miss the Pentecostals' Fourth of July-week camp meeting of some 8,000 people at the central Louisiana town of Tioga. A frequent participant is former Gov. Edwin Edwards, who also unashamedly frequents Nevada casinos and has a reputation for womanizing. _Evangelist Jimmy Swaggart's sprawling complex in Baton Rouge, complete with Bible college, audio and video recording studios and Family Worship Center, was a multimillion-dollar boon to the state capital's economy _ at least until a sex scandal diminished the preacher's popularity. ``Our people really support moral values,'' said Elton Pody, mayor of the north Louisiana town of Ruston, who lobbied legislators not only on municipal issues but also for the anti-abortion bill. Wayne Parent, a political science professor at Louisiana State University, suggested another possible reason for the Legislature's affection for issues of morality _ the state's sorry financial condition. Until a few years ago, Parent said, balancing the state's multibillion-dollar budget was easy. Oil prices were high and oil taxes paid for everything. Things changed when oil prices plummeted in the mid-1980s. Lawmakers have had to cut services, put supposedly temporary sales taxes on traditionally exempt items such as groceries and medicine, and fight over Roemer's tax overhaul proposals, most of which have died. Issues of abortion, the flag and smutty or drug-related records were easy to deal with when the alternatives were a tight budget and unpopular taxes, Parent said. ``These were almost welcome distractions,'' said Parent. Former state Rep. Kevin Reilly, who once called Louisiana a ``banana republic,'' agreed with that assessment. ``It's a diversionary tactic, no question about it,'' said Reilly, who left the House in 1987 to devote more time to business. ``And every legislative body does that,'' he added. ``The United States Congress does that. Just recently they were talking about a flag burning amendment in the Congress when we have this huge budget deficit.'' Not even the director of one of Louisiana's most conservative lobbying groups believes many people took the state flag bill seriously. ``I think the flag burning bill was sort of thought of as a sort of horseplay _ send a message, get a little chuckle, but don't get too serious about it,'' said Ken Ward of the Louisiana Moral and Civic Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Witness Delivers Testimony, Almost Delivers Baby, In Court
DOC.TEXT: The victim of an attempted purse-snatching insisted on delivering her testimony in court even though it almost meant delivering her baby on the witness stand. Chavez Lynch, a week overdue with her first child, was in the first stages of labor when she was taken into the courtroom in a wheelchair for a pretrial hearing Friday. ``It was extremely obvious,'' said Municipal Court Judge Jack Gifford. ``Just after she started testifying she had a contraction, and it certainly concerned me.'' Gifford asked Lynch if she wanted to continue. ``She said, `Yes, I'm here. I want to finish this.''' As soon as she finished testifying at the pretrial hearing, Lynch was wheeled out of the courtroom and rushed to a hospital, where she gave birth some hours later. The hospital, at Lynch's request, would not release any information about mother or newborn.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Rivals Form New Party
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa's rivals in the Solidarity movement founded their own party on Saturday and called for Poland's next president to be elected by the people, not the Parliament. The founding completes the split of the political movement that struggled against the Communists in the 1980s, triumphed in elections last year and dominates Poland's non-Communist government. The founding convention of the Citizens Movement for Democratic Action drew more than 1,000 supporters. Many of those in the new party were heroes of Solidarity's fight against Communist rule. Organizers said they wanted the party to be an alternative to the Center Alliance, a 2-month-old pro-Walesa political party. They said they would offer support to Solidarity Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, whom Walesa has often criticized. Zbigniew Bujak, a leader of Solidarity during its underground years, acknowleged the polarization of the movement, but he said such a division ``does not have to be bad.'' ``A democratic country is a country of different proposals. We will have to forget about the otherwise comfortable structure in which the picture was black and white _ just us against them,'' said Bujak. The new party's Polish acronym is ROAD, and it played on the acronym's English meaning, calling itself the best road to democracy. Behind the podium as Bujak spoke was huge white sheet with a broken black line down the middle to represent a highway. In its first political step, the party convention voted nearly unanimously to endorse a constitutional amendment calling for the president to be elected by the people and not _ as now _ by the two chambers of Parliament. Adam Michnik, who was once a key adviser to Walesa, criticized the Center Alliance's call for an early presidential vote by Parliament. ``We want the whole society to decide,'' he told a news conference. The pro-Walesa group calls for electing Walesa president by the current Parliament this fall, urges immediate privatization of the economy and faster ouster of holdover Communists from positions of authority. The new party wants early presidential elections but not by Parliament, arguing the current chamber is tainted by the 1989 political deal that set aside a portion of seats for Communists. Walesa strategists believe they can put together enough votes in Parliament to elect the Solidarity chairman president, where he would oversee the drafting of an entirely new post-Communist constitution. The new party sees Walesa as politically vulnerable in a direct election. The new party's membership includes most of Walesa's longtime advisers and allies in Solidarity, including filmmaker Andrzej Wajda; parliamentary secretary Henryk Wujec and government ministers Aleksander Hall, Jacek Kuron and Witold Trzeciakowski. President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former Communist Party leader, elected to a six-year term a year ago, already has signaled he will step down early. He sent a letter to Parliament on Saturday saying he agreed with a planned September discussion on holding early presidential and parliamentary elections. Jaruzelski's election was meant to prevent the Soviets from stepping in to quash reforms. But now that Soviet influence has waned across Eastern Europe, his presence is seen as anachronistic.

DOC.HEAD: Waitress Killed, Cook Wounded in $20 Robbery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4-5th grafs to put first, second references to Johnson in proper order.
DOC.TEXT: Four youths masked with nylon stockings over their heads shot and killed a waitress at a small restaurant and wounded a cook before fleeing with $20, police said Saturday. At least one of them was carrying a rifle, said police Detective Dennis Robbins. ``They fired several times, demanded money and fired again,'' Robbins said. ``It appears shots were deliberately fired at'' the waitress and cook. Sgt. Jeff Johnson said the youths took $20 from a cash drawer and ran away late Friday. No customers were inside at the time. There were no arrests by early Saturday, said Johnson. The male youths were believed to be 16 to 18 years old, he said.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Soviet New South I, Bjt, Two Takes,1021
DOC.HEAD: Part I: New Mood
Islam, Economics, Ecology: Recipe for Unrest in Soviet South
LaserPhoto NY301 of July 23. Graphics SOVNEWSOL, SOVNEWSO1, SOVNEWSOG
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: In the heart of Asia, far from the tumult of the Kremlin, a new mood of defiance and independence is taking hold. This is the first installment of a four-part series by an AP special correspondent who traveled through the restive Soviet south.

Townsfolk in this ancient capital of tiled turquoise domes and haunting memories are starting to refer to the Soviet state in the same past tense they apply to Tamerlane and Genghis Khan. ``The Soviet Union is rotting away,'' said Alex Ulko, a young painter and English student at the University of Samarkand. ``Within a few years, Asians will be shaping their own nations.'' Moscow is omnipresent in Soviet Central Asia, from government offices and Communist Party headquarters to donkey-riding KGB informants in remote hamlets. But new political currents, rooted in an Islamic religious revival, economic resentment and environmental concerns, are carrying Asian peoples inexorably further from the Kremlin. Although Lenin's iron-cast goatee still juts resolutely forward in city parks, Asians revere their own wise men, in flowing white beards and colored robes, who evoke a past few have forgotten, a past almost palpable at night when Islamic chants can be heard down twisting lanes shaded by mulberries. The five Central Asian republics _ Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tadzhikistan and Kirghizia _ stretch from the Caspian Sea to China, an area almost as big as the United States. Their 50 million inhabitants, 20 million in Uzbekistan, make up a fifth of the Soviet population. A few examine 21st century problems in nuclear physics and biochemistry, but many more live in rag tents or mud hovels, as in the days of the Golden Horde. In some ways Central Asia is marked indelibly by a century of Russian czars and commissars. But many here see the Russian interlude as destined to be yet another turn of history, no more vital to the present than when camels plied the Silk Road from China to Europe. New political parties, ecological movements, Moslem clergymen in reopened mosques and young radicals all press for broader freedoms leading to independence. Even local Communist Party cadres are insisting on greater home rule. ``Perestroika has brought truth, but truth has brought unrest,'' noted Agzam Rahmidov, an English professor in this old crossroads city in Uzbekistan. For one thing, Central Asians complain of economic exploitation. The Uzbekistan prime minister, Shukrulla Mirsaidov, contends his people pay out three times as much to the central government as they get back. In June, Uzbekistan and Tadzhikistan refused to export food to other republics at the low prices decreed by the state. Later, the Uzbek Parliament adopted a preliminary ``declaration of sovereignty.'' Anti-Moscow sentiment reaches deep into daily life. Russian settlers are leaving the region at a quickening pace, spurred by sporadic pogroms against ethnic minorities. Youths are evading the military draft and rebelling against officers they accuse of bias. In a nation fraught with more immediate crises, these pressures stew largely out of sight. In June, a border clash between Uzbeks and Kirghizis in the old holy city of Osh commanded attention as the official death toll mounted to as high as 800. But when Soviet troops imposed calm, the spotlight moved on. ``The situation in Central Asia is very serious, and we don't understand it fully,'' said Igor Krupnik, a conflict specialist at the Academy of Sciences in Moscow. ``No one has the data.'' The problem, Central Asians say, is that distant analysts are often thrown off by convenient generalities about peoples who are anything but homogeneous. Over millennia, borders were traced across the sands by conquerors, from the Mongol hordes, to Turkish tyrants like Tamerlane, to the Russian czars. Josef Stalin drew the last map in the 1920s, when the regions of Turkestan and Eastern Bukhara were transformed into five republics. The plains of Kazakhstan, biggest and northernmost of the five, separate European Russia from Asia. To the south lie the other four: in the east, the small mountainous enclaves of Tadzhikistan and Kirghizia, bordering China and Afghanistan; in the west, the highlands and deserts of Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan, stretching toward the oilfields of the Caspian Sea. These Central Asian neighbors are linked by the Koran and often by common linguistic roots. But just as often they are divided by disputes over land and water. In the Soviet grand plan, the whole region was given over to cotton. Fields were irrigated from the majestic rivers Amu Darya and Syr Darya, and Russian migrants settled frontier lands. Today only 40 percent of the Kazakhstan population is Kazakh. But decades of poor planning have so bled the rivers that they no longer replenish the Aral Sea. Half of the world's fourth largest lake has dried up, its exposed lakebed now just loose salt poisoned by pesticide runoff. To revive the Aral Sea, Uzbeks want to cut off the Karakum Canal, used by the Turkmens to water their desert. ``Land was exploited in the most disgusting colonial way,'' said Sergei Kapitsa of the Physical Problems Institute in the Soviet Academy of Sciences. Central Asian planners want to diversify from cotton. But the region is short of energy. And the Tadzhiks, ensconced in high mountains, balk at flooding villages for more hydroelectic dams. In this climate of tension, an isolated skirmish over a piece of scarce farmland, like the one in Osh, can flash overnight into pitched battles in capital cities hundreds of miles apart. Explosive mixtures have resulted from past Soviet policies of dispersing inconvenient minorities to once-remote areas, such as the Fergana Valley, which includes Osh. Last year, rampaging Uzbeks killed at least 100 people in pogroms against Turks resettled from Georgia almost two generations ago. Other minorities, including Russians, were also targeted.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: SAMARKAND, U.S.S.R.: also targeted.
DOC.TEXT: This February, an estimated 50 people were killed in riots in the Tadzhik capital, Dushanbe, reportedly touched off by rumors that Armenian refugees would settle there. In May, mobs burned 47 homes of Armenians and Jews in the Fergana Valley. Authorities cite local causes for each outbreak, sometimes blaming unnamed political opportunists, religious fanatics or drug-crazed hooligans. But others see deeper roots. ``The problem is social frustration among a generation of youths who are losing their old values and see nothing to replace them,'' said Munira Shadheedi, a historian in Dushanbe. Opposition politicians, mostly writers and other intellectuals, see a policy vacuum as Communist Party stalwarts push ahead with only modifications of ideas that have failed to inspire confidence. These new leaders say it is too early to design specific programs for independence. First, most say, they must abolish entrenched official corruption, which impoverishes and embitters their populations. Alternative parties are beginning to attract wide support. The Uzbekistan popular front, Birlik, has inspired similar movements in other republics. Krupnik said he saw signs these disparate opposition groups were linking up, forging the beginnings of a grass-roots movement across Central Asia. Their main obstacle is a historical aversion to mixing among ethnic groups in the region, he said. If Central Asia mixes anywhere, it is here in Samarkand, a city of 390,000 people that recently celebrated its 2,500th anniversary. The old mud synagogue blends unnoticed into a block of Moslem houses. Men of all religions wear the same square black skullcaps embroidered in white. A multitude of nationalities sits together for tea and patterned wheels of bread, escaping the sun under shade trees. But a chat with Samarkand university students suggests that this harmony of old is changing fast. A Crimean Tatar woman felt growing antipathy and said her family wanted badly to get home. Her Russian-Ukrainian friend said Uzbeks are making up for lost time in reasserting national pride. ``There is a very dark fear which is difficult to understand,'' concluded a young Russian, like the others reluctant to be quoted by name. ``We see discrimination against others. The Russians are next.''
DOC.HEAD: NEXT _ Part II: Islam Resurgent
Circus Legislature Sets New Standards for Chaos in Massachusetts
DOC.TEXT: After passing the state's largest tax hike in history, Massachusetts legislators tried to junk that plan and tried to pass an even bigger package. Then on the same day, they decided to return to the original plan. ``This is really a test,'' joked state Rep. John Flood. ``They want to see how many dumb votes the Legislature will make in one week.'' But not many people have been laughing, especially not the Wall Street analysts who have dropped Massachusetts' bond rating below every other state. The Legislature finally enacted a balanced, $13.43 billion budget early Saturday morning and a $1.43 billion bond authoritization, but for months Massachusetts had struggled to solve its fiscal difficulties. As Massachusetts economy continued to sink, the state ran up a deficit exceeding $1 billion in the fiscal year that ended June 30. Last week's events seemed to set new standards for Statehouse chaos, and they came just when it appeared the state had put its troubles behind. ``It will be less than a week before the Massachusetts Legislature makes it into Johnny Carson's monologue,'' remarked James Braude, head of the Tax Equity Alliance for Massachusetts, a group that favors higher taxes. After wrangling over the escalating budget deficit, lawmakers had sent Gov. Michael S. Dukakis a $1.2 billion tax package. Dukakis signed the law, proclaiming ``the miracle is beginning to revive,'' a reference to the ``Massachusetts Miracle'' theme of his failed 1988 presidential campaign. Then legislative negotiators agreed on a budget for the fiscal year that began July 1. Never mind that the budget was more than three weeks late; Massachusetts has made this a habit in recent years, forcing the state to adopt temporary spending plans. But the $13.7 billion budget presented Monday still had a $200 million-plus deficit. Dukakis would be able to bring balance it with his line-item veto powers, but nonetheless lawmakers who were still smarting over the tax battle decided to revolt. What emerged, to nearly everyone's shock, was a proposal to repeal the just-passed tax plan, which included a controversial sales tax on business services, and substitute another version athat would cut the tax on services but make income taxes even higher. The strategy was to appease House members by giving them a package resembling a tax plan they approved earlier in the year. In the end, though, the plan to do a flip-flop on the tax plan failed. The House Ways and Means Committee endorsed the measure, but the resulting firestorm through the Statehouse killed it. Almost lost during the confusion was the fact that the state still had that new tax law on the books. Even Senate President William Bulger, known for his strong authority, said during the height of the recent chaos: ``I am here and I am bewildered.'' ``This is appalling,'' said Francis Faulkner, of Citizens for Limited Taxation, an anti-tax group. ``You have legislators asking what's going on. These are people who are supposed to represent the state.'' Faulkner's group is counting on public anger toward the Legislature, because his organization is sponsoring a ballot petition in November that would roll back state taxes and fees to 1988 levels, thereby undoing the new tax law. Also in November, voters will choose a new governor to replace Dukakis, whose popularity tumbled like the state's bond ratings and who decided against seeking re-election. Both Democrats and Republicans have campaigned against Dukakis' policies, saying the antics in the Legislature demonstrate a lack of leadership. ``This is far beyond a partisan issue. This is a matter of whether people in other parts of the country think we're crazy,'' said Francis Bellotti, a Democratic gubernatorial contender and former attorney general. ``The House blames the Senate. The Senate blames the House. Everybody blames the governor,'' he said. ``This is absolute insanity.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Sees Door Open for More Executions
DOC.TEXT: The execution of a convicted killer should end weeks of controversy over whether Florida's electric chair is a valid means of execution or a torture device as defense attorneys claimed, the governor said. ``Florida should now be able to resume carrying out its capital punishment statute,'' Gov. Bob Martinez said after Anthony Bertolotti was pronounced dead Friday evening. ``The people of Florida can know that criminals who show a total disregard for human life will indeed be called upon to pay the ultimate penalty for their actions,'' the governor said. During the May 4 execution of Jesse Joseph Tafero, flames and sparks shot from the inmate's head and smoke filled the execution chamber. Tafero was finally declared dead after three jolts of electricity. Attorneys for three condemned inmates won indefinite stays from the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta with arguments that the electric chair was not functioning properly. As a result, Martinez ordered an independent examination of the chair. In a demonstration witnessed Monday by the media and state officials, Michael Morse, an associate professor of electrical engineering at Auburn University, concluded the chair was functioning properly and would send a lethal amount of electricity through an inmate's body. Prison officials said a moistened synthetic sponge contact, used for the first and only time in the Tafero execution, caused flames to rise from his head. On Friday, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld a ruling by a lower court that the chair's 2,000-volt charge is ``sufficient to cause painless termination of life,'' ending the legal alternatives for Bertolotti. The three cases held up by the 11th circuit would be the likeliest to result in the next execution, the governor's press secretary, Jon Peck, said Saturday. ``No decision has really been made on those other three, but potentially at least they could be treated a little differently because they all are basically ready and they were awaiting a ruling on the workings of the chair itself,'' Peck said. Martinez, a strong advocate of the death penalty, applauded the courts' decisions clearing the way for Bertolotti's death. ``It is gratifying that the courts concluded Florida's electric chair does in fact work as it is designed to,'' the governor said. ``Today's events have begun to restore certainty to Florida's ultimate penalty, and I commend the courts for moving toward that eventual end,'' he said. Bertolotti was sentenced to die for the Sept. 27, 1983, murder of Carol Ward. She was working in her yard in Orange County when Bertolotti approached and asked to use the telephone, and she let him in. He grabbed a knife, robbed her of $30 and then stabbed her repeatedly until the knife broke. He then found another knife and stabbed her until she died, leaving the knife in her body. At some point, Bertolotti removed her clothes and raped her. An unrepentant Bertolotti wrote several letters to prosecutors after his conviction, saying he wasn't sorry. ``I have no regrets or sorrows for the murder of Carol Ward,'' he wrote. She ``should have locked her damn door. I really did a favor by taking her life, don't you think so?'' Bertolotti was the 23rd inmate to die in the electric chair _ dubbed ``Old Sparky'' _ since Florida resumed executions in 1979. Since inmates carved ``Old Sparky'' from an oak tree almost seven decades ago, it has killed 219 state murderers and rapists and one federal killer.

DOC.HEAD: Peru's New President Takes Office As Economic Crisis Deepens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with inauguration. Pickup 4th, `Earlier...'
DOC.TEXT: Alberto Fujimori, the novice politician whose election shocked Peru's power brokers, was sworn in today as president of a country beset by staggering political and economic problems. Fujimori assumed power from outgoing President Alan Garcia in an elaborate ceremony in the capital. Earlier in the day, government helicopters flew over Lima and thousands of policemen and soldiers patrolled city streets. Despite the security measures, rebels late Friday blew up two electrical towers to black out most of the city for the second consecutive night. Earlier in the week guerrillas fired two rocket-propelled grenades at the Presidential Palace. Recent fighting in the country's Andean mountains and Amazonian jungle has left hundreds dead. The violence prompted the heavy security for today's ceremony, which was to be attended by a U.S. delegation headed by Secretary of Education Lauro Cavazos. Peru's economy has become increasingly unstable in the days leading up to Fujimori's swearing-in to five-year term. Many banks have run out of money and workers cannot cash their checks. People must wait hours to buy rationed gasoline and bread. The dollar's value jumped more than 75 percent in one week. Daily inflation topped the 6 percent mark by the end of the week, according to the private economic firm Cuanto. Until last week daily inflation had been running at about 1 percent. Key to reversing the economic collapse will be what Fujimori says upon taking office, analysts say. Confidence in his government will quickly evaporate if he does not soon offer detailed plans to combat the crisis, they say. Fujimori has proposed harsh but vague measures to bring Peru's economy under control. He said he wants to end price subsidies, sell off many government companies and impose an emergency tax on the wealthy. Fujimori plans a devaluation of the Peruvian inti that will make the dollar cost 300 percent to 400 percent more. He has already met in New York with the heads of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Peru has been isolated from world lenders since outgoing President Garcia cut ties with the two institutions in 1986. But the new president will have little to work with. The government is bankrupt and paralyzed by strikes. Four of five people lack steady work. The country is $20 billion in debt. Peru's main export is coca, the main ingredient used to make cocaine. The Peru Fujimori inherits also suffers from a severe drought that has wiped out crops and drastically cut urban water supplies. Hydroelectric plants run at half capacity and the daily blackouts that result have greatly slowed industry. Politically, Fujimori's small Change 90 party is nearly isolated. Since his landslide victory over novelist and free-market advocate Mario Vargas Llosa June 10, Fujimori has cut many ties with the left and center-left parties that supported his campaign. Garcia, a populist, has called on workers to resist any economic ``shock'' program. But Peru's center-right parties have also shown little desire to aid Fujimori. Former president Fernando Belaunde Terry has said these parties were elected to form Fujimori's opposition. Peru's military, however, has been less reluctant to work with the new president. An unprecidented three Cabinet positions _ defense, interior and fisheries _ will be held by military officers. The presence of a general atop Peru's powerful Interior Ministry likely signals a stepped-up effort to combat the country's two main guerrilla groups, analysts say. Peru's police force is controlled by the Interior Ministry. The move comes as the Maoist Shining Path and the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement have stepped up attacks. More than 19,000 Peruvians have died in political violence in the past 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: When Mark McEwen quit college one semester before graduation, he told his parents: ``I went to college to learn about people, so I don't need chemistry.'' McEwen, who was raised in the suburbs between Baltimore and Annapolis, says his hunch paid off. Besides acting as the weatherman and music editor for ``CBS This Morning,'' he will be one of eight hosts for a late-night talk show pilot, ``Midnight Hour.'' McEwen's stint comes Aug. 13-17. ``It's a hoot to be on national television,'' said McEwen, 35. ``There you are as a kid ... in the teeming metropolis of Odenton and you think, `What am I going to end up doing?' You don't imagine this.'' McEwen's destination when he left college in 1976 was Los Angeles for a career in stand-up comedy, but he ended up as a disc jockey back in Baltimore, then in Detroit, Chicago and New York. He started doing commercials, which led to the morning news show. ``Weather is OK, but it's not what I set out to do,'' he said. ``I do enjoy being able to say what I want. You have to be quick to do this. Live TV is live, so they need somebody who can blab like I can.''

The state's ``first gentleman,'' Bill Orr, says sales of his cookbook have surpassed 20,000 and have brought in more than $50,000 for the Governor's Mansion Restoration Foundation. ``The cookbook was enjoyable to produce and has been just as much fun to promote,'' said Orr, the husband of Gov. Kay Orr and a Lincoln insurance executive when he isn't cooking. The money will be used by future governors to remodel the living quarters of the mansion, he said. Books can be ordered by writing the governor's mansion in Lincoln.

Ecumenical Patriarch Dimitrios I, the spiritual leader of the world's Eastern Orthodox Christians, has received an honorary degree from Hellenic College and Holy Cross Greek Orthodox School of Theology. The honorary doctorate of divinity was awarded Friday, as the 75-year-old primate neared the end of a 27-day visit to the United States. He returns to Europe on Sunday. The 269th successor to Andrew the Apostle, the patriarch referred to the ages-old role of his predecessors as teachers of ``the word of God's truth.'' He also repeated a message delivered throughout his trip, telling the gathering of 2,000 people, ``Stand firm and go to the teachings which you were taught.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: An investment company responded to mismanagement charges leveled in a lawsuit by boxing champion Thomas Hearns by saying his extravagant lifestyle sometimes left him unable to pay his bills. Monthly financial statements filed Friday in Palm Beach Circuit Court by the company being sued showed the Detroit fighter spent $89,749 in April 1987. His spending included $2,288 for bedspreads, shams and curtains for a boat, $7,688 for a television and antenna, and $800 for a bodyguard, according to the statement from Davimos Advisors. There was also $2,400 for child support. The documents were filed in response to a July 13 lawsuit by Hearns charging the investment firm mishandled his money and collected hidden commissions on his investments. ``There were times when he listened to our advice. There were times he didn't,'' company President John Davimos said Friday from the firm's Los Angeles office. In return for 2.5 percent of each purse, Davimos handled Hearns' business affairs. The company also assisted Hearns' attorneys on ``various paternity suits and other legal matters,'' lawyer Larry Duffy wrote in the response. Ted Souris, one of Hearns' lawyers, denied the World Boxing Organization super-middleweight champion is having financial problems. Besides asking the court to dismiss the suit, Davimos filed a counterclaim for $170,000, the firm's share of Hearns' earnings from the Leonard fight.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Moslems Hold Government Hostages in Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Moslem extremists who stormed into Parliament firing automatic weapons held the prime minister and other officials hostage Saturday. Trinidad's archbishop said the rebels had wired the captives with explosives. The rebels said they had overthrown the government in the attack Friday afternoon, but Education Minister Clive Pantin said Saturday that the government had not fallen and was in control of the situation. The Red Cross said several people were wounded, and a news report said three people were killed. After bursting into the Parliament building Friday afternoon, the rebels from the Black Moslem group took Prime Minister Arthur N. Robinson and members of his Cabinet hostage. Some captives were apparently being held in the Parliament building called Red House and others in a TV station. Archbishop Anthony Pantin said on government radio he talked to coup leader Abu Bakr for 25 minutes Saturday afternoon. He said Bakr told him the TV building was surrounded by men with guns and he would detonate the captives and himself if an attack was launched. ``He has informed me that the prime minister and other parliamentarians in the Red House are wired up with explosives,'' Pantin said. Police superintendent Leonard Taylor imposed a curfew until 1 p.m. Sunday. Acting President Joseph Emmanuel Carter declared a state of emergency Saturday morning and put the country's 5,000-member army and 1,500-member police on alert. Carter was serving as president while President Noor Hassanali was in London.

DOC.HEAD: Killings of Medellin Police Continue After Cartel Declares Truce
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen killed four more police officers in Medellin, three of them after the city's cocaine cartel declared an end to its campaign of bombings and assassinations, police said Saturday. Minutes before the Extraditables, as the Medellin drug bosses call themselves, sent a message by facsimile mail to the local press Friday calling for a truce, gunmen killed a police officer, according to a police statement. Three other police officers were assassinated later in the day, the statement said. ``We decree a unilateral, indefinite cease-fire and we suspend attacks against police, bombings in all Colombian cities and the executions of politicians, journalists, judges and other functionaries,'' the statement said, which claimed the cartel was responsible for the murders of 215 police officers this year in Medellin and the surrounding region. The authenticity of the statement could not be independently verified. Police say the cartel is paying assassins $4,000 for each police officer killed. The Extraditables' statement said the killings were in retaliation for the murder and torture of suspected cartel members by police. Police deny the charge. Human rights officials say there is strong evidence that members of the force are participating in slayings in Medellin's poorer neighborhoods, where the cartel's killers are based. About the same time the cartel's statement was being released, a bomb exploded at a police post in the Medellin neighborhood of Villanueva, wounding five people, including a child, police said. El Tiempo, the country's largest newspaper, quoted police sources as saying that Friday's communique by the cartel was part of a strategy by cartel leader Pablo Escobar to have the government scale down its escape manhunt for him. Earlier this year, the Medellin cartel suspended its terrorist attacks as part of a peace overture to the goverment. The violence resumed after the administration of President Virgilio Barco ruled out negotiations with the cartel. Since August 1989, when Barco began his drug crackdown, traffickers have been blamed for the deaths pf more than 450 Colombians in terrorist attacks. The government is continuing to crack down on the traffickers' organization in Medellin. Authorities on Friday arrested 17 Medellin residents suspected of working for the drug cartel as hired killers, an army communique said. Meanwhile, police and hospital officials said that at least 18 civilians were killed late Friday by unidentified armed groups in Medellin, Colombia's second biggest city. Authorities also announced that they were increasing Medellin police salaries by 25 percent. Police now earn about $100 a month, not including benefits. The low salaries are repeatedly signaled as a major cause of police corruption and inefficiency.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Bodyguard Reassigned After Testimony on Drug Use
DOC.TEXT: One of Mayor Marion Barry's long-time security officers has been reassigned by the city police department and may face further investigation after his testimony at Barry's drug and perjury trial was contradicted, law enforcment sources say. James Stays, a 29-year police veteran, has been reassigned to an administrative post pending an internal police investigation into whether he has used cocaine or covered up drug use by Barry, police sources say. A government witness testified Friday that she used cocaine with Stays at a 1985 cookout in suburban Kettering, Md. Stays, the first defense witness to testify for Barry, said he never saw drugs on a 1986 trip with Barry took to the Virgin Islands. He also denied ever using drugs. The government witness, former civilian police employee Delois Mise, also testified that she once saw Stays and Barry together in a hotel room where a small bag of what appeared to be cocaine was lying on a table. Edward Sussman, Stays' attorney, could not be reached for comment Saturday. Prosecutors also produced a city government document Friday indicating a defense witness was not at work the day he said he took a job application from a government witness who had said she had personally delivered the application _ and crack cocaine _ to Barry. A government form introduced into evidence by prosecutors indicated that Clifton Roberson was absent from his job on Sept. 7, 1988, the day he said he received a job application from admitted cocaine dealer Lydia Reid Pearson. Pearson testified that she gave Barry drugs and the application on that day. Barry's trial resumes Monday, when prosecutors expect to conclude their rebuttal case. The defense ended its case Friday without calling Barry to the witness stand. The case could go to the jury late in the week. Jury selection for the trial began June 4. The police investigation of Stays could the first probe the Barry bodyguard faces, sources said. ``He will be dealt with administratively first, within the police department,'' said one federal law enforcment source. The source said tht federal prosecutors may conduct their own investigation later. Judy Smith, a spokesman for U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens, declined to comment. No further action has been taken against Stays for fear of afffecting the outcome of Barry's trial, one police source said. ``The last thing we want to do is give (Barry defense atorney R. Kenneth) Mundy a reason to say, `Hey, they moved against this guy because he defended the mayor.'' The investigation of Stays will begin once the mayor's trial is completed, the police sources said. If evidence of criminal conduct is discovered, those details will be provided to the U.S. Attorney's office, which, for reasons of protocol, normally allows the police department to carry out an internal probe before pursuing a criminal investigation of an offficer, the police source explained. Violations of police administrative procedures will be handled within the department, the police source said. A variety of punishments would be possible, including a reduction in Stays' rank or pension level. Police and other law enforcement sources said factors that could weigh against prosecution of Stays include his seniority and stated intention to retire within the next year. ``He has told a number of people, before all this happened, that he intended to retire when he reached 30 years of service,'' one police source said. ``If he is gone, that might affect a decision to prosecute.''

DOC.HEAD: Smiles Have No Place In Highway Construction Site
DOC.TEXT: State highway workers weren't smiling last week when they discovered some new faces in their midst. Unauthorized signs depicting a frowning face at the beginning of road construction along westbound Interstate 70 just east of suburban Reynoldsburg and a smiling face at the end of it were ordered removed Thursday. Officials believe the inent of the unidentified signmaker was to make the going a little easier for construction-weary motorists passing through the three-mile site. The signs were erected sometime Wednesday night. ``I think they are cute, but they are dangerous,'' said Michael Cull, spokesman for the Ohio Department of Transportation. In all, four signs dotted the route. The first bore a frown, the second had no expression, the third showed a hint of a smile and the final face at the end of the construction wore a wide grin. The signs appeared official and resembled the yellow-and-black ``Have a nice day'' pins and stickers that were seemingly ubiquitous several years ago. Cull said the signs had to go because they were not standard issue. He also said that any signs not designed to direct drivers safely through such sites are considered dangerous. About four years ago, a similar setup, which had progressively happier faces, was done by the authorities themselves in Michigan. State officials received more than 300 letters of support from motorists. One letter writer at the time, a Baptist minister from New York, called the signs ``a blessing to me.''

DOC.HEAD: France Says Release of Terrorist Raises Hope for Lebanon Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said France's decision to pardon a convicted terrorist whose freedom had long been sought by Iran may help win the freedom of all Western hostages in Lebanon, a newspaper reported Saturday. An Iranian newspaper on Saturday also tied the release of Anis Naccache to the hostage issue. The pardon was widely criticized by newspapers, some politicians and various lobbying groups. President Francois Mitterrand pardoned Naccache and four accomplices Friday and put them on a plane for Tehran. Naccache had served 10 years of a life sentence for the failed assassination of Shahpour Bakhtiar, Iran's prime minister before the 1979 Islamic revolution. A policeman and a passer-by were killed and another policeman paralyzed in the 1980 assassination attempt in Paris. Naccache was allegedly acting on Iranian orders and his imprisonment has been a major object of contention between France and Iran. ``This measure excuses neither the crime nor the criminals,'' Foreign Minister Roland Dumas told the Le Monde newspaper in a Saturday interview. Dumas said he expected the freeing of Naccache to result in ``a general calming, a lowering of tensions in the region, and, I also hope, we are working toward it, the liberation of all Western hostages still held'' in Lebanon. Dumas' words increased speculation that the release of Naccache could help efforts to free the 16 Western hostages in Lebanon, including six Americans. An official Iranian news agency report said on July 7 that a European hostage would soon be released. Syrian military sources in Lebanon said the released hostage would likely be Brian Keenan, an Irish teacher held hostage in Lebanon for four years. But no word has been heard from his kidnappers. The Tehran Times, an English language newspaper in Iran, wrote Saturday that Naccache's release ``can even be expected to add to the optimism that has been created for the release of one or two European hostages.'' The paper is believed to reflect the thinking of Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani. It urged other Western governments to follow the French lead, saying ``such moves can facilitate the Iranian republic's humanitarian efforts to convince the Lebanese groups to free the hostages.'' France is the only Western nation that has managed to free all its hostages from Lebanon. Besides Keenan, pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem groups in Lebanon hold six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss and an Italian. The longest-held hostage is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Iran claims the former government of Premier Jacques Chirac made a deal to pardon Naccache in exchange for the freedom of the last three French hostages held in Lebanon. They were freed in May 1988, days before the French presidential election, which Chirac lost. Chirac, a conservative, denied again Friday any deal had been struck. Dumas also said there had been no negotiations on the issue with Tehran. But Iran has made its wishes known on numerous occasions and France has met many other Iranian demands. In June 1986 France expelled Massoud Rajavi, head of a guerrilla group fighting to overthrow the Iranian government, and in November 1987, provided a plane to Tehran for Iranian embassy translator Wahid Gordji. He had been wanted for questioning in a 1986 wave of bombings in Paris. In each case, French hostages were freed. France also repaid part of a $1 billion debt to Iran. French observers predict the freeing of Naccache will aid in settling the financial dispute, which dates to the 1979 Iranian revolution, and pave the way for business ventures. The chief lawyer for Naccache, Antoine Comte, said Saturday the families of the five freed terrorists paid $740,000 in damages to the victims, as ordered in 1982 by the court. Half of the money is to go to Bernard Vigna, who was paralyzed for life in the assassination attempt. But the policeman's mother told Agence France-Presse, the French news agency, that the family did not want ``dirty money.'' The family refused to comment on the release of Naccache, saying only their reaction was ``bad.''

DOC.HEAD: Bats Infiltrate North Dakota Courthouse
DOC.TEXT: Workers in the McLean County Courthouse are going bats. Sixteen bats have been captured dead or alive in various departments within the last two weeks. A cleaning woman recently was wiping under a sink and a bat came out on her cloth. Another was found alive in the wastebasket in a room where the county commissioners had been meeting. Some have been found hanging on the walls near the ceiling. Officials say they think the bats are coming in the courthouse through cracks in a tower, then venturing down air vents. The next bat captured alive will be tested for rabies and other diseases, said Sandy Birst, district health nurse.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Could Provide Key Vote on Fetal Protection, Desegregation Cases
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Restores dropped prepositon ``on'' in 19th graf, ``I would ...'' ^By RICHARD CARELLI
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter, if confirmed, could provide key votes on such issues as abortion counseling, fetal protection and school desegregation in the 1990-91 court term that begins Oct. 1. The justices could be closely divided on those and other issues already docketed for decision, and Souter's views on them are a mystery. Legal scholars and lawyers following the cases say retired Justice William J. Brennan's votes would have been predictably liberal. The book on Souter: He's a conservative. The big question: How conservative? ``We're going from a known quantity in Brennan to an unknown,'' said Clarke Forsythe, general counsel of Americans United for Life, an anti-abortion group closely watching the abortion-counseling and fetal-protection cases before the court. At issue in the first are federal regulations that bar government-financed family planning centers from counseling women about abortion. The regulations are being attacked as alleged violations of free-speech and abortion rights. The so-called Title X program gives about $200 million a year to some 4,000 clinics nationwide that serve about 5 million low-income women. Forsythe, who wants the court to uphold the regulations, says he expects Justices Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens, the court's three most liberal members, to vote to strike them down. He said he hoped the court's conservative bloc _ Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy _ will unite to say the regulations are valid. ``It's not an easy case, and Souter could play a key role,'' Forsythe said. The second case could affect millions of working women. The court must decide whether employers may exclude all women of childbearing age from some hazardous, but comparatively high-paying, jobs to protect their fetuses. At issue is a car battery manufacturer's policy of banning women who cannot prove they are infertile from jobs that expose them to lead. ``Justice Brennan will be missed in both the workplace case and the Title X case,'' said Patricia Ireland of the National Organization for Women. ``He would have found (the fetal protection policy) to be offensive and inappropriate in that it ignores what exposure to lead does to men's reproductive systems. And he had a great history of respect for freedom of speech and women's rights,'' Ms. Ireland said. Susan Ross of the Sex Discrimination Center at Georgetown University's law school, said the outcome of the fetal protection case could hinge on Souter. ``We have reason to hope that Blackmun, Marshall and Stevens will be with us, and we think O'Connor probably will be with us,'' Ms. Ross said. ``We don't have much hope of picking up Rehnquist, Kennedy or Scalia. Perhaps White will vote against the policy, but I'm not optimistic. It's possible the outcome could depend on Souter.'' She added, ``Souter hasn't had to deal with employment-discrimination matters. It's very difficult to fathom where he'd come out.'' The court also must decide whether public school districts may abandon the forced busing of students after achieving racial balance in their schools if such a move would lead to resegregation. The ruling in an Oklahoma City case could be enormously important for the hundreds of school districts, including those in most major cities, under court-ordered busing plans for racial desegregation. ``I would suspect Justice Brennan would not have been on our side in this one,'' said William Pendley of the conservative Mountain States Legal Foundation. ``His absence from the case is a positive step, but Souter would be a question mark.'' Even American business is busy assessing the impact of Brennan's exit and Souter's possible entrance, most immediately in the controversy over the skyrocketing awards won in personal injury lawsuits and other cases. At issue in a case the court has under study is whether such awards can go so high they become unconstitutional. The justices last year said whopping awards never can violate the Constitution's ban on excessive fines but it left unanswered whether they might violate due-process rights. ``This is a big one, and we generally knew where Justice Brennan was coming from,'' said Jan Amundson, general counsel of the National Association of Manufacturers. ``He wasn't always anti-business. But Souter is an unknown. We're optimistic but uncertain.'' The court began its summer recess last month with 54 cases already scheduled for argument and decision in the coming term. The justices likely will add 80 to 90 more cases to that docket through next winter. ``Next year at this time, I wouldn't be surprised to count 15 or 20 decisions that would have gone the other way had Brennan still been on the court,'' Northwestern University law professor Lawrence Marshall said. Others are more interested in which _ not how many _ cases will fall into that category.

DOC.HEAD: City Opens Arms, and Streets, to Cruisers
DOC.TEXT: Teen-agers with time on their hands and gas in their tanks poured into this town for its first officially sanctioned Cruisin' Night, turning the narrow streets into a kind of ``Appalachian Graffiti.'' Whether riding in T-top sports cars, sitting on the tailgates of parked pickups or just standing on the street corner sipping free soft drinks, the teen-agers made the scene Friday night. ``You drive around and holler at some girls and park, and they come by and see you and pull in and talk to you,'' said 16-year-old Freddie Anderson of Belfry, Ky., as he sat on the roof of his Camaro. Officials and merchants in this town on the Kentucky-West Virginia border thought up Cruisin' Night after officials in several other cities cracked down on cruisers by enforcing traffic and loitering laws. Prizes were awarded in four categories: ``Best Looking Cruiser Car,'' ``Best Looking Cruiser Truck,'' ``Loudest Cruiser'' and ``Best Vanity Plate.'' Other prizes were awarded based on random drawings from registrations at the end of the three-hour event. The teen-age traffic jam resembled scenes from the movie ``American Graffiti,'' which depicted cruisers in a California town in the early 1960s. Downtown Williamson was packed Friday night with teen-agers, and occasionally with older drivers who found themselves caught in the bumper-to-bumper traffic, sometimes with panicked expressions. As the sun went down, the T-tops came off and the car stereos came on. The rap song ``Pump Up the Jam'' filled the air. Some drivers parked their cars and trucks and watched the others drive up two blocks on Second Avenue, left one block on Pike Street, down two blocks on Third Avenue and left one block on Harvey Street, ready to begin the circuit again. A line of cars stretching across two bridges into Kentucky waited to join the parade in this town of 5,000-plus people. ``It gets pretty boring after a while, but there's nothing else to do here,'' said Heather Gannon, 15, as she sat on the tailgate of a pickup truck. ``This is it.'' Richard Foster, 20, said he and the half-dozen young men with him would have come downtown even without the Cruisin' Night promotion. ``We're always here,'' said Foster, a weekend cruiser for five years. City police Sgt. R.E. Pyrtle, walking his beat, said the promotion appeared to bring the teen-agers downtown a little earlier than usual but said there was no trouble. ``Friday and Saturday nights, the kids mainly come here about 10 o'clock and cruise, but not to the extent it is tonight,'' he said. As the cruisers cruised Friday night, several adults watched from park benches outside the Mingo County Courthouse. ``I think it's just fine if it works out right,'' said Inice Ball, 79. ``I think it's fine for our young people, because there's nothing for them to do here.'' Williamson's invitation to the teen-age cruisers contrasts with what other area cities are doing. In Charleston, nearly 60 miles to the northeast, police reacted to merchant complaints about noisy, littering teens this summer by strictly enforcing traffic regulations. Across the Tug River from Williamson in South Williamson, Ky., police have taken steps to block cruisers from congregating in a mall parking lot. But Colin Berry, president of the Williamson merchants' association and an organizer of Cruisin' Night, declined to criticize officials who want to put the brakes to cruising. ``It's not up to me to judge what someone else should do,'' he said. ``Different towns have different problems.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Advance on Doe's Mansion; Ambassadors Appeal for Help
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based partly on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia. AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith was among them.

Rebel soldiers fought to within one mile of President Samuel Doe's fortified mansion on Saturday and battled pockets of government troops for control of a hill overlooking the city center. Meanwhile, five European ambassadors warned that the country was slipping into ``anarchy and national suicide,'' called for an urgent U.N. Security Council meeting, and suggested that U.S. troops intervene. While the forces of National Patriotic Front leader Charles Taylor remained blocked by government troops six miles east of the capital, the smaller force of a rival rebel leader, Prince Johnson, advanced into the city. Johnson's disciplined rebel forces, neatly dressed in camouflage uniforms, carefully picked off snipers' nests as they moved up the steep hill toward the Ducor Palace Hotel, which has a view of the city center. Rifle and machine gun fire reverberated across the hill, as civilians hid in their houses. Johnson's rebels took control of the Waterside and West Point districts, at the city end of one of the two bridges from Bushrod Island. The island is on the opposite side of the city from Doe's mansion, one mile away. Doe has pledged to make his final stand inside the heavily fortified mansion. The rebels, who began their offensive in December, accuse the government of corruption and human rights abuses and demand Doe's resignation. The five ambassadors representing European Economic Community nations issued their warning Friday. Italian Ambassador Gianguido Lanzoni advised his government on behalf of all the EEC ambassadors that ``the interdependence of nations no longer permits other nations to sit idle while one country plunges into anarchy and national suicide.'' ``There is no longer any effective government in control of this country,'' Lanzoni told his government in a cable. He advised his government to call the U.N. Security Council into emergency session to discuss the chaos and killing of civilians on both sides in Liberia's civil war. And he suggested the European countries should look favorably on any American move to intervene ``in view of the special relationship'' between Liberia and the United States.'' There are four U.S. warships off the coast of the West African nation, founded by the descendants of freed American slaves. But the United States has refused to intervene, saying the war is an internal Liberian affair. The civil war has degenerated into tribal war between members of Doe's Krahn tribe and Gio and Mano tribesmen, many of whom support the rebels. Diplomats say both sides have indiscriminately killed civilians. Taylor, in a message broadcast Friday and Saturday over a local radio station, declared the dissolution of Doe's government and promised to hold elections in six months. Taylor said the Doe government was to be replaced by a National Patriotic Reconstruction assembly of which he will be leader. But reports from rebel-held territory said Taylor remained 30 miles from the front, and his forces were making little progress. One of Taylor's commanders conceded the government was still holding Spriggs-Payne Airfield in eastern Monrovia. On the other side of town, Doe's hard-pressed troops retreated with one of their three tanks from Broad Street, near the Ducor, to Center Street, outside the Defense Ministry, about half a mile from the mansion. The tank was so crammed with goods looted from shops in the neighbourhood that the crew barely had room to maneuver. Streets in the city center were deserted and all shops remained closed. A group of three foreign reporters walked through the no-man's land between the two armies and into the rebel-occupied waterside district. They spoke with rebels who were engaged in heavy exchanges of gunfire with government forces. At the junction of United Nations Drive and West Point Road, two bodies lay in the street. When the reporters went past the same place an hour later, another body was lying on the sidewalk. All were dead soldiers. Market people in West Point watched the fighting from their houses which had fallen behind rebel lines overnight. They sold what little food they had left, mostly tea bags and small tins of tomato paste. Fishermen set their nets to haul in sardines, which they sold at $2.50 a pound. A tiny sea ray was offered for 50 cents. Half a mile from the rebel checkpoint at West Point, two government soldiers had pulled up in a car and were talking to the wife of one of them. Ahead of them was only the empty street, littered with garbage. The wife hurredly threw her husband a pair of jeans, a T-shirt and shoes, yelling ``change, change.'' Then she was gone, while the soldier shamefacedly began taking off his army uniform and putting on his civilian disguise.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Threatens to Retaliate Against U.S. Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: The speaker of Parliament said Saturday that Iraq is prepared to retaliate against a U.S. decision to impose economic and trade sanctions against Baghdad. The U.S. Senate voted Friday to cut off $1.2 billion in U.S. loan guarantees to Iraq. The Senate also moved to bar sales of weapons and sensitive technology to Iraq. The Senate move, and a watered-down sanctions package approved by the House, were signs of growing congressional concern about Iraq's human rights abuses, intimidation of its neighbors, harboring of terrorists and developing chemical and nuclear weapons programs. The Iraqi legislator, Saad Mahdi Saleh, warned Iraq may impose its own sanctions against the United States. ``We flatly refrain from having economic relations with those who have no interest in having economic relations with us,'' Saleh said. Saleh, who is also a member of the policy-making council of the ruling Baath Party, said the Senate decision was motivated by the pro-Israeli lobby in the United States. His remarks, reported by the official Iraqi News Agency, were the first Iraqi reaction to the Friday vote. ``We, the representatives of the Iraqi people, express our surprise at the illogical decision taken by those Congress members who are either threatened or misled by the Zionists and their premeditated propaganda,'' Saleh said. Saleh praised those legislators who voted against the sanctions move. ``We see those who belittle us as the minutest and meanest of creatures,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Balloonist, 72, Flies By The Seat Of His Pants
DOC.TEXT: Balloon pilot James Johnson has drawn a lot of attention at the 1990 U.S. National Hot Air Balloon Championship. For one thing, the 72-year-old Johnson is the oldest entrant in this year's championship, which ends Sunday. And unlike most other pilots, he literally flies by the seat of his pants, sitting beneath his multicolored homemade balloon, the Wallaby, in a chair instead of the usual brown wicker basket. ``I wanted to do something a little different,'' said Johnson, who took his first balloon ride at age 60. ``You do get an awful lot of attention. Everywhere you go, you're a star.'' Although he owns a traditional ballooning basket, Johnson said he enjoys a more open-air feeling when he's flying. ``I'm so used to this thing that it doesn't bother me anymore,'' he said. ``I like this one better.'' Airborne with a large fuel tank positioned behind his back and a neon orange helmet atop his head, Johnson looks more like Flash Gordon than a retired electronics engineer from Garland, Texas. Though he took up the sport at a late age, he said he always dreamed of being a pilot. ``I was just determined to learn to fly,'' he said. ``I had been interested for a long time, and I lived in Europe, where they do quite a bit of gas ballooning.''

DOC.HEAD: Agency That Used Tax Money for Parties Seeks to Cleanse Image
DOC.TEXT: Employees of a federally funded job training center held parties at a fine resort and bought VCRs for home use, thanks to a loophole allowing them to spend interest on federal grants any way they wanted. Now, some congressmen are seeking to close that loophole. All told, the South Central Private Industry Council, a federally financed job assistance agency, spent more than $20,000 on parties and other luxuries in the last four years. The council has been investigated over the last three months, and the probe's findings may lead Congress to revise a federal law that allows job agencies to spend interest earned on federal Job Training Partnership Act money at their own discretion. ``It hurts the public perception of carrying out the intent of the program. This is out there for training disadvantaged and displaced workers,'' said David Williams, deputy assistant secretary of the U.S. Department of Labor, which oversees the job program. Williams said several congressmen have moved to revise the law to mandate that money be used only for job training. The SCPIC, one of 17 such agencies in Wisconsin, has a $2.4 million budget this year and employs nine workers. It is responsible for training unemployed and displaced workers in four south-central Wisconsin counties and finding them jobs. Of the $20,900 spent by the council, $13,509 was for the last three annual meetings held each August at the Chula Vista resort in Wisconsin Dells, a popular tourist haven. Last August, council members spent about $4,000 on the annual party, including $2,450 on lodging, dinners, drinks, and nightclub admissions; $480 to rent a boat for a ride around a lake and $400 for hors d'oeuvres, records showed. In December, the council spent $951 on a Christmas party for the staff at the Fur, Fin and Feather restaurant in Oxford. And earlier this year, the council staff purchased four videocassette recorders at a cost of $1,196. Employees took them home. Administrators defended the purchases, saying the workers would use the equipment at home to bolster skills they lack the time to improve in the office. When an audit first disclosed the spending, the council's former marketing director, Jane Stroede, and others defended the parties as a necessary means for thanking volunteer board members. ``I don't think fun is against the public interest,'' Ms. Stroede said in April. But the council has since changed its position after months of stinging criticism from government watchdogs. It has fired its director, Mary Zilisch, and created a committee to review all spending and operations. Council board member Ronald Thompson, chairman of the review committee, said the board will vote in the next month on improvements, including a recommendation that no taxpayer money be used for parties. ``It's a matter of public perception,'' Thompson said in explaining the changes. State officials are also promising the agency will get plenty of increased regulation. But even with the changes, the council may have done irreparable harm by ruining public trust and blemishing a program that many government watchdogs already have distrusted for years, some say. ``They've got a terrible record,'' said former U.S. Sen. William Proxmire, a Wisconsin Democrat who built a reputation during his three decades in Congress for demanding frugal spending with his ``Golden Fleece'' awards. He claimed the program has cost $18.5 billion since the act passed in 1982, but statistics show it helps only one in 20 participants get off welfare.

DOC.HEAD: Newcomer Alberto Fujimori Sworn in As Peruvian President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with details of inauguration, speech. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Political newcomer Alberto Fujimori, sworn in Saturday as president of beleaguered Peru, offered dialogue with Marxist rebels and promised fairer treatment for the South American nation's poor. The new president attacked corruption and pledged to lead debt-ridden Peru back into the international community of nations. He also said the blame for the international narcotics problem lies with cocaine-consuming nations as well as drug-producing nations like Peru. Peru is the world's main source of the coca plant, from which cocaine comes. The bespectacled 52-year-old former college president _ an upset winner in elections in June _ accepted the red-and-white sash of office and said ``I swear by God'' to try to solve Peru's problems. ``Peruvians are fed up with being fed up,'' he said. Fujimori's comments at the ceremony in the red-carpeted, cedar-paneled the House of Representatives chamber brought cheers from lawmakers. The new president was celebrating his birthday on Saturday, which is also Peru's independence Day. Fujimori, who is to serve until 1995, faces daunting problems. He mentioned the 2.2 million percent inflation over the past five years, increasing poverty, its bloated bureaucracy, drug trafficking and terrorism. ``The people elected us to institute a new language of nationwide understanding _ the language of dialogue, cooperation and a search for consensus,'' Fujimori said. The backdrop was a bronze frieze of Gen. Jose de San Martin, Peru's 19th-century liberator, and a large wooden crucifix. The new president asked for special congressional power to decree new and fairer taxes, presumably on Peru's wealthy elite. He said he would set up a special anti-corruption committee, simplify customs regulations, reduce government participation in the economy and push for measures to give ordinary Peruvians greater access to government officials. When Fujimori said his administration would be ``implacable'' in its fight against government corruption, many members of Congress stood up and chanted their approval. The new leader did not mention by name his leftist populist predecessor Alan Garcia, who took office in 1985. But he said: ``We inherited a disaster.'' Garcia's farewell speech drew boos from some lawmakers, and a few walked out. Fujimori said he would scrap a bank-nationalization law that went on the books under Garcia but never was implemented. He repeated a campaign pledge to reverse Garcia's policy of freezing out Peru's creditors and ignoring the $20 billion foreign debt. ``Our administration is resolved to re-establish Peru's international relations in the financial field,'' the new president said. He said he hopes to stimulate foreign investment in Peru. On drugs, Fujimori took a stand similar to that of President Virgilio Barco of Colombia. Barco who was on hand for the inauguration, along with the presidents of Argentina, Bolivia, Chile and Venezuela. Fujimori said cocaine-consuming countries are just as responsible for stopping drug use as are South American nations that grow coca leaf and turn it into cocaine. ``You cannot place the weight of the responsibility for this fight on a poor country buried in a severe economic crisis,'' Fujimori said. He said Peruvian peasants who grow coca to survive need an alternative. The Bush administration is pressuring the Andean nations to militarize their fight against the cocaine trade. Washington has offered Peru $35 million in military aid. ``This is not a simple military question ... due to the obvious and indisputable demand of a powerful market outside Peru,'' Fujimori said. The new president also proposed ``reason and dialogue'' to deal with Marxist rebels. Political violence has resulted in about 19,000 deaths in the last decade. Fujimori said Peru also must improve living conditions in the remote, impoverished Andean highlands, where terrorists _ principally the fanatical Marxist Shining Path rebels _ have their strongholds. Garcia had also called for dialogue with terrorist groups, but the response was increased assassinations and bombings.

DOC.HEAD: Unresolved McMartin Case Left Many Victims in its 7-Year Wake
DOC.TEXT: The McMartin Pre-school child molestation case began in a wildfire of bizarre accusations that swept in from the seaside community of Manhattan Beach to engulf Southern California for seven years. When the longest, costliest case in U.S. history ended last week with a deadlocked jury, the passion that ignited it was all but extinguished and the anger that kept it going erupted only intermittently. But left in the ashes of the McMartin case are many victims. Raymond Buckey, 32, who endured five years in jail and two trials, said his family suffered beyond measure. The jury in the first trial acquitted Buckey of 40 charges last January and cleared his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, of 12 counts. That jury deadlocked on 13 counts against Buckey, and prosecutors refiled eight. The jury in his second trial deadlocked Friday on eight molestation charges and a mistrial was declared. Prosecutors said there would be no third trial in the case that cost Los Angeles County more than $13.5 million. ``I'd like to get for my family the house that was taken away from them,'' Buckey said afterwards. Peggy McMartin Buckey, 63, and her husband, Charles, had to sell their home and the prestigious school, which grandmother Virginia McMartin had operated for 22 years, to pay legal costs. Buckey's sister, Peggy Ann, a teacher of handicapped children, lost her teaching credential but won it back in a long, bitter battle after charges against her were dismissed. Teachers Betty Raidor, Babette Spitler and Mary Ann Jackson lost their careers as nursery school teachers, even though they were ultimately cleared. ``The case has poisoned everyone who had contact with it,'' the judge in the first trial said at one point. ``By that I mean every witness, every litigant and every judicial officer. It's a very upsetting case.'' Those words from Superior Court Judge William Pounders came after two witnesses had died, one by his own hand, the other from alcohol-related disease. And the children who fueled the case with claims of satanic rituals, animal sacrifices and molestations were balking at repeated ordeals on the witness stand. The newscaster who first broke the McMartin story lost his job and jurors learned he had an affair with a therapist who interviewed the McMartin children at Children's Institute International. The saga began in August 1983 when a mother reported to police that her son had been molested at the preschool. Hysteria followed after police asked parents to check their children for signs of molestation. Hundreds of parents reported their children were victims, and tots were rushed to the institute for interviews. Therapists decided more than 100 probably had been molested. Everyone agreed that the children who testified were victims of the long litigation. ``Those kids cannot be McMartin kids for the rest of their lives,'' prosecutor Joseph Martinez said after jurors deadlocked in Buckey's second trial Friday. ``It's been a horrible experience.'' But some parents would not give up. ``My child was not called as a witness in either trial,'' Robert Salas said. ``And that was one of the things wrong in the case. The case was flawed from the beginning.'' For District Attorney Ira Reiner, the case became an albatross. It is believed to have cost him the Democratic nomination for state attorney general. His predecessor, Robert Philibosian, who filed the original McMartin case, called the outcome ``a political disaster'' for Reiner. Buckey's lawyer, Danny Davis, has said he may leave the practice of law and devote himself to helping children. He has called Buckey ``an American hero'' and ``the most courageous client I've ever had the privilege of serving.'' He said he would not file civil lawsuits against anyone on Buckey's behalf. ``We've lost a lot of faith in the judicial system and I can think of nothing worse than for my client to get involved in civil litigation,'' he said. Buckey, who matured and gained confidence under the publicity spotlight, now hopes to fade into anonymity. ``I would like to be just left alone,'' he said. ``I'd like to move out of the city and find a little fresh air.''

DOC.HEAD: United States, ASEAN Play Down Differences on Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: The United States and its allies in Southeast Asia are in general agreement on policy regarding Cambodia even if they disagree on some specifics, Thailand's foreign minister said Saturday. The Thai official, Siddhi Savetsila, said the ``fundamental objectives'' of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the United States on Cambodia are the same. ``We are at one on comprehensive political solution and we both agree on the urgent need for the Cambodian supreme national council to be established at the earliest opportunity,'' Siddhi said. He spoke at ASEAN's annual meeting with its largest trading partners, the United States, Japan, Canada, the European Community, Australia and New Zealand. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told the meeting Friday that ``we are drawn together by converging interests _ in matters of security, economics, democracy and human rights.'' When it comes to specifics, however, the United States and ASEAN have not held identical positions on Cambodia. The ASEAN countries _ Thailand, Singapore, the Philippines, Brunei, Malaysia and Indonesia _ were jolted by Baker's announcement earlier this month that the United States was withdrawing its recognition of the U.N. seat held by the three-member Cambodia resistance coalition. The coalition includes the Khmer Rouge, which is blamed for killing hundreds of thousands of Cambodians when it ruled the country from 1975-78. The Khmer Rouge, backed by China, now is the strongest member of the resistance coalition. Baker said Washington would open talks with Vietnam, the main backer of the Cambodian government in Phnom Penh, and possibly with Phnom Penh itself to try to end the fighting. ASEAN organized the resistance coalition in 1982 with U.S. support, and it has been the cornerstone of ASEAN policy toward Cambodia since then. Baker said continued support for the coalition in the U.N. General Assembly ``is only providing the Khmer Rouge diplomatic cover for its military maneuvers.'' The United States and ASEAN agree that a supreme national council of individuals representing a broad spectrum of opinion should be formed to hold Cambodia's U.N. seat and embody the country's sovereignty until elections can be organized under U.N. auspices. An earlier ASEAN plan would have the council comprise representatives of the Communist Khmer Rouge and other members of the coalition, non-Communist followers of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and anti-Communists under former Premier Son Sann, plus the Phnom Penh government. Also at the ASEAN meeting, the European Commission announced it would set up a comprehensive program for repatriation of Indochinese refugees. The announcement said the program would help provide a safe and orderly return for those who fled to crowded, makeshift camps.
