It also said it would try to help improve conditions in Vietnam and continue to help with costs for the camps in first-asylum countries.

DOC.HEAD: About 400,000 Moslems Scattered Across Caribbean
With AM-Trinidad, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 400,000 Moslems make the Caribbean their home, but most are East Indians who disdain the radical politics of black Moslems like those who are holding Trinidad's government hostage. Saturday, black Moslem Abu Bakr took over Parliament and threatened to kill the prime minister and much of his Cabinet. Bakr is a fundamentalist who has developed strong support from Trinidad's poor black community. His Jamaat al-Muslimeen sect has an eight-acre commune in western Port-of-Spain, where more than 250 men, women and children live. There is a large mosque, day care center, school and kitchens for the homeless. Bakr has close ties with Libya and has often stated that Islamic principles must dominate society. But few East Indian Moslems support views like Bakr's and tensions between Moslems of East Indian and African descent _ two groups that rarely mix _ have been high. Many East Indians consider the black Moslems political opportunists inspired more by the black power movement than by traditional Islam. Stokely Carmichael, the black power advocate of the 1960s in the United States, was born in Trinidad. Among the region's political leaders, prominent Moslems include East Indian President Noor Hassanali of Trinidad and Prime Minister Hamilton Green of Guyana, a black who converted to Islam in the 1960s. The first Moslems came to the region to work in the sugar cane fields, either as black slaves in the 1700s or as indentured servants from India 100 years later. Now domed mosques can be found on a dozen Caribbean islands, but the heaviest concentrations of Moslems are on the islands of Trinidad and Tobago and in Guyana and Suriname on the South American mainland. ``One of the region's strongest religious trends today is the movement toward Islam among blacks,'' says freelance writer Larry Luxner, who lives in San Juan. In the last 20 years, many blacks have converted to Islam. Luxner, who has written extensively on Moslems in the Caribbean, estimates that Trinidad-Tobago and Suriname each have 100,000 Moslems and Guyana 120,000. Trinidad and Tobago is mostly a Hindu and Christian nation of 1.3 million people. About 6 percent of the population is Moslem, with those of East Indian and African descent each make up 40 percent of the Moslem population. Writing in the Arabic magazine Aramco World in 1987, Luxner said Trinidad had 85 mosques, Guyana 133 and Suriname, formerly Dutch Guyana, 150. He said 25 percent of Suriname's 400,000 people were Moslem, the highest percentage in any country in the Western Hemisphere. There are also 2,500 Moslems in Puerto Rico, most of them Palestinians who arrived between 1958 and 1962, Luxner said.

DOC.HEAD: Rental Car Company Loses $3 Million Verdict
DOC.TEXT: A jury ordered Alamo Rent-A-Car Inc. to pay a man $3 million for false arrest after the company reported the car he had rented and returned as stolen. A Broward County Circuit Court jury awarded Dania businessman Michael Mancusi $300,000 in compensatory damages and $2.7 million in punitive damages Friday for malicious prosecution. ``The night I was standing in jail, I knew it was wrong,'' Mancusi said Saturday. ``Big corporations like this should not be able to swoop down and sweep people off the streets and put them in jail.'' The case began when Mancusi rented an Oldsmobile Calais from the Fort Lauderdale-based company for a week on July 15, 1986. He kept the car longer but didn't think there would be a problem because he had rented cars from Alamo before on a month-to-month basis. He said he received a letter demanding the car's return three weeks later, and a company employee agreed to an extension over the telephone. But Mancusi said he was called by a police detective Aug. 27 and told the car had been listed on a ``hot sheet'' of stolen cars. He said he returned the car that same day. But on Sept. 2 an Alamo employee signed an auto-theft arrest affidavit and Mancusi was taken to jail 14 days later. During booking, Mancusi's name was spelled incorrectly on jail records, leaving him in limbo behind bars when relatives tried to bail him out because there was no record of him under the correct spelling. He spent a total of 28 hours behind bars and was subjected to two rectal examinations for contraband. The case went to trial in February 1987, but after it was explained in court the judge ordered prosecutors to drop the charges. Alamo attorney Bob Merchin blamed police and prosecutors for proceeding with the criminal case. ``Michael Mancusi may have suffered some indignities, but that was not the fault of Alamo,'' Merchin said. Mancusi, who owns a company that makes commercials and corporate and travel videos, didn't see it that way and pressed his civil case. ``Obviously it's a nice award, but I spent a lot of time in jail, and I had a lot of anguish between the time of the arrest and trial, so I thought it was a very fair award,'' he said. ``I don't rent from Alamo any more,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Governors Angered Over Bush Administration Proposal on Tax Deductions
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New throughout with news conference, other updated material ^With AM-Education Goals Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The nation's governors gathered Saturday for their annual summer meeting, voicing bipartisan opposition to a Bush administration plan to limit deductibility of state income taxes. ``The deductibility of state and local taxes should not be further eroded,'' said Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad, a Republican and chairman of the National Governors' Association. He said Republican and Democratic governors were united in opposition the proposal by the Bush administration and congressional Republicans to raise more federal revenue by reducing the ability of taxpayers to deduct state and local tax payments from their federal tax bill. Republicans were wary, however, of talk among Democratic governors of offering a resolution or other statement condemning the deepening savings and loan scandals and perhaps suggesting a national commission of inquiry. ``We're viewing it as political positioning,'' said Michele Davis, director of the Republican Governors Association. Anticipating a possible Democratic-led resolution on the problem, Branstad said at a news conference that there was no need for partisan finger-pointing on the S&L issue _ but that there may be regional blame. ``This is one farm state governor that resents having to pay the bill for the high rollers in other states who were trying to line their own pockets and help their buddies,'' Branstad said. ``And it's both parties that have been involved in helping in this effort, and I don't think it makes a lot of sense to point the partisan finger.'' Branstad said he was ``madder than hell about being asked to pay for that because I went through the agriculture crisis in the mid-80s. ... I had millions of people in my state that suffered greatly. We didn't get a lot of sympathy through that time and I don't like the idea of paying the bills for the extravagance of those people involved in the S&L crisis.'' The first official session of the governors' annual meeting was Sunday. The host city of Mobile placed metal crowd-control barricades along downtown sidewalks in case of protests, though few were expected, and the city planted new palm trees along the route from the airport. The governors planned to discuss a wide range of issues before their meeting ends Tuesday, including a report on implementing the education goals they agreed on with President Bush last fall. Democratic governors met privately Saturday in nearby Pascagoula, Miss., in a home overlooking the Gulf of Mexico. Democratic Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas said the Democrats were trying to reach a position on a S&L policy. The governors stated their opposition to the latest proposal on taxes in a letter to the administration before the meeting. The bipartisan National Governors' Association has a longstanding policy against such a move, spokeswoman Rae Bond said. The governors argue that limiting or eliminating deductibility, in addition to raising federal taxes for individuals who itemize their deductions, would make it more difficult for states to raise additional revenues to provide new services _ and might lead to increased pressure to lower state and local taxes. The governors also dislike any proposals to raise federal excise taxes, viewing that as an infringement on state and local tax bases. ``The governors are very apprehensive about anything that would reduce the flexibility of states to be able to deal with their own situation in terms of revenue sources that are traditionally the states','' Branstad said. A group of Northeastern governors sent a letter of their own to federal budget negotiators saying the move would cause the federal income tax to become ``a tax on a tax,'' and would especially hit Northeastern states, where 18 percent of the national population pays 30 percent of all state and local personal and property taxes. ``It would strike especially hard at middle- and working-class families,'' they said. ``As a region, the Northeast is already suffering from the disproportionate impact of the savings and loan bailout.'' The tax idea emerged late last week from negotiations on a federal budget solution. Under the GOP plan, the currently unlimited deduction for state and local taxes would be limited to $10,000. Administration officials estimated the plan would generate $3 billion a year in federal revenue. In addition, federal budget negotiators are discussing raising the federal excise tax on beer and other alcoholic beverages, generating $7.2 billion. Several Democratic governors were considering offering proposals on the savings-and-loan costs, including Richard Celeste of Ohio, Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts and Douglas Wilder of Virginia. One plan circulated by Wilder would call for a national commission to investigate the collapse of savings and loans that threaten to cost federal taxpayers as much as $300 billion or more in bailout costs. On education, a disagreement emerged over the makeup of a commission that would issue report cards on how states are doing in meeting their education goals. An administration plan to have four seats each named by the administration, the governors and Congress would leave it dominated 8 to 4 by Republicans and was being opposed by Democrats, who feared it could become a partisan weapon. ``That has been a very sensitive area,'' Branstad acknowledged. Clinton said House Speaker Tom Foley and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell have written the governors suggesting the commission be established by an act of Congress. Clinton said the governors hadn't decided on a response. ``I'd say we'll all get a bad grade, or somebody will get a bad grade, if this report card business isn't up and running pretty soon after this meeting,'' Clinton said.

DOC.HEAD: Increased Alcohol Tax Would Add $101 Yearly to Typical Family's Expenses
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 11-12 pvs, bgng: `Every governor,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with quote from governors' conference. Picks up 13th graf pvs, Forty-one states
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's proposal to increase taxes on alcoholic beverages would cost the average American family $101 a year, with the greatest burden falling on the poor, congressional analysts say. The proposal, which would cost drinkers $7.2 billion a year, is part of the second deficit-reduction tax increase offered by the administration this year. The new package has yet to be agreed to by Republican congressional leaders _ let alone by top Democrats _ who are trying to negotiate deficit cuts of more than $50 billion for next year. Under the proposal, the $1.98 federal tax on a fifth of 80-proof vodka would rise to $2.54. For the first time in almost 40 years, taxes on beer and wine would be raised as well, so that an ounce of drinking alcohol would be taxed at 25 cents, regardless of the form. That would boost the 16-cent tax on a six-pack of beer to 81 cents and the 3-cent tax on table wine to 76 cents. The tax on other forms of wine, which is based on alcohol content, would go up accordingly. Analysts say the impact would be felt most by those with the lowest incomes, simply because they tend to spend a greater share of their earnings on alcohol than do the more affluent. According to the Congressional Budget Office, the 20 percent of Americans with the lowest incomes (averaging $8,228 after taxes) spend $308 a year or 3.7 percent on liquor, wine and beer. The top one-fifth, with after-tax incomes averaging $77,622, spend about $1,210, or 1.6 percent. A second new element of the administration plan would target upper-income Americans. For the first time, it would limit the federal deduction for state and local income taxes _ to $10,000 per couple or individual _ and raise up to $3 billion a year. Figures from the Joint Committee on Taxation indicate that the 86 percent of taxpayers with incomes under $50,000 a year would pay only 0.2 percent of that tax increase. Couples and individuals in the $50,000-to-$75,000 range would pay 0.5 percent; those between $75,000 and $100,000, 1.9 percent; and those making $100,00 to $200,000 would pay 11.2 percent of the increase. Those earning more than $200,000 would pay 86.2 percent of the $3 billion. Anything falling so disproportionately on the well-to-do usually is inclined to be endorsed by Democrats, but not this idea. It didn't take long for them to figure out that limiting the deduction of income taxes would make it more difficult for states to raise those taxes. The nation's governors condemned the plan. Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad, a Republican and chairman of the National Governors' Association, said Saturday ``The deductibility of state and local taxes should not be further eroded.'' Branstad, speaking in Mobile, Ala., at the governors' annual summer meeting, said governors of both parties were united in opposition to the proposal. Forty-one states have a personal income tax; in most, it is the prime source of revenue. The IRS has no current estimate on how many couples and individuals claim a deduction of over $10,000 for state and local income taxes. However, on returns filed in 1989, the 46 percent of taxpayers who itemized deductions claimed a writeoff averaging only about $3,800 for income and property taxes combined. The proposal would not affect the deduction of property taxes. While the well-to-do would have to swallow most of that $3 billion tax increase, as a group they would come out ahead when the entire administration package is considered. That is because the most contentious element of the plan is the same as when President Bush sent it to Congress last January: a reduction in the tax on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of stock and other investments. Bush contends the reduction would prompt so much economic activity that investors actually would pay $4.9 billion more in taxes in 1991 and still more in ever year in the future. Democrats agree the cut would boost collections in one year but say it quickly would become a drain on the treasury. But their opposition is rooted in another factor: More than 80 percent of the tax cut would go to those with incomes over $100,000 a year. About half the $50 billion-plus deficit reduction proposed by the administration for next year would come from tax increases, including user fees, and the cut in capital-gains taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow's Gorky Street Renamed Tverskaya Street, Its Old Monicker
DOC.TEXT: Gorky Street, Moscow's main thoroughfare that in pre-revolutionary days was home to fashionable shops and stores, will be given back its old name of Tverskaya Street, a newspaper reported Saturday. The decision to give the street back the name it had since the 15th century follows similar moves throughout the Soviet Union. Cities, streets, ships, farms and factories that were renamed for Bolshevik and other Soviet figures earlier this century are being given back their old names, to the delight of local residents. The newspaper Izvestia reported that the decision to rename Gorky Street was made by the Moscow City Council, which is headed by radical reformers. The City Council's headquarters is on the street. Tverskaya Street was renamed Gorky Street in 1932, after Russian socialist writer Maxim Gorky. The street, which runs westward from the Kremlin, has been an important route for centuries _ leading to the ancient town of Tver, which in 1931 was renamed Kalinin, for Mikhail Kalinin, one of Josef Stalin's henchmen. On July 19, Kalinin was given back its old name of Tver. Tverskaya Street once was narrow and twisting, but in the 1930s was made into a broad boulevard. Once the site of fabulous stores in pre-revolutionary days, it now is lined by huge, bland office buildings, including the massive Central Telegraph Office. Also on the street is the Gastronom No. 1 food store, formerly called the Yeliseyevsky Store, as well as the offices of Izvestia. Cosmetics queen Estee Lauder opened a boutique on the street earlier this year, and a Pizza Hut franchise is scheduled to open there soon. The street runs by Pushkin Square, which is home to the first McDonald's restaurant in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Judge's Request Clears the Courthouse
DOC.TEXT: It was a routine day at the police information desk until a judge showed up with a request. Officer Dave Davidson, who usually fields such questions as where to pay parking tickets, said Pierce County Superior Court Judge E. Albert Morrison walked up to his desk Thursday and plopped a package on the counter. ``He walks up and ... says `I'm Judge Morrison. I received this package at home and I'm suspicious of it,''' Davidson said. ``My heart just stopped,'' Davidson said, thinking of recent bomb attacks against judges elsewhere in the country. ``The judge said, `I wanted it checked out.''' Police evacuated nearby police administrative offices and courtrooms. Tacoma's police bomb squad was assigned to the Goodwill Games, so Army explosives experts were flown in from Seattle, said police spokesman Mark Mann. An X-ray examination revealed the box contained only paper products.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Says Eisenhower Spurred Revolution in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Former President Ronald Reagan honored another White House resident, Dwight Eisenhower, saying his predecessor was largely responsible for the wave of democracy now sweeping Eastern Europe. Standing on the porch of the white wood-frame home where Eisenhower lived as a boy, Reagan told a crowd of about 7,000 people in sweltering heat Friday that Eisenhower's philosophy and values were drawn from the open fields of Kansas. ``President Eisenhower did not live to see such changes (in Europe), but he knew they were coming. He set them in motion,'' said Reagan, referring to his fellow Republican's policies in the early days of the Cold War. As a statesman, he said, Eisenhower took broad measures to make a freer, more peaceful world. Before his speech, Reagan laid a wreath on Eisenhower's grave. After making his remarks, he toured a display called ``White House Treasures,'' which features more than 300 pieces of presidential memorabilia. Reagan's visit to Abilene, the town Eisenhower called home, was part of the celebration of Eisenhower's 100th birthday. Although Eisenhower left Kansas, the state never left him, Reagan said. ``Ike's Abilene was a state of mind and a set of values, first learned in this simple white frame house,'' Reagan said. ``Eisenhower remembered Abilene as a leveling ground where bank accounts counted for little and bloodlines for even less.'' Eisenhower lived in the house shaded by a hackberry tree from the late 19th century until 1911, when he left for West Point. He is buried in a nearby chapel, in an $80 regulation Army coffin. Reagan was introduced by President Bush's chief spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, a native of Abilene. Two other former presidents have confirmed plans to visit Abilene during the Eisenhower Centennial, which ends Oct. 14. Gerald Ford is scheduled to speak on relations between the president and Congress on Aug. 20, and Richard Nixon will speak about the end of the Cold War during an appearance Sept. 8.

DOC.HEAD: Governors Outline Strategies to Achieve Goals
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 4-7, ``Despite all xxx to update with Clinton remarks
DOC.TEXT: States should move away from the arbitrary grouping of students by age, governors said Saturday in a report that criticizes ``assembly line'' teaching. The recommendation is one of several in the report being offered at the National Governors' Association's annual meeting in Mobile, Ala. The report outlines the strategy for meeting the educational goals endorsed by President Bush and the governors in late February. The strategy was developed by the NGA Task Force on Education, co-chaired by Govs. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Carroll Campbell of South Carolina. ``Despite all the effort that has been made in the decade of the '80s to invest more money, start new programs and raise standards, we still face a crisis,'' Clinton said in Mobile, Ala., where the governors gathered to open their annual conference. ``We are still a long way from meeting these goals. ... We still haven't made fundamental and dramatic changes in the very design and structure of the education system,'' Clinton said. ``But we first have to face the fact that we still have problems with the attitudes of the citizens whose votes and opinions ... will determine whether we can make the changes we must make.'' The proposals will be discussed this week at the governors plenary session. The task force report criticized elementary and secondary schools for assigning students based on where they live, grouping them according to age and narrowly defined ability, and offering them curriculum and textbooks that are ``fragmented and repetitive.'' The present system requires too many teachers who focus ``largely on the mastery of discrete, low-level skills and isolated facts,'' the report said. By doing so, the report says, the system denies opportunities ``for students to master subject matter in depth, learn more complex problem-solving skills, or apply the skills they do learn.'' ``This arrangement was designed to prepare a work force destined for the assembly lines of the industrial age,'' the report says. The task force suggested that states rely on practices that ``expand rather than limit access to learning opportunities'' for low-achieving students, said the report. The report noted that ``age grading and fixed school years'' could be detrimental to those preschool and younger children not making adequate progress. States should consider other approaches such as upgraded early primary programs, multi-age grouping or summer programs that allow children to progress at their own rate and still meet performance standards, said the report. Other specific recommendations include placing top priority on developing new tools for assessing student performance. The governors' report said that portfolios, essays, or other open-ended problems that require students to synthesize, integrate, and apply knowledge and data need to be developed as alternatives to the exclusive use of conventional multiple-choice tests. The task force also asked states to conduct a statewide literacy assessment and asked employers to audit the literacy and other skills of their own employees. Shirley McBay, president of the Quality Education for Minorities Network, praised the strategies and underscored the governors' recommendation to eliminate tracking and ability grouping. ``They have recognized, as did we, that nothing short of restructuring the nation's educational system will do and that a holistic, coordinated approach is required,'' said McBay. The National Education Association a few weeks earlier called for elimination of academic tracking, stressing that the practice keeps underachievers down and lumps minorities into classes that can prevent them from realizing their potential. The American Federation of Teachers, however, complained the strategies fail to specify the role the federal government should be playing in assisting the states.

DOC.HEAD: 16 Killed in Fighting Between Rival Shiite Groups
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead and fixes type; SUBS eight grafs for 18-21 bgng `Amal calls...' to add government threats against rebel general; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Warring Shiite Moslem militias fired howitzers and multi-barrelled rocket launchers in south Lebanon on Saturday. At least 16 combatants were killed and 42 wounded, police said. Ambulances, sirens wailing, evacuated casualties from the battleground in the southern Apple Province to hospitals in Sidon. Security sources said many bodies could not be evacuated because of the intensity of the fighting. The Red Cross pleaded with fundamentalist pro-Iranian Hezbollah and the Syrian-backed Amal militia to abide by a four-hour ``mercy cease-fire'' Sunday to remove the casualties. The Red Cross threatened to ``immediately withdraw from the region'' if the cease-fire was not followed. Police could not establish who was winning ground in the latest confrontation, which broke out at the Hezbollah-held village of Kfar Milki, six miles southeast of Sidon. The fighting spread to Jarjou on the southwestern edge of Hezbollah's enclave in the province, according to a police spokesman, who cannot be identified under standing regulations. Amal, in a statement, said its fighters controlled Jrinnaya hill, which overlooks Kfar Milki on the northwestern edge of the Hezbollah enclave and were advancing through the deserted village. Hezbollah, or Party of God, said its fighters ``crushed four attacks.'' The fundamentalist group accused guerrillas of Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization of ``direct involvement'' in the attacks against its lines. Arafat has about 1,000 guerrillas manning a buffer that separates Hezbollah's enclave from Amal-held territory. The Palestinian deployment has helped block an advance west toward the Mediterranean coast and south toward the main Shiite cities by the pro-Iranian group. Amal did not refer to the reported Palestinian involvement in the fighting. The police spokesman said Arafat's guerrillas have ``sealed off'' the confrontation zone preventing policemen and news reporters from monitoring combat developments. He said, however, that four dead Palestinian guerrillas and 27 wounded were evacuated from the Kfar Milki region to hospitals in Sidon. ``The Palestinians are obviously involved in the fighting, but we can't establish whether they are taking part in ground attacks or just participating in the shelling duels with Hezbollah gunners,'' the police spokesman said. PLO officials in Sidon and Palestinian refugee camps on the outskirts of the port city refused to comment on the fighting Saturday. Amal and Hezbollah have been locked in a three-year intermittent confrontation for dominance of the 1.2 million Shiites, Lebanon's largest sect. By police count, the power struggle has killed 1,202 Shiites and wounded 4,131. Amal calls Hezbollah incursions into Apple Province an ``Iranian invasion,'' charging that the 2,000-member Iranian Revolutionary Guards contingent in Lebanon was involved. The command of the Revolutionary Guards contingent in Lebanon broke its usual silence Saturday to defend its role in Lebanon, saying it was only aimed at ``fighting the Zionists (Israel) and defending the Moslems.'' The statement, published by the leftist newspaper As-Safir, called on Amal and Hezbollah to ``end the fighting among brethren and unite your guns against the Zionist enemy.'' The Iranian troops came to Lebanon with the declared objective of taking part in confronting Israel's invasion in 1982. They set up headquarters in the east Lebanon's town of Baalbek and have since trained most of Hezbollah's fighters. In another development, the government of President Elias Hrawi announced Saturday it will take ``the proper measures'' to end a rebellion by Gen. Michel Aoun. He leads a rival administration in the country's Christian enclave. The government's statement, issued after a four-hour Cabinet meeting, did not elaborate. Beirut newspapers predicted the government steps include the imposition of an economic blockade of that part of the Christian enclave controlled by Aoun. Aoun, the former army commander, battled Syrian forces last year in an unsuccessful effort to drive them from Lebanon. That fighting left at least 900 people dead and 3,000 wounded. Earlier this year, Aoun's soldiers battled a rival Christian militia for control of the country's Christian enclave. Those battles ended in a standoff.

DOC.HEAD: Sharon Steel Corp. Settles With Posner
DOC.TEXT: Miami financier Victor Posner will pay Sharon Steel Corp. $7.5 million to settle legal actions against him by the company and its creditors, a federal court officer said. The case between Posner and Sharon Steel, with assets of at least $500 million, was the second-largest trusteeship case in the nation. F.W. Agnew, the bankruptcy court trustee overseeing Sharon Steel's reorganization, announced the tentative agreement with Posner on Friday. Besides paying the $7.5 million, Posner will relinquish his controlling share of stock in the company and he and his affiliated companies will give up claims of $55 million against Sharon Steel. ``He is giving up all ownership claims and every interest whatsoever,'' Larry Palmer, chief counsel to the trustee, said Saturday. Posner was chairman, president and chief executive officer of Sharon Steel until he was ousted during the company's bankruptcy reorganization. The creditors said Posner mismanaged the company and drained its assets. Among other things, they charged that he used $4.4 million of Sharon Steel money to pay his legal fees in a federal tax evasion trial in Florida, in which he was convicted in September 1987. ``The value of the settlement is not only the money but in making him go away,'' Palmer said of Posner. He said court action could have taken years. A spokeswoman for Posner did not immediately return a phone call for comment. The tentative agreement was reached Wednesday in Pittsburgh in a hearing before U.S. District Court Judge Donald Ziegler, according to Agnew, who was involved in the negotiations. It must be approved in a joint hearing with Ziegler and U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Warren Bentz, to be scheduled in late September, Agnew said. According to Palmer, the case involving Sharon Steel was the second largest trusteeship case next to the Eastern Airlines case. Sharon Steel filed in 1987 for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws and a trustee was appointed. ``It was an economic shambles when we took over,'' Palmer said. Posner's affiliated companies, DWG Corp., NVF Co., Pennsylvania Engineering Corp. and their subsidiaries and affiliates, joined in the agreement, Palmer said. In May, a New York investors group filed a plan to bring Sharon Steel out of bankruptcy proceedings. The investors, the New York merchant bank Castle Harlan Inc. and Quantum Fund, an investment fund, said they plan to contribute $65 million to the company's pension plan, which would eliminate all back payments required by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. Howard Clark, president of Local 1197 of the United Steelworkers, said Saturday that 2,200 workers at Sharon Steel in Farrell have a tentative contract with Castle Harlan. The contract would take effect if the investors group is allowed to buy and reorganize Sharon Steel, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rain From Rockies To East Coast, Flooding In Upper Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Storms spread rain from the Rockies to the East Coast on Saturday, with locally heavy rain causing flooding in the Upper Midwest. Many streams in Iowa were running high from several days of heavy rain. Some streams in the Cedar River basin of northeastern Iowa left their banks Friday, leaving thousands of acres of farm land under water. The West Fork of the Cedar River at Finchford reached flood stage on Saturday, and was expected to crest Sunday at 15 to 16 feet, the National Weather Service said. The agency predicted that would put 20,000 acres of farm land under water. Some residential flooding was expected at Waterloo, Cedar Falls and Vinton. Three days of heavy rain also made rivers rise in south-central Minnesota, the weather service said. Urban flooding was reported in the Glencoe area, southwest of Minneapolis, where 3 to 5 inches fell Friday night, flooding many basements, the agency said. A motel basement wall collapsed, but no injuries were reported. ``The water just started to seep in slowly and then faster and faster and then the wall just gave way,'' said Glencoe police officer Tom Draper. ``It's basically just a big hole in the wall.'' The Crow River was expected to crest at Delano, west of Minneapolis, on Monday about 1{ feet above flood stage. In Texas, the Rio Grande was near flood stage Saturday southeast of Presidio and rising. A flood warning was in effect into Sunday over the Big Bend of southwestern Texas. Showers and thunderstorms extended over central and western Montana, east-central Wyoming, southern South Dakota, Nebraska, northern Kansas, Iowa, southern Minnesota and west-central Illinois, with scattered precipitation over eastern Wisconsin. Showers and thunderstorms also spread from southwestern Texas to southeastern New Mexico and the Texas Panhandle, along the Gulf of Mexico coast and over northern and central Florida. Showers and storms also extended over the South Carolina coast, eastern North Carolina, southern Virginia, Delaware, Maryland and southern New Jersey. Elsewhere, showers and thunderstorms were scattered over central and northern New England. Miami hit a record high for the date of 94 degrees during the early afternoon. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 56 degrees in Arcata, Calif., to 104 in Palm Springs, Calif. The low for the Lower 48 states was 38 degrees in Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO ADD GRAF MARK IN LEAD
Pipe Bomb on Tel Aviv Beach Kills One, Injures 19
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS two grafs to UPDATE with six Palestinians wounded in occupied lands
DOC.TEXT: A homemade pipe bomb exploded Saturday on a crowded Tel Aviv beach, killing a 17-year-old Canadian tourist and injuring 19 people, including a 9-year-old boy, officials said. Tel Aviv police spokeswoman Dalia Gilad said 13 Arabs were detained on suspicion of planting the bomb, which had been hidden in a beach bag. After the explosion, Israelis attacked several Arab bathers, stoned Arab-owned cars and beat Arab workers in the beachfront hotels. Ms. Gilad said seven Israelis were detained by police in connection with the attacks. She also said additional police were being deployed near the beaches to prevent further attacks on Arabs. Col. Bill Minis, a spokesman for the Canadian Embassy in Tel Aviv, identified the slain girl as Marnie Kimmelman of the suburban Toronto township of Willowdale. He said she died after surgery at Tel Aviv's Ichilov hospital. Minis said she was on a tour sponsored by the Canadian Zionist Federation. Bianka Ledderman, deputy director of Tel Aviv's Ichilov hospital, said 18 other people, including three other Canadian girls, were treated for slight injuries and released. The 20th victim, a 9-year-old boy, was brought into another Tel Aviv hospital for treatment and was released. One witness at the beach said there was complete confusion after the explosion. ``Suddenly I heard an explosion and people flew in all directions, scared, in shock and not knowing what to do,'' said the owner of a beach snack bar on Israel army radio. No group claimed responsibility for the attack. Police Commissioner Yaakov Turner urged Israelis not to riot and said increased Arab-Jewish tension was one of the goals of the bombers. ``The intention of the bomb-setters is exactly that, not only to injure, but to create such rioting between Jews and Arabs,'' Turner said on Army radio. Turner urged Israelis to be more vigilant to prevent attacks. ``We have special broadcasts that explain to the public what they have to do, that they have to be aware and suspicious of everything,' Turner said on Army radio. ``People have to be aware of what is going on around them. Hopefully in this way we will limit injuries.'' Saturday's attack was the first since July 1, when a letter bomb exploded inside a staircase mail box in downtown Jerusalem. Three people were slightly injured in that attack. Since May, a rash of bomb attacks have spread throughout the country. The most serious of the recent attacks was on May 28, when a bomb exploded at Jerusalem's Ben-Yehuda market. It killed one Israeli and injured nine other people. That attack was claimed by two Palestinian groups, the fundamentalist Islamic Jihad and a Syrian-backed dissident Palestine Liberation Organization faction. In the occupied territories Saturday, six Palestinians _ including a 13-year-old _ were wounded in clashes with Israeli soldiers. A total of 724 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians in the 31-month uprising against Israeli occupation. At least 242 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most as suspected collaborators. Forty-five Israelis also have been killed.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Lieutenant Receives Seven-Year Sentence for Rape on Ship
DOC.TEXT: A military judge sentenced a U.S. Navy lieutenant to seven years in prison Saturday after convicting him of raping a female officer aboard ship at a Spanish port. The judge, Capt. Thomas A. Lawrence, also dismissed Lt. j.g. Robin E. Brown, 27, of Rawlins, Wyo., from the Navy. Lawrence said he hoped the sentence would express the naval community's ``moral outrage and indignation'' that such a sexual attack could take place against one of its female officers. Navy officials in Spain said they could recall no previous case in which a male officer had been accused of raping a female officer. They said cases of shipboard rape are extremely rare. ``I think the judge did a good job of letting it be known that this won't be allowed in the Navy _ on ships or anywhere else,'' said the rape victim, who stressed that she did not hold the Navy responsible for what happened. The Navy has withheld the woman's name and rank to protect her privacy. Brown's defense attorneys said they planned to appeal his conviction and sentence. He was accused of raping the female officer on April 4 aboard the USS Suribachi while the ammunition ship was docked in Cartagena, Spain. Prosecutors said the rape occurred after Brown and the victim had gone drinking in town with fellow officers from the ship. On Friday, the judge found Brown guilty of one count of rape under the military code of justice. Defense lawyers chose to have the judge hear the case rather than a jury of six officers. The judge accepted the prosecution's contention that Brown returned to the ship drunk and entered the woman's stateroom, getting into her bed while she was asleep and initiating sexual intercourse. Brown, who is married and has a 1-year-old daughter, did not testify during the weeklong trial, but took the stand Saturday at his sentencing hearing. He said he believed he committed the crime, should be punished, and apologized to the victim. ``I'm very sorry for all the harm I caused your family,'' said Brown. ``I'm very ashamed of what I've done. I never intended to harm anybody. I wish you guys could forgive me.'' In her testimony Saturday, the victim said she and her family had suffered deep anguish as a result of the rape. ``He violated me physically,'' she said. ``I was in my stateroom, which is my home. And I should be left alone there. If I can't sleep in my own bed, where can I be left alone?'' Brown's defense attorney, Marine Capt. J.H. Drescher, admitted that Brown had sexual intercourse, but said his client was drunk at the time and may have believed the female officer had indicated her consent while semiconscious by making a gesture to encourage Brown. At the sentencing hearing, Drescher asked for a one-year sentence, telling the judge that Brown is `not an evil man ... (but) he was too weak to say `no.''' The prosecutor, Marine Capt. Walter Sharp, asked for a prison sentence of 12 to 15 years, saying Brown had committed an act of ``selfish self-gratification.'' Brown displayed no emotion as the judge declared the sentence. He will receive reduced pay during his confinement and lose all pay and benefits upon his release. Brown's trial has drawn attention because complaints of sexual harassment and discrimination in the Navy have increased in recent years as the number of women enlistees has grown from 9,000 in 1972 to the current 64,000. The service has come under particular scrutiny after a female midshipman resigned in April from the U.S. Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md., after she was handcuffed to a urinal and photographed by some male classmates in a hazing incident in December. The incident prompted the academy's superintendent to institute a new program of sensitivity training for midshipmen that focuses on sexual harassment and equal opportunity for women. Brown will be held in the brig at the joint U.S.-Spanish naval station in Rota before being transferred to a military prison in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Asylum-Seekers Abandon Italian Mission In Havana
DOC.TEXT: Four Cuban asylum-seekers left the Italian ambassador's residence in the Cuban capital after President Fidel Castro promised not to prosecute refugees who fled to diplomatic compounds there, news reports said Saturday. During a speech Thursday, Castro said no asylum seeker who had entered a foreign embassy by force would be granted permission to leave the Caribbean island. But he also guaranteed that asylum seekers who abandoned the diplomatic missions in Havana would not be prosecuted. The four reported to leave Friday had occupied the Italian envoy's residence since July 17. They departed Friday of their own free will, according to Mexican news services reporting from Havana. Beginning July 9, dozens of asylum-seekers entered the Swiss, Czech, Spanish and Italian diplomatic missions in Havana. The surge of refugees has put Communist Cuba at odds with the United States and Spain, once the island's colonial ruler. Castro has claimed the United States instigated the crisis, and U.S. officials have denied the charge. The Spanish Embassy's trade representative, Ignacio Ruperez, told reporters in Havana that the example of the asylum seekers who left the Italian diplomatic mission was a good precedent for those remaining in his country's embassy, said the Mexican news agency Notimex. The asylum-seekers who abandoned the Italian ambassador's house were driven back to their homes by embassy personnel, the independent Mexican news agency Excelsior reported. It said they ranged in age from 20 to 25 and were unemployed. Excelsior quoted them as asking to be excused for the problems their actions had created.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Says Program Ill-Conceived, Could Increase Segregation
DOC.TEXT: A program to let poor Milwaukee public school pupils enroll in private schools at state expense could disrupt the racial balance in the state's largest school system, an attorney argued in court Saturday. Patrick McDonnell, an assistant city attorney for Milwaukee, told a Dane County Circuit Court judge that the state's school choice program could ``cause the entire Milwaukee public schools system to become more rather than less segregated.'' But an attorney representing six parents and six of the private schools favoring the program said school choice creates a new educational opportunity and gives parents more control over their children's education. Judge Susan Steingass heard testimony from about a half-dozen attorneys in two lawsuits against the program, which is scheduled to start next month. Under the program, the first of its kind in the nation, the state would provide $2,500 per pupil for low-income families who want to transfer a child from the Milwaukee public schools to a non-sectarian private school. It was approved in April and signed into law by Republican Gov. Tommy G. Thompson. The primary lawsuit, on which Judge Steingass is expected to rule next week, claims the program is unconstitutional for providing state dollars to private schools. It was filed against the state by the Wisconsin Education Association Council, Wisconsin's largest teachers union. The union is among several education groups that oppose the program along with State Superintendent Herbert Grover, saying it undermines public education because private schools cannot be held as accountable as public schools. ``What the Legislature did is ignore 25 years of history of desegregating Milwaukee Public Schools,'' McDonnell said, contending the exodus of students in some areas could upset the ratios of white and black students in the city's federally-ordered desegregation plan. Robert Friebert, representing the Milwaukee chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and three statewide school groups, said the Legislature failed to include in the law means for the state to monitor the progress of the program's pupils. ``You can't have the public funds without the public controls'' under the public purpose doctrine in the Wisconsin Constitution, Friebert said. Landmark Legal Foundation Center attorney Clint Bolick, whose Washington-based group is representing the parents and private schools, said the school choice plan creates a new educational opportunity, which the Legislature is allowed to do under the state constitution. ``It transfers power in the area of public education from the educational establishment to the parents,'' Bolick said. The plan was a step in equalizing educational opportunities for poor pupils with those of wealthier pupils, Bolick said. Warren Weinstein, an assistant attorney general representing the state, said it was not unconstitutional for the program to receive state funding. Weinstein said the law calls for scrutiny by Superintendent Grover and an audit by the Legislative Audit Bureau by 1995. The second lawsuit, filed by Landmark Legal Foundation against Grover, claimed the school superintendent was illegally trying to force private schools in the program to meet complex and strict requirements not spelled out in the law.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Voices Support for Besieged Leader of Trinidad
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 9-10, ``Later, the State
DOC.TEXT: The White House expressed ``strong support'' Saturday for Trinidad's prime minister, a captive of black Moslem rebels who took over the Caribbean island's parliament. President Bush was spending the weekend relaxing at his oceanfront summer home here, but he and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft were kept abreast of the attempted coup, a spokeswoman said. Bush, who spent the morning on the tennis courts and boating, attended the wedding of a second cousin in late afternoon. Deputy press secretary Alixe Glen said Bush and Scowcroft were ``following the situation carefully'' in Trinidad and Tobago, a former British colony off the coast of Venezuela that gained independence in 1962. ``We maintain our strong support for the Democratic government of Prime Minister (Arthur) Robinson,'' Ms. Glen said. ``It appears that no American citizens are in any danger. The situation seems limited to one building,'' she said. Trinidad and Tobago have not yet asked for help, but the United States would consider the request if they do, she said. Robinson and several members of his cabinet were being held hostage in the parliament in Port-of-Spain by rebels led by former policeman Abu Bakr, leader of a Moslem sect that said it recognizes no government but ``the law of almighty Allah.'' Later, the State Department issued this written statement: ``We condemn yesterday's attempt by a violent extremist group to overthrow the democratic government of Trinidad and Tobago. We call upon the parties in this attempted coup to release the hostages under their control and to surrender to the legislative constitutional authority of Trinidad and Tobago. This violent attack on the government has no support from the people of Trinidad and Tobago who have enjoyed a long tradition of democratic government. The United States fully supports the elected government and is consulting closely with it and other interested governments in the region.'' An administration official who accompanied Bush to Maine said the army was still loyal to the prime minister and his four-year-old government. On another international hotspot, Liberia, Ms. Glen said, ``The situation has not changed. We're following it closely.'' The beleaguered government of President Samuel Doe has been under siege for weeks in that West African nation. Rebel leader Charles Taylor claimed Friday to have established his own government, even though street fighting continued. Bush, getting a weekend respite from the drawn out negotiations with Democrats over the budget deficit, brought his wife, Barbara, daughter, Dorothy LeBlond, and several grandchildren with him Friday on the flight from Washington to Pease Air Force Base in Newington, N.H. He also gave his taciturn Supreme Court nominee, David H. Souter, a ride home to New Hampshire. Before heading off to visit his mother at a Concord nursing home, Souter said it felt ``damn good'' to be back in the Granite State. This was the Bushes' third visit to their vacation home since Memorial Day. President and Mrs. Bush attended the wedding of a second cousin, Ruben Andrus Holden V, 37, of Marshfield, Mass., to Pamela Anne Grindle, 35, of Boston, at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Kennebunkport. The stone church, which overlooks the Atlantic, is where the Bushes attend Sunday services. Guests were required to walk through a portable metal detector. Mrs. Bush will stay behind when the president heads back to the White House on Sunday evening. The president will return here to Walker's Point on Aug. 10 and stay until Labor Day.

DOC.HEAD: Tests Find Cocaine in Colombia Soft Drink
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `The drink's ...' with two grafs identifying manufacturer and ADDING quote from its president. CORRECTS name of beverage to ``Pony Malta de Bavaria,'' sted ``Bavarian Malt'' throughout.
DOC.TEXT: A man who drank from a soft drink bottle containing dissolved cocaine was in a coma Saturday while federal officials discovered two other tainted bottles and checked possible links to Colombian drug smugglers. Drug traffickers frequently smuggle cocaine by dissolving it in liquids, officials said. Maximo Rene Menendez, 25, suffered convulsions and cardiac arrest after drinking from a bottle of the Colombian soft drink ``Pony Malta de Bavaria'' that contained an unknown amount of cocaine, said Jeanne Bush, acting supervisor of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration's Miami office. ``He had a very violent reaction,'' she said. ``He is gravely ill.'' Menendez was in critical condition at AMI-Kendall Regional Medical Center, said hospital spokeswoman Roxana Fernandez. She said it was too early for a prognosis for Menendez, who was on a respirator. ``Right now it looks better, but they really don't know what's going to happen,'' she said. Eight 6.16-ounce bottles of the drink were taken from Manendez's home in the Miami area, and tests performed at an FDA laboratory in Atlanta found high concentrations of cocaine in two of them. One bottle contained 54 grams of dissolved cocaine and the other had nearly 37 grams, said FDA spokeswoman Estela Brown. The other bottles contained untainted beverage. The drink Pony Malta de Bavaria is similar to a heavy non-alcoholic beer. It was not known how much cocaine Menendez had consumed, Ms. Fernandez said. She said 25 milligrams would constitute a lethal dose. Menendez noticed a strange taste to the drink after swallowing, she said, telling his father ``there was poison in it and to take him to the hospital.'' After Menendez was stricken Thursday, the FDA ordered the drink removed from the shelves of the Miami supermarket where he purchased it. Additional tests on Pony Malta de Bavaria taken from the supermarket and other stores are planned before a decision is made on any further recall, said Ms. Brown. The drink is manufactured by Cerveceria Bavaria S.A., based in Bogota, Colombia. Company president Augusto Lopez said Saturday the drink is produced both there and in Barranquilla, Colombia, and is shipped abroad by independent exporters. Lopez said he had no information about those exporters, adding that the brewery has nothing to do with the drink once it is sold in Colombia. Customs spokesman Michael Sheehan said cocaine smuggling in liquid form is a common trick among drug traffickers. ``We've seen dozens of cases of liquefied cocaine,'' he said. ``We've seen cocaine dissolved in wine, water, all sorts of ways.'' Sheehan said one smuggling ring filled clear plastic bags with a cocaine solution and placed them inside larger bags of water containing tropical fish from Latin America. Other traffickers have soaked towels and clothing in solutions of cocaine, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: AIDS Will Kill 3 Million Women, Children In 1990s
DOC.TEXT: At least 3 million women and children worldwide will die of AIDS in the 1990s, a medical journal reported Saturday. The report, published in the London-based journal The Lancet, said AIDS has become the leading cause of death for women ages 20 to 40 in many places, including New York City and central African cities. ``In these cities, infant and child mortality could be as much as 30 percent greater than what would otherwise have been expected,'' the report said, which cited figures from the World Health Organization. ``During the 1990s, not only can hundreds of thousands of pediatric AIDS cases be expected, but also more than a million uninfected children will be orphaned because their HIV-infected mothers and fathers will have died from AIDS.'' The HIV virus causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome, a disease that attacks the body's immune system and leaves victims susceptible to a wide variety of infections and cancers. There is no known cure. AIDS is most often transmitted through sexual contact. Other means of transmission include transfusions of tainted blood or blood products, and the sharing of contaminated hypodermic needles or syringes by drug abusers. AIDS can also be passed from mother to child at or before birth. The report in Lancet said Geneva-based WHO estimates that during the 1980s, there were about 500,000 cases of AIDS in women and children. ``During the 1990s, WHO estimates that the pandemic will kill an additional 3 million or more women and children worldwide,'' the report said. The report in The Lancet was written by WHO researcher James Chin. He said the estimates cited had been developed by WHO's Global Program on AIDS. Chin's report, entitled ``Current and Future Dimensions of the HIV-AIDS Pandemic in Women and Children,'' gave no estimate of AIDS deaths among males in the 1990s. But WHO last year estimated that a total of 6 million people were likely to have AIDS worldwide by the year 2000. Saturday's report said that during the second half of the 1980s, HIV infections among homosexual and bisexual men have shown a decreasing trend in most areas of the world. ``By contrast there has been a slow but steady increase in HIV infections among heterosexual populations: this trend has been most pronounced in Latin America, especially in the Caribbean,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan Woman Recalls Romance With Souter
With AM-Souter's Impact, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Anne Stanley says she fondly recalls her four-year romance with U.S. Supreme Court nominee David Souter, a man she describes as ``most comfortable in jeans and a flannel shirt.'' ``It was a typical young love, a wonderful romance,'' Stanley, 49, said recently. ``It was always understood that we were engaged and we would marry one day.'' But they drifted apart in 1963. The former Anne Grant married David Stanley in 1965; Souter never married. Souter and Stanley started dating in the summer of 1959 when they lived three miles apart in Weare, N.H., she said Friday. That fall, she entered Wellesley College in Wellesley, Mass., about 12 miles from Harvard, where Souter was a junior. When Souter was a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University in England, they wrote each other long letters and she visited once in 1963. ``He was unusually bright, honest, funny, witty, perceptive, self-disciplined and a good listener,'' she said. ``All of those good qualities have endured.'' President Bush nominated Souter, 50, on Monday to replace retired Justice William J. Brennan. Stanley said she sent a note to congratulate her former beau. No one answered the phone Saturday at Souter's home in New Hampshire. Souter's mother, Helen Souter, said by telephone Saturday that she remembered Anne Grant well. ``We were very fond of Anne,'' Mrs. Souter said. ``She's a lovely person.''

DOC.HEAD: Klan Marches in Posh Palm Beach
LaserPhoto WPB1
DOC.TEXT: About 30 Ku Klux Klansmen and neo-Nazis rallied and marched down this exclusive retreat's most famous street Saturday to jeers from a crowd of about 1,000 people. The marchers, split between Klansmen and young neo-Nazis, walked down Worth Avenue past royal palms, manicured hedges and pastel shops, many of them closed. About 130 officers from six police departments, most in riot gear and carrying batons, closely monitored the march in an area that includes many survivors of the Nazi Holocaust. The 45-minute event proceeded with little incident, although the presence of hoods, shaven heads and swastikas turned what had seemed a typical blend of tourists, shoppers and rubberneckers into a jeering mob. A spectator was arrested for disorderly conduct during the march, said police spokesman Craig Gunkel. After the march, police intervened when a group of people chased down a marcher and tried to wrestle an American flag away from him. The crowd included legions of news photographers and reporters, and police spent much of their energy controlling photographers, several of whom complained they were struck. The city had tried to block the event, but the Klan won a July 2 ruling from U.S. District Judge Norman Roettger in West Palm Beach allowing it. The march had been planned for July 4, but Klan leaders said the ruling didn't give them time to organize it by then. The march started almost an hour late after the white supremacists seemed to have trouble gathering their troops. ``Many of them got lost,'' explained rally organizer Richard Ford, a Klan wizard from Lantana. William ``Wild Bill'' Gandall, a Palm Beach County retiree with an eye patch and crutches, tried to stop the march before it began. He hobbled out and threw his body on the street, but was carted off, asking for his heart medicine and muttering, ``I had to try to stop it.'' The symbols that brought the most anger were Nazi swastikas and salutes, which infuriated older Jewish onlookers. ``This is a fringe, psychotic element preaching hate and destruction,'' said Boca Raton retiree Stanley Winter. Wendell Baker, a 25-year-old black attending the rally, said he was unhappy at the amount of exposure given the march, which he described as a ``publicity stunt.'' The marchers gathered at Memorial Fountain across from the police station, shouting racial epithets, giving Nazi salutes and castigating ``race traitors.'' Ford defended the right of the neo-Nazis to be there with his Fraternal White Knights and other Klan groups, but was almost apologetic in an aside to reporters. ``They're more racist than we are,'' he explained, as young jackbooted militants baited the jeering crowd. Walter and Pat Carlson, two of Ford's neighbors, attended the rally and described him as ``a regular guy,'' friendly with neighbors of all races. ``He's not the kind of guy looking to firebomb a church,'' said Walter Carlson. In a statement issued Wednesday, the Klan said it was holding the event in Palm Beach because the city ``has long been a symbol of the power and influence of White Chrisitians and is now seeing that culture subjugated by a vocal liberal-minority coalition.'' A counterdemonstration in Palm Beach was scheduled Sunday by the Rev. Thomas Masters of the New Macedonia Baptist Church in nearby Riviera Beach and Jewish leader Lynn Kesselman.

DOC.HEAD: Caribbean Leaders Condemn Coup Attempt, Consider Assistance
With AM-Trinidad, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Caribbean leaders Saturday condemned the attempted overthrow of the government of Trinidad and Tobago. Jamaica and Barbados put their armies on alert in case Trinidad's government asks for help. Several Caribbean heads of state and government officials were in Jamaica to attend a summit of the Caribbean Economic Community. The meeting starts Sunday. Trinidad Prime Minister Arthur N. Robinson, who has been held hostage since Friday by black Moslem rebels in Port-of-Spain, Trinidad's capital, is an influential figure within the community and had planned to attend the summit. Trinidad and Tobago, with a population of 1.3 million, is the second largest member after Jamaica in the 13-nation Caribbean community, which groups 11 island nations as well as Guyana and Belize. Percival J. Patterson, acting prime minister of Jamaica, said his country's defense force was being readied in the event the community was asked to provide military assistance. ``The army has been placed on full alert,'' Patterson said after a meeting in Kingston with other Caribbean leaders who had arrived early for the summit. Prime Minister Erskine Sandiford of Barbados said his island nation's army had also been placed on alert. ``Barbados supports democratic government, and where such governments are overthrown or threatened by illegal means, we will not support this,'' Sandiford said. ``If any request is made we will consider assistance.'' In Dominica, Prime Minister Eugenia Charles called for an end to the takeover attempt. ``We cannot allow this nonsense,'' said Ms. Charles, who asked for U.S. military intervention in Grenada in 1983 after a bloody coup there. Troops from the Caribbean community provided token support for the invading U.S. forces, which ousted the Marxist military junta that took power after killing Prime Minister Maurice Bishop and several government ministers. Lynden Pindling, prime minister of the Bahamas, also pledged Saturday ``to render whatever assistance'' possible if Trinidad's government asks for help from the Caribbean organization. Pindling did not indicate, however, whether his administration was willing to consider military assistance. Trinidad's foreign minister, Sahadeo Basdeo, who had led a delegation to pre-summit discussions in Kingston, said Saturday afternoon that he would attempt to return home to assess the situation. ``We are pleading with the rebels to free the prime minister and to talk about their problems,'' Basdeo said. ``We are pleading for common sense and rationality to prevail, and for a restoration of democracy.'' In Port-of-Spain, Acting Foreign Minister Edden Shand, who was released by the rebels Saturday, made a statement on radio opposing any foreign military intervention. In Kennebunkport, Maine, President Bush and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft were ``following the situation carefully,'' said deputy press secretary Alixe Glen. In Caracas, the Venezuelan government said it would not recognize any rebel government in Trinidad and Tobago, a former British colony of two islands which lies off Venezuela's coast. ``Venezuela ... energetically rejects this attempt to overthrow the constitutional government,'' said the statement released Saturday by the government news agency Venpres. Trinidad and Tobago is one of 48 members of the Commonwealth, an association of Britain and its former colonies. In London, the Commonwealth secretary general on Saturday called the attempted coup ``unwelcome and unacceptable.'' Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, another Commonwealth member, called for the immediate release of Robinson and other government hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Ind. Judge Rules 2 Live Crew Album Obscene, Texas Prosecutors Agree
DOC.TEXT: An Indiana judge has ruled the 2 Live Crew album ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' violates standards of decency and should not be sold to minors, and Dallas prosecutors filed charges against two store chains for selling the album. The million-selling album has already been ruled obscene by a Florida judge and banned from record stores in San Antonio. In Indiana, Howard County Judge Randy G. Hainlen issued his ruling late Friday after reviewing an affidavit submitted by Prosecutor James D. Andrews and listening to the tape in his chambers. A member of the prosecutor's staff purchased the cassette Wednesday from a Karma Records Tapes Tickets store, which displayed the tape on a shelf ``that is easily and readily accessible to anyone who enters the store, including minors,'' the affidavit said. Entertainment Enterprises co-owner Dave Crockett, whose company is the parent of 23 Karma Records stores in Indiana, said the company has banned the sale of the 2 Live Crew tape to anyone under 18 since October. According to Andrews' affidavit, the album's ``lyrics are so filled with explicit and detailed verbal descriptions or narrative accounts of sexual excitement, or sexual conduct, along with timely moaning and groaning that they violate contemporary community standards of obscenity and are harmful to children.'' In Texas, Dallas Assistant District Attorney David Pickett said the lyrics of the rap album are obscene under the Texas penal code. ``We feel the record is obscene to adults as well as children,'' Pickett said at news conference Friday. ``We felt like we needed to make a statement to these corporations.'' Misdemeanor charges were filed against Sound Warehouse Inc. and Hasting's Records and Tapes. Pickett said the offense will be the sale, distribution and display of harmful materials to a minor. If convicted, the retailers could be fined up to $10,000 each. Sound Warehouse president Terry Worrell said the company wasn't aware that it carries any product which has been deemed obscene by the district attorney's office. No one was available for comment at Hastings corporate headquarters in Amarillo. Pickett said investigators successfully sent a 13-year-old boy into a Sound Warehouse to buy the record. Undercover investigators have also bought the album from both stores in recent weeks, Pickett said. Pickett, who is running for district judge, said he isn't worried about anyone thinking his move is a political one. He also said he realized that the publicity may ultimately benefit the group. A planned 2 Live Crew concert in Dallas earlier this month turned violent after the show's promoter reneged and failed to pay the group before they went on stage. Angry patrons threw chairs and knocked out windows at the Longhorn Ballroom. San Antonio police last month arrested a record store owner for selling the album. He pleaded innocent this week to promotion of obscenity. In June, two members of 2 Live Crew were arrested in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after they performed songs from the album.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Facts and Figures
With AM-Mongolia
DOC.TEXT: Here's a brief look at pertinent facts about Mongolia: GEOGRAPHY _ Mongolia is a landlocked country of about 600,000 square miles of rolling grassland and mountains. Its highest point is in the Altai Mountains in the west, which rise 14,420 feet. Average rainfall is only eight inches a year, with the Gobi Desert in the south getting as little as 2.4 inches. PEOPLE _ Mongolia's population was estimated at 2 million in 1988. Most are ethnic Mongols but a tiny minority are Khazak, Russian and other minorities. One quarter of Mongolians live in the capital city, Ulan Bator, and half live in rural areas, mostly engaged in herding. Few true nomads remain but many people are semi-nomadic, moving with their herds between winter and summer camps. HISTORY _ Genghis Khan united the scattered, nomadic Mongol tribes in the 13th century and turned them into a conquering horde. At its peak, the Mongol empire he founded claimed territory from the Danube River in Europe to China's Pacific coast. The Manchus ousted the Mongols as rulers of China in 1691. The Mongols ruled Mongolia until 1921. A small band of revolutionaries aided by Soviet troops revolted that year and proclaimed an independent socialist state in northern, or Outer Mongolia. The southern party, Inner Mongolia, remained part of China. Mongolia remained in the Soviet bloc and began its recent moves toward political and economic reform only after Moscow did. ECONOMY _ The economy centers around herding and developing natural resources such as copper, molybdenum and timber. With 25 million head of livestock, Mongolia exports wool, leather and meat. Less than 1 percent of the land is cultivated. The economy is centrally planned and major industries are state-subsidized. Mongolia receives substantial aid and investment from the Soviet Union but in April 1990 approved a joint venture law intended to encourage investment from Japan and the West. GOVERNMENT _ After nearly seven decades of monopoly, the Communists bowed to popular demonstrations earlier this year and legalized other parties. However, the Communist Party, formally called the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, has 98,000 members and far outnumbers the opposition. The second-largest party is the Mongolian Democratic Party with a declared membership of 7,200. The Communists have promised to stop receiving state funds but retain cells in the army and police force.

DOC.HEAD: Voting Begins in Mongolia's First Free Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with polls opening, comments by voters, new color. No pickup. Note that most Mongolians use only one name
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XULA1
DOC.TEXT: Voters on foot and horseback flocked to the polls Sunday to vote in this Soviet-bloc country's first multiparty elections that will decide the pace of democratic and free-market reforms. At High School No. 1 in Ulan Bator, election officials showed observers from various parties that the ballot boxes were empty when voting began. They then used string and sealing wax to secure the boxes. Voters, most wearing the traditional Mongolian herders' dress, began arriving just after the polls opened at 7 a.m. ``From the start it is going quite well,'' said Amarbayasgolam, an observer from the Mongolian Democratic Party, the largest opposition party. Two British election observers also were on hand among 19 from various countries. Five new parties are challenging the ruling Communists, formally known as the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, in the elections for the national, provincial and local legislatures. The Communists, who have held power in this remote Central Asian nation since 1921, are assured control of the national legislature, the 430-seat Great People's Hural, after winning a primary election July 22. The opposition parties only have 130 candidates still in the running out of an original 338. But the opposition hopes to win in the new 53-seat Small Hural, which will meet between the Great Hural's annual sessions and have considerable power. Its seats will be allocated to parties according to the results of a party preference poll that is included on Sunday's ballot. At stake are the speed and boldness of political and economic reforms, which street demonstrations last winter and spring forced the Communists to accept. By agreeing to free elections, the ruling party added Mongolia to the list of Soviet-bloc nations experimenting with democracy. Though the reform movement has swept through Eastern Europe, Mongolia is the first Asian Communist state to hold multiparty elections. However, the opposition has accused the Communists of only paying lip-service to reform in order to stay in power. They and ordinary Mongolians also have complained that the election is not fair because greater weight is given to rural votes, expected to favor the Communists. They also complain that nominations were made before all the parties were able to register. In the election district where High School No. 1 is located, however, the Mongolian Democratic Party's candidate, a 31-year-old rock star, is favored to win a Great Hural seat. Tsogtsaikhan, a singer and guitarist for the group Honkh, finished first in the primary in that district. Chultemtsuren, a 75-year-old retired official who wore World War II medals, said he voted for the rock star. Asked why he didn't vote for the Communist candidate, he said, ``I worry about the future of the country, that's why I vote for a younger man.'' Chultemtsuren, like most Mongolians, uses only one name. Mongolia's generally low-key campaign went into high gear on Saturday as candidates made the rounds nationwide in a final effort to get out the vote. More than 4,000 youths rallied in the evening in front of the Lenin Museum in Ulan Bator to cheer candidates for the Mongolian Democratic Party and listen to Honkh and other rock groups. ``I am a permanent fighter for democracy,'' declared Dorligjav, the party's deputy chairman. ``We will fight not only for the election but beyond for political change.'' The crowd waved the party's blue banners and joined in singing Honkh's biggest hit, a song that urges Mongolians to wake up _ ``The Sound of the Bell.'' In one shantytown district in western Ulan Bator, an elderly Buddhist monk who is running for the Great Hural led residents in dedicating a hilltop shrine Saturday afternoon. They erected a stone carved with the picture of a goddess and placed gifts of yogurt and candy before it. Local residents said the hill had been an informal place of prayer before the Communists virtually banned worship in the 1930s. Religious freedom was one of the demands of the pro-democracy demonstrators, and believers have begun reopening temples on their own in the past few months. As the group dispersed, a campaign worker called out, ``Vote for the National Progressives,'' the party to which the monk, Dagva, belongs. The National Progressives also have a candidate in one of the election's most dramatic races. One of their founding members, a 29-year-old lawyer named Ganbold, is facing the chairman of the Communist Party, Gombojavyn Ochirbat, in a race for the Great Hural. Ochirbat, 61, took office in March after the demonstrations forced his predecessor, Jambyn Batmonh, to resign. He has embraced reform, but also stresses moderation and maintaining order. The National Progressives favor rapid privatization and establishment of laws to guarantee freedoms. Ganbold's campaign workers handed out the candidate's platform and pictures of Genghis Khan, the 13th-century warrior who built a great Mongol empire.

DOC.HEAD: 16,000 Peasants March On Mexico City to Demand Land
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 3rd `The marchers...' to CORRECT location of Veracruz; pickup graf 4 `They are...'
DOC.TEXT: A three-mile-long column of 16,000 peasants marched to the governing party headquarters Saturday to back their demands for land reform. ``This is the only way we can open the doors of the agricultural sector agencies, and the only way they'll take us into account and provide solutions to our problems,'' protest leader Cesar del Angel was quoted as saying by the independent Excelsior news service. The marchers arrived at the office complex of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party in downtown Mexico City after a six-day trek from the state of Veracruz on the Gulf of Mexico. They are demanding 200,000 acres of land in the state. They said the government promised the lnd in an Oct. 16 written agreement with their organization, the National Movement of 400 Communities, the official news agency Notimex reported. The movement is affiliated with the governing party. The agreement between the government and the peasants reportedly calls for the breaking up of more than 210 large landholdings in Veracruz, which would then be parceled out to farm families. Protesters also demanded a settlement of about $11 million for lands lost in the development of a lake in the state of Mexico, Notimex said. It has been government policy since the 1910-1920 revolution to eliminate big, wealthy landholdings and distribute estates among landless peasants. The policy has resulted in tiny, mostly inefficient farms worked by individual families or owned collectively by villages. The previous two administrations claimed there were no more big landholdings in Mexico and further land redistribution would hurt productivity.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards $14.5 Million to 14 Exposed to Asbestos
DOC.TEXT: A jury awarded $14.5 million to 14 industrial workers who sued a Florida manufacturer over their exposure to asbestos. Most of the workers were employed at shipyards in Alabama, where they worked with pipe insulation and cement containing asbestos, said Russell Budd, a Dallas attorney representing the plaintiffs. The jury found that Celotex Corp. of Tampa, Fla., was liable for health problems suffered by workers who installed or worked around the asbestos products. In their decision Wednesday, the jurors found that the workers suffered asbestos-related injuries, that Celotex failed to give warnings of known asbestos dangers and that the asbestos products were unreasonably dangerous. ``It showed these people (the workers) had a progressive lung injury that scars the interior of the lungs and ultimately requires oxygen therapy,'' Budd said. A man who answered the phone at Celotex's Houston plant Saturday said no one would be available for comment until Monday and that there was no weekend spokesman on duty. The lawsuit was filed in 1988. The case was tried in Dallas because some of the original 27 defendants were based here. All the defendants except Celotex settled for an undisclosed amount before the case came to trial, Budd said. None of Budd's clients has died or been found to have cancer. The damages include about $4 million for future suffering. That amount is to be split into awards of $75,000 to $750,000 per plaintiff. Each plaintiff also was awarded $750,000 in punitive damages. State District Judge Michael O'Neill must approve the award.

DOC.HEAD: USAir Flight Makes Emergency Landing After Bomb Threat Found Onboard
DOC.TEXT: A USAir flight made an emergency landing Saturday after a passenger found a message written in soap on a restroom mirror indicating a bomb was on board, an airline spokesman said. Flight 1582 from Charlotte, N.C., to Chicago was delayed at the Indianapolis International Airport for about three hours as FBI and local law enforcement officers examined the plane, said USAir spokesman John Bronson in Pittsburgh. No bomb was found. The 74 passengers and five crew members aboard the Boeing 737 got off the plane, and were interviewed by the FBI, Bronson said. Three passengers were detained, said Bronson, who had no further details. The FBI declined to comment on the incident. ``In the message, the word `bomb' was in it,'' he said. ``I don't have the exact wording. The passenger alerted the crew and the pilot diverted the aiplane because we take these things very seriously.''
