The airplane landed at the airport at 9:55 a.m. The plane stopped on the tarmac rather than taxi up to the terminal, but passengers and crew did not use emergency exit to get off the plane, Bronson said.

DOC.HEAD: China Criticizes Britain's Plan for Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: China on Saturday criticized Britain's decision to grant citizenship to 50,000 Hong Kong families, saying it violates the spirit of the agreement to return the colony to Chinese rule in 1997. However, the Foreign Ministry statement, carried by the official Xinhua News Agency, was less harsh than in the past. The measure passed in the British parliament Monday. It was first proposed in December. Since then, the Chinese government has attacked it repeatedly and angrily. The plan's aim is to prevent an immediate exodus of the colony's most talented people by assuring them citizenship at Britain. They could thus be guaranteed a new life in Britain at a later date. Saturday's statement said the measure was ``unacceptable to the Chinese government'' and ``will not be recognized by the Chinese side.'' China threatened to ``take further measures at an appropriate time in response to the erroneous action of the British side.'' It did not elaborate. ``This move of the British side contravenes the spirit and essence of the relevant agreement between China and Britain ... and impairs China's sovereignty,'' the statement said. Britain and China in 1984 signed the agreement to return Hong Kong to China in 1997, when the British lease on the colony runs out. Hong Kong is an enclave on the southeastern coast of China. China has promised that Hong Kong can retain its free-wheeling capitalist economy and lifestyle for 50 years after 1997, but confidence in China's promises plummeted after last year's army crackdown on pro-democracy protestors in Beijing. The milder tone of Saturday's statement by China is probably part of China's attempts to mend ties with Western nations, including Britain, which banned high-level diplomatic contacts and imposed economic sanctions after last year's crackdown.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Teen-Agers Charged in Random Subway Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with victim in critical condition.
DOC.TEXT: Seven teen-agers attacked a subway rider early Saturday, slashing his neck, after terrorizing other train passengers, Transit Authority police said. The 19-year-old victim, who staggered bleeding from the train when it reached the Brighton Beach stop in Brooklyn, was in critical condition at Coney Island Hospital following the 5:35 a.m. attack. Four girls and three boys, ranging in age from 13 to 19, were involved in the attack, said Transit Authority police spokesman Al O'Leary. ``They were acting disorderly, very loud, and intimidating passengers by waving belts,'' said O'Leary. ``There is no evidence of a robbery,'' O'Leary said when asked what prompted the attack. ``Their motivation is unknown.'' No weapon was recovered, he said. All seven teens were apprehended and charged with attempted murder, assault and criminal possession of a weapon, O'Leary said.

DOC.HEAD: Wildlife Author Roger Tory Peterson Rescued from Island
DOC.TEXT: Renowned naturalist Roger Tory Peterson came close to drowning when his boat capsized off Maine, and suffered chest pains while stranded on an island for four hours, authorities said. The 82-year-old author of ``A Field Guide to the Birds,'' a guidebook for birdwatchers published 52 years ago but still considered the Bible of birding, spent two days in a hospital and was released Saturday. The Lyme, Conn., man was rescued with five companions from Western Egg Rock, also known as Puffin Island, after the group's 17-foot boat capsized in the surf Thursday night off the 1-acre island in Muscongus Bay, the Coast Guard said. Peterson had been working on a documentary about bird life on the uninhabited islands off Maine that he last visited a half-century ago. Peterson and his companions were flown by helicopter to St. Andrew's Hospital in Boothbay Harbor after they were picked up from the island, said Coast Guard Senior Chief Petty Officer William Bless. Hospital tests showed Peterson did not suffer a heart attack. Peterson's famous guidebook revolutionized nature study, taking ornithology out of the laboratory and making the feathered world of the treetops more accessible. The book is found in more than 3 million homes and libraries and is considered one of the main reasons 60 million Americans take an interest in birds.

DOC.HEAD: Banner Towing Plane Crashes, Killing Pilot
DOC.TEXT: A single-engine, banner-towing plane on its way to the beaches crashed and burned shortly after taking off Saturday, killing the pilot, officials said. Jack Beale took off around 11 a.m. from the landing strip at Sky Signs' banner-plane airfield near Conway, just northwest of this resort, when the plane's engine apparently stalled and the plane crashed, officials said. The 63-year-old Conway man had just picked up a new advertising banner, which he was going to tow over the beachfront. He had no passengers. The plane exploded on impact, and the flames had virtually burned out when firefighters arrived, said Charlie Brown of the Horry County Volunteer Fire Department. Beale had been flying for Sky Signs for about three months, said company co-owner Mike Marion. Federal Aviation Administration officials from Atlanta were on their way to the crash site to investigate the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Powell Praises Contribution of Blacks in U.S. Wars
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top military official praised blacks' contributions in U.S. wars at a ceremony Saturday opening construction of a monument to the ``buffalo soldiers'' who fought in the West. The Buffalo Soldier Monument will honor all black American soldiers, said Gen. Colin Powell, the first black chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. ``From pre-Revolutionary times through the Revolutionary War, through every one of our wars and on up to the present, black men and women have willingly served and died,'' Powell said. ``But for most of that time blacks served without recognition or reward for the contribution they made for our freedom,'' he said, adding that it was ``freedom they did not enjoy here in their own beloved native land.'' The monument is planned for the Fort Leavenworth grounds near Smith Lake in northeast Kansas, where the buffalo soldiers of the 10th Regiment once camped between campaigns against Indians on the Great Plains. ``America has made enormous progress from the days of the buffalo soldiers to the days of a black chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff,'' Powell said. ``We aren't perfect. We never will be. But the beauty of this country is that we're always making progress.'' Powell serves as the top military adviser to the president, the secretary of defense and the National Security Council. The 9th and 10th Calvary Regiments of buffalo soldiers were formed by Congress in 1866 to patrol the western frontier. It was the Indians who dubbed black men who served in the segregated regiments the ``buffalo soldiers.'' In their service from the mid-1800s to the early 1900s, the buffalo soldiers endured discrimination, hardships and neglect that white regiments didn't have to suffer. They protected settlers, built forts and fought Apaches and Comanches on the Great Plains and along the Texas border. The monument's design calls for a large bronze statue of a rifle-carrying buffalo soldier on a horse. In the design, the soldier stands on rocks between two ponds _ one behind him to represent the past and a reflective pool in front to see into the future. Water will flow over the rocks into the reflective pool.

DOC.HEAD: Oka Mayor Proposes Selling Disputed Land to End Mohawk Standoff
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of this Quebec town said Saturday that a deal had been struck to sell the federal government a disputed parcel of land in the hope of ending an 18-day-old armed standoff between police and Mohawks. Meanwhile, Indian negotiators met to draw up their response to the latest proposals from Quebec authorities to end the confrontation. The standoff in Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, began after police rushed a barricade set up by the Mohawks to stop the expansion of the local golf course on land they claim is ancestral. An officer was killed in the gun battle that followed, but it is still not clear if he was shot by Indians or fellow officers. The Assembly of First Nations, an Indian organization, said at least 5,000 people were expected to take part in a mass rally Sunday in Oka. Organizers are billing it as the largest Indian demonstration in Canadian history. Demonstrators have been asked to bring flowers to present to the police as a symbol of peace. Oka Mayor Jean Ouellette said a deal had been reached Friday to sell the federal government a 67-acre parcel of land that had been slated for the golf course expansion, town spokesman Robert McCoy said. The proposed purchase price was not disclosed. The land would be combined with a 30-acre tract that Ottawa's Indian Affairs Department plans to buy from a French businessman to make a reserve for the Kahnesatake Mohawk community in Oka. Ouellette told more than 100 local residents gathered outside the town hall that he would recommend that the town council approve the land sale as a special meeting on Tuesday, McCoy said. But many in the crowd expressed opposition to the deal, accusing federal and provincial authorities of giving in to the Mohawks at their expense. Under the proposed deal, the federal government would provide compensation to homeowners on or near the land to be sold for use as a Mohawk reserve and help make up for future lost municipal taxes from the acreage, McCoy said. There was no immediate reaction from Mohawk representatives to the land purchase proposals. On Friday, Mohawk negotiator Mavis Etienne shrugged off the government's planned purchase of the 30 acres, saying: ``No one has any business negotiating for our land, acting like they are buying it when they don't even own it.'' Mohawk negotiators met Saturday behind their barricades in Oka, but had no immediate response to a set of proposals from Quebec Native Affairs Minister John Ciaccia to settle the dispute. On Friday, Ciaccia said Quebec is prepared to withdraw nearly all the police from Oka and the Kahnawake Mohawk reserve south of Montreal. The Kahnawake Indians have blocked the Mercier Bridge to Montreal in sympathy with the Oka Mohawks, forcing commuters to make long detours. In return, Ciaccia proposed that the Mohawks withdraw from their barricades and turn in their weapons and explosives. However, the provincial official rejected a demand for amnesty for those involved in the gun battle with provincial police. Instead, Ciaccia proposed setting up a commission of inquiry _ with a Mohawk representative _ to investigate the death of the policeman.

DOC.HEAD: Former TV Anchor, Women's Rights Activist Found Dead
DOC.TEXT: Kim Thomas-Friedland, a women's rights activist and a former news anchor for Financial News Network, was found dead at her home in Charlotte, and police were conducting a murder investigation, authorities said. The cause of death had not been established, police said. Ms. Thomas-Friedland's husband, Edward Friedland, told police he found her body on his return from work around 10 p.m. Friday. ``We are conducting a homicide investigation,'' said police Capt. D.R. Harkey. An autopsy was ordered to determine what killed her, he said. Ms. Thomas-Friedland, 32, was a leader in the Charlotte chapter of the National Organization for Woman and a former anchor for cable television's Financial News Network. She also was the co-author of an advice book for pregnant woman.

DOC.HEAD: Zsa Zsa Spends First Night in Slammer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with husband's report on Miss Gabor; picks up 7th graf, ```It's nourishing ...'
DOC.TEXT: Zsa Zsa Gabor says the food she's eaten since she's been in jail hardly has been haute cuisine and the former Miss Hungary could use one of her fur coats, her husband said Saturday. ``She complained she was freezing very much last night, so I packed her a couple of pillows and some silk covers and took it in to jail so she's not going to freeze tonight,'' Frederick von Anhalt said. Miss Gabor spent her first night in jail Friday, after beginning a three-day sentence for slapping a Beverly Hills policeman during a traffic stop last year. Police Sgt. Byron Sumrow said the tempestuous Miss Gabor hasn't been asking for anything special. ``The worst you could get out of her was that the food wasn't that great,'' Sumrow said. ``She ate the same breakfast as our other prisoners,'' Sumrow said. ``It's standard county issue _ a TV-type frozen breakfast which serves hash browns, toast and scrambled eggs.'' Von Anhalt described the food as ``hamburger and mashed potatoes,'' and said his wife won't be eating much during her stay. ``It's not her favorite food. She likes salads, she likes lots of salads and diet food and the food is very rich,'' he said. ``She is on a diet anyhow, so she's not going to eat very much.'' Von Anhalt visited his wife Saturday morning, along with daughter Francesca, Sumrow said. For lunch Miss Gabor had a cold sandwich and coffee. On the dinner menu was salisbury steak, peas and potatoes, a roll with butter, and coffee or water. ``It's nourishing and county-approved,'' Sumrow said. Miss Gabor spent Friday night in an 8-foot by 10-foot private cell with a metal-frame bed, a toilet and sink. She is scheduled to be released Monday afternoon. Municipal Court Judge Charles Rubin enforced a three-day jail sentence last May after ruling Miss Gabor had violated probation by failing to perform 120 hours of community service at a shelter for homeless women. Along with her jail time and community service, Rubin ordered Miss Gabor to pay nearly $13,000 in fines and restitution.

DOC.HEAD: Former Bank Robber Makes Big Donation in Abilene
DOC.TEXT: A Kansas City philanthropist returned Saturday to the town where he robbed a bank more than 30 years ago, this time to donate $50,000 for a new band shell in the city park. Delbert Dunmire robbed the Commercial State Bank of Abilene of about $2,600 in October 1958. Dunmire said his donation for the band shell in Eisenhower Park represented compounded interest for the money he stole. ``It was an act of malfeasance on my part, and I can't make excuses for it,'' he said. ``It was a crime against society that I can never repay society for. And I'm not attempting to do that now. ``I am attempting to go back and cover my tail wherever I have done wrong and try to do right,'' he said. Dunmire was caught after the robbery, and served time in prison. His wife, Debbie, presented the check Saturday to Marlin Fitzwater, an Abilene native and President Bush's press secretary, who was in town for his 30th high school class reunion. Fitzwater than gave the check to city officials. During the ceremony, Dunmire joked about the long-ago bank robbery. After being presented a key to the city from Mayor Wade Phillips, Dunmire joked it was the key to a jail cell. After the ceremony, Dunmire produced a maroon gym bag loaded with cash and let people reach in to each take one unseen bill. People of all ages reached into the bag, which was filled with $1, $5, $10, $20 and $100 bills. The new band shell will replace a band shell destroyed by fire in February 1989. Work on the new shell was expected to be finished by late summer. Dunmire is the founder of Growth Industries Inc. in Kansas City. The millionaire businessman also has donated weapons to the Missouri State Highway Patrol.

DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong Police Intercept Boat With 31 Vietnamese Refugees
LaserPhotos HK1, HK3
DOC.TEXT: Hong Kong authorities Saturday intercepted 31 Vietnamese boat people in a wooden fishing boat off this British colony. The refugees _ 15 men, 14 women and two boys _ were expected to be sent to detention centers after screening, police said. No further details were available as to where the group left from in Vietnam. A total of 3,697 Vietnamese boat people have arrived in Hong Kong so far this year. About 55,000 of the refugees are in Hong Kong camps awaiting resettlement overseas or repatriation to Vietnam. Under a policy adopted in 1988 to reduce the number of new arrivals, those who fled their homeland for economic reasons do not qualify for refugee status and resettlement. The vast majority of detainees affected by the new law are expected to face mandatory repatriation to Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Reached 12 Hours After Strike By Symphony Musicians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with agreement approved; picks up 5th graf, `Wages were ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Honolulu Symphony Orchestra won't miss a beat this season, symphony officials said after reaching an agreement Saturday on a new contract. Symphony Society Board Chairman William Quinn said the settlement means Saturday night's Starlight ``Pops'' Concert featuring guest conductor and pianist Peter Nero would go on as scheduled. The settlement was announced at 9:30 a.m., 12 hours after the musicians took up picket signs for their second strike in four years. Their previous strike in 1986 lasted three months. The performers overwhelmingly approved the new pact in the afternoon, their union said, but details of the vote and the contract were not released. Wages were a key issue in the dispute over a new contract to replace one that expired May 31. Although the strike began Friday night, negotiations continued until 6:30 a.m. Saturday when they broke off. It was unclear just how the agreement came about. The settlement covers some 60 full-time musicians and 20 part-timers. Musicians Association of Hawaii Local 677 President Milton Carter said base pay for the musicians in Honolulu is $21,400, compared to $55,000 in San Francisco and $35,000 to $45,000 in Rochester, N.Y. During negotiations in May the union proposed an increase to put the base salary at $34,775.

DOC.HEAD: Bouquet-Bearing Gunmen Fire on Mourners At Burial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-8, `New York ...,' to CORRECT deceased's last name to `Vuu,' sted `Vuv.'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NR1
DOC.TEXT: Three gunmen posing as flower-bearing mourners at a New York City gang member's funeral opened fire on about 100 people at a cemetery Saturday, wounding seven people, officials said. At least seven other people were trampled in the panic that followed the gunfire around 2:30 p.m. at Rosedale Memorial Park in this city just south of Newark, and were treated at hospitals for cuts and bruises. A 20-year-old man who was among those shot was flown by helicopter to the trauma unit of University Hospital in Newark. The others' wounds were not considered life-threatening, hospital officials said. Police Capt. Raymond Beckman said the funeral was for a Vietnamese man who was member of a New York gang called Born to Kill. About 100 people were attending the funeral when the gunmen fired, then fled, Beckman said. ``As they walked by the casket with a bouquet of flowers, they dropped them and opened fire on the mourners,'' the captain said. New York police said the funeral to bury Vinh Vuu, 21, began in Chinatown in lower Manhattan earlier Saturday. Vuu was shot four times in the chest early Wednesday in a drive-by shooting in Chinatown, said police Sgt. Tina Mohrmann. She said Vuu was a leader of the Chinatown-based Vietnamese gang. Beckman said three weapons were used, including an Uzi submachine gun and a shotgun. A 9mm Beretta handgun was found on the ground. That gun, which had been fired, may have been used by someone in the crowd, firing back at the shooters, Beckman said at a news conference. Police were searching for three suspects Saturday night, said police Lt. Richard Gerbounka Beckman agreed with New York police that the shooting may be related to gangland strife between the Vietnamese gang and Chinese gangs in lower Manhattan. The gunmen were apparently wearing sunglasses and trench coats, making it difficult for witnesses to say whether they were Chinese, Vietnamese or Caucasian, Beckman said. The people attending the funeral were brought to the police station for questioning. Beckman said accounts differed on how the gunmen got away. Police earlier said investigation efforts were hindered because most of the mourners, who were Vietnamese, spoke little or no English, but Beckman later said they spoke English and were cooperating. The man flown to University Hospital was taken to the operating room, said nursing supervisor Dorothy Crews. Beckman said five people were shot, but hospital officials said seven people were admitted for gunshot wounds. One woman and five men aged 17 to 21 were taken to Elizabeth General Hospital, where they were in stable condition with gunshot wounds, said nursing supervisor Bobbie Fairchild. A 22-year-old man was treated for a twisted ankle. Six people were taken to Rahway Hospital for injuries suffered when they were trampled and for shock, said hospital spokeswoman Nancy Jackson. Published reports last year said the Born to Kill gang has used terror tactics to break into Chinatown's underworld power structure. Authorities said then that the gang was responsible for robberies, assaults and murders and heroin trafficking.

DOC.HEAD: Bertha Upgraded to Hurricane
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Bertha turning away from Florida coast, quotes; picks up penultimate graf, `Meanwhile, Arthur ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Bertha, the first hurricane of the Atlantic season, was born Saturday, but turned away from the Florida coast and headed out to sea, forecasters said. Bertha became a tropical storm Saturday afternoon, but strengthened and was declared a hurricane hours later when its top sustained winds hit 75 mph. ``Hurricane Bertha really isn't much of a concern to the U.S. mainland,'' said meteorologist Jesse Moore of the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. ``The only piece of land it could possibly affect at all would be Bermuda, and we don't have it forecast to go up that way yet,'' he added. ``It's highly unlikely they'll see much more than some swells.'' At 10:30 p.m. EDT, Bertha's center was at 30.5 degrees north latitude and 72.8 degrees west longitude, or 520 miles east of Jacksonville. The hurricane was moving northeast at about 10 mph, and was expected to maintain that course through Sunday, forecasters said. Bertha is threatened by a low-pressure zone off the Carolina and Virginia coasts generating strong, upper-level winds that could cut the top off the hurricane and weaken it considerably, Moore said. Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Arthur, which peaked with 70 mph wind Thursday but quickly lost strength Friday, had ``completely dissipated. You can't even see any remnants of him in the satellite pictures,'' Case said. Tropical storms are named when their sustained wind speed reaches 39 mph and become hurricanes when wind speed builds to 74 mph. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: New Jersey Woman Wins Appeal in Syria Export Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court said Friday a New Jersey woman should have been allowed to withdraw her guilty plea in an arms export case because her lawyer had not effectively represented her. The three-judge panel of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia sent the case back to U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfiled Jackson for further proceedings. Jackson had sentenced the woman, Rosemary Loughery of Mount Holly, N.J. to two years in prison in 1987 but had allowed her to remain free pending appeal. She had pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to ship an air navigation beacon system with her business partner in violation of arms export license requirements. Her partner, Kevin Paul Gilday of Philadelphia, had been sentenced by the judge to 20 months to five years on the same conspiracy count. Ms. Loughery originally had been charged with the conspiracy count and nine counts of mail fraud alleging that the defendants tried to `defraud the United States of the right to conduct its lawful business affairs and implement the foreign policy of the United States of America free from stealth, chicanery, false statements, fraud and deceit.'' On the advice of her lawyer, Francis Hartman, she agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy count in exchange for dropping the mail fraud counts, thus reducing her maximum exposure to prison from 50 years to five, the appelate judges noted. The judges also noted that though she told probation officers she believed she had done nothing wrong. Between her indictment and her plea, the Supreme Court ruled that mail fraud charges could not be used to protect ``intangible rights,'' but only in cases alleging the loss of money or property. Hartman did not tell his client of that development. She found out about it through newspapers and told him she wanted to withdraw her plea of guilty. But Hartman advised her to wait until Gilday was sentenced before making up her mind, which she did. Jackson refused to let her withdraw the plea, saying it was ``motivated by an apprehension that she will receive a like sentence.'' She then fired Hartman and got a new lawyer. If she had withdrawn her plea when she wanted to, three months earlier, Jackson probably would have let her, the appellate panel said. ``Her constitutional right to a jury trial was at stake, not Hartman's,'' the judges wrote Friday. ``This is not a case where counsel has made a strategic decision that in retrospect, with the benefit of hindsight, appears to have been ill-advised. Rather, Hartman's conduct evinces an abdication of his repsonsibility to his client.'' No beacons were delivered. Gilday had been dealing with undercover customs agents.

DOC.HEAD: Hunt Continues for Flight 811 Cargo Door
DOC.TEXT: A remote-controlled submarine searching the ocean floor for the cargo door that blew off a United Airlines jet last year has yet to find anything after four days underwater, a Navy spokesman said Friday. The Orion deep submergence system, equipped with sonar and a video camera, is prowling the ocean bottom nearly three miles deep and about 100 miles south of Honolulu. The search will cover 24 square miles of the ocean floor twice and is expected to continue until the middle of next week, Lt. Cmdr. Bob Anderson said. In the Feb. 24, 1989 accident, the cargo door on United Airlines Flight 811 opened at 22,000 feet, tearing away a section of the Boeing 747 fuselage. Of the 355 passengers aboard the flight from Honolulu International Airport to New Zealand, nine were swept to their deaths and five were seriously injured. The crew managed to return the jet safely to Honolulu. The National Transportation Safety Board has completed its inquiry into the accident, but requested the search for the 10 foot-by-10 foot door with hopes its inspection will lead to better plane safety. Personnel aboard the 226-foot Navy ocean tug Narragansett have placed in the ocean a field of electronic transponders, which transmit electrical signals to chart movements of the video camera-equipped Orion sub. The transponders hang about 150 feet above the ocean floor around the perimeter of the search area. If the door is spotted by the submersible, a second device will be deployed at a later date to recover it. The door is believed to be lying under about 15,000 feet of water. The NTSB's inquiry determined that a faulty design of the door's locking mechanism probably caused a cockpit panel light to falsely indicate the door was locked. It blamed United, Boeing Co. and the Federal Aviation Administration for failure to correct problems with the door.

DOC.HEAD: NAACP Sues Insurer Alleging Racially Discriminatory Policies
DOC.TEXT: The NAACP and several black homeowners filed a discrimination lawsuit Friday alleging that the city's largest provider of homeowner's insurance instructed agents to stop writing policies for blacks. The class-action lawsuit drafted by the American Civil Liberties Union was filed in U.S. District Court against American Family Mutual Insurance Co., based in Madison. ``We see this as a national issue, as part of a national trend, and in this country, we still believe that separate but unequal is against the law,'' said John Powell, national legal director for the ACLU. The action seeks unspecified monetary damages and a court order to stop the practice. American Family spokesman Gary Gibson declined to comment on the lawsuit, saying he hadn't seen the document. But he denied any charges of the practice known as redlining, in which insurers instruct agents to avoid selling policies in areas with more than 25 percent black residents. ``We have made a concerted effort to serve the inner city and minorities,'' Gibson said in a brief telephone interview. The plaintiffs include Alderman Marvin Pratt, who alleges the insurer reduced his homeowner's coverage when he moved into an inner-city neighborhood. ``I'm just representative of the many numbers of folks who live in certain zip codes who have been discriminated against,'' Pratt said. Evidence in the lawsuit includes a handwritten note from an American Family manager to an agent that reads: ``Quit writing all those blacks!! They are the reason for your poor persistency.'' The note was turned over to the plaintiffs by an agent who has given a sworn statement about the company's practices, said the ACLU and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The lawsuit alleged the insurer discriminates against black homeowners by instructing agents not to sell policies to blacks, failing to hire and retain black agents and locate offices in black neighborhoods and offering blacks ``less advantageous'' terms than whites. The lawsuit also alleged redlining. Wisconsin NAACP President Felmers Chaney said redlining makes it difficult for black homeowners to maintain the value of their property, leads to the decline of inner-city neighborhoods and promotes segregation. ACLU spokesman William Lynch said the problem of redlining is industrywide, but American Family has been sued because it has the worst record of discriminating against blacks.

DOC.HEAD: High-Ranking Army Officer Dies in Parachute Exercise
DOC.TEXT: A high-ranking Army officer plunged to his death during a parachute training exercise, the second such fatality at Fort Bragg this year, authorities said Friday. Col. Richard J. Malvesti died from injuries received in a parachute jump at the Holland Drop Zone on Fort Bragg about 10 p.m. Thursday, an Army spokesman said. The 44-year-old colonel was the director of operations for the Joint Special Operations Command at Fort Bragg, Maj. Doug Foster said. Malvesti was a native of Quincy, Mass. He was commissioned in the Army in 1967 and had been assigned to Fort Bragg since 1980. Military authorities declined to release more details about the accident pending an investigation. The last parachute fatality at Fort Bragg was in January, also during a training exercise, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: State, Archdiocese Agree on AIDS Care
DOC.TEXT: The state Friday gave the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York approval to care for AIDS patients in nursing homes, exempting it from requirements that patients receive contraceptives, safe-sex counseling and abortion services. The state Public Health Council's action came despite protests by some AIDS activists. Approval had been delayed while the archdiocese found ways to provide AIDS education without violating its teachings against condom use, extramarital sex, homosexuality and other practices. The state requires that patients be told how to avoid the transmission of the AIDS virus by using condoms and to inform patients of the dangers of intravenous drug use. Under the compromise announced Friday, the archdiocese will provide education and information to nursing home residents about sexual practices that transmit AIDS and the benefits of condoms, said Health Department spokeswoman Frances Tarleton. Catholic nursing homes will routinely refer patients to off-premise agencies ``for more intensive counseling or if they wanted to get condoms, abortion, or other gynecological services, like birth control,'' said Tarleton. The compromise will result in 266 new AIDS beds at three archdiocese-run nursing homes. There is no target date for adding the beds, said archdiocesan spokesman Joseph Zwilling. Tarleton said that by the end of 1995, the city will need an estimated 3,000 nursing home beds to care for AIDS patients. There are now only 44, all at the Terence Cardinal Cooke nursing home run by the archdiocese. The state has received applications for only 1,700 more beds despite incentives like state-backed loans, enhanced Medicaid reimbursements rates and planning grants. Members of ACT-UP, an AIDS activist group, demonstrated at Friday's meeting. They oppose the church's involvement in AIDS care because of its stance on condoms, abortion and other issues. ``The fact of the matter is, they (archdiocese officials) have come forward where other organizations ... have not,'' said Tarleton. ``The state's position is that we need desperately to get these nursing home beds in place in New York City.'' She said the nursing homes will provide an alternative for AIDS patients languishing in hospital beds and for people who can't get home health care. ``It's not the most ideal way to handle AIDS prevention education but we think it does reflect an effort on the part of the archdiocese to ... provide these services to residents,'' said Tarleton.

Oil analysts predict crude prices and the cost of gasoline will rise later this year as a result of the OPEC agreement to curb output. Price-depressing overproduction by Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates is less likely after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's intimidation campaign aimed at making the countries honor their OPEC-set output quotas, analysts said. Under the agreement reached Friday by the 13 ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, gasoline prices are expected to rise up to 10 cents a gallon by December. The OPEC members agreed on a new overall production cap of 22.5 million barrels a day through the rest of the year. The figure is 400,000 barrels above the previous ceiling but will require OPEC to cut its actual production, currently estimated at 23 million barrels a day or more.

The longest and costliest criminal case in U.S. history ended when jurors deadlocked in Raymond Buckey's retrial on charges he molested three girls at McMartin Pre-School. The judge declared a mistrial, and prosecutors said they would not try Buckey a third time, closing a case that began seven years ago. Amid initial allegations involving more than 100 children and suggestions of satanism and animal torture, the case prompted national concern over molestation. ``I think there is reason to say `enough' at this point,'' District Attorney Ira Reiner said after Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg declared a mistrial Friday. ``There has been a mighty effort and there is no verdict,'' Reiner said.

Lawmakers maneuvered to override Gov. Buddy Roemer's second veto in a month of legislation that would have made Louisiana the toughest anti-abortion state. ``Where I stand now reflects the majority of the people of this state,'' Roemer said. ``That does not mean it reflects the majority of the Legislature. That's to be determined and that's fair.'' The bill Roemer vetoed Friday would have prohibited abortions except to save the life of the mother and in cases of aggravated rape and incest reported to police and a physician no more than a week after they occurred. On July 6, Roemer vetoed an even tougher bill lacking the exceptions for rape and incest. Two-thirds majorities in both legislative chambers are required to override a veto; an override of the earlier veto passed the House but fell three votes short in the Senate.

Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial will go to the jury next week without jurors hearing the mayor defend himself or face questions from prosecutors. After the defense closed its case Friday, prosecutors alleged in rebuttal that a defense witness lied when giving testimony that undermined a cocaine possession charge against Barry. Barry didn't testify, saying he wanted to avoid theatrics. ``It would have been good Perry Mason drama, L.A. Law drama, but I'm not about Perry Mason drama,'' the District of Columbia mayor said after the day's session.

President Bush says he's pleased with the initial reaction his Supreme Court nominee has received from senators and says New Hampshire jurist David Souter seems to have ``broad support'' for the post. At the same time, the president said he has no comment on highly critical comments of both him and Souter by Justice Thurgood M. Marshall. ``I have a very high regard for separation of powers and for the Supreme Court. And thus, I think people can get along without a comment from me on this interview,'' Bush told reporters aboard Air Force One on Friday. The president is spending the weekend at his oceanside family vacation home.

A farm bill that keeps major support programs and increases environmental protection is the most progressive agricultural law ever passed by the Senate, the Agriculture Committee chairman says. The $54 billion measure, setting farm policy and spending for the next five years, was approved Friday. The House version is expected to pass next week, followed by a conference committee to iron out any differences between the two versions. ``It's the most progressive farm bill I've seen come out of this body,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., who guided the bill to the final 70-21 vote after taking a strong interest in seeing environmental provisions strengthened. The bill establishes price-support programs for commodities and sets policy for nutrition programs, agricultural exports, soil and water conservation, agricultural research and extension work, food inspection and other responsibilities of the Agriculture Department.

DOC.HEAD: A Criticism of Downsizing
DOC.TEXT: Downsizing has become perhaps the most commonly used technique by which American businesses hope to contain costs and become more competitive. Managers say it is quick and effective. Those who have practiced it point to smaller payrolls, reduced expenses and lower overall administrative costs. Sometimes plants and offices can be closed and sold off. In general, downsizing is viewed as cutting the fat. That may be how it's viewed, but that's not the result, says a professor who in three years talked to many chief executives and managers and surveyed 3,000 management employees in 30 downsized companies. The majority of downsizing efforts are failures, declares Profsssor Kim S. Cameron of the University of Michigan. He found that unless management was very good, ``the employees performed worse after the cutbacks.'' In fact, said Cameron, ``in only five or six of the organizations I studied did I see a marked increase in productivity. In all the rest, performance went down.'' Considering the context into which that statement was delivered, it is indeed a shocking one. In the past decade, hardly a company with any measure of pride hasn't considered downsizing. Thousands did it. At times, downsizing became almost a fad. It was the all-purpose remedy for ailments only vaguely discerned. Why, it was even patriotic: How could America compete in the new global economy if it wasn't lean, mean, fit and determined _ free of bureaucratic midriff? But management, says Cameron, has been reactive, viewing downsizing as defensive, protective, conservative. It hasn't been proactive. Rather than thinking through the issues, it focused on the quick fix. ``There is no such thing as a quick fix when downsizing,'' says Cameron. Such an approach is more destructive than constructive. It is the ``grenade approach,'' or ``throwing something at the problem and making a big noise.'' Effective downsizing must be thought through. It must be part of a broad strategy because ``effective downsizing is a transformation of a firm's culture as much as it is a reduction in personnel.'' Effectively implemented, downsizing begins with an analysis of tasks, resources and talents, and an understanding of what jobs and people can be eliminated and which ones the company cannot afford to lose. It must involve strong, visible, visionary leaders who can describe a process and outcome that employees will support. It should involve ``bottom-up'' participation of employees. The strategy should employ teamwork, especially among salaried workers, and those teams should communicate with each other. It should even involve suppliers, distributors and customers. Rather than one huge and potentially destructive shock, it is wiser to use small, slow steps over a period of time. All the while, the downsizers should keep their eye on quality and the maintenance of it. If you want to fail, Cameron observes, you might try across-the-board layoffs and attrition without benefit of analysis; load work on remaining employees; seek more work for the same pay; and think of quality only in terms of error-detection. Do that, he suggests, and the downsizing effort, almost always begun in an attempt to make the company more efficient, will make it worse off than before.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Monday, July 30.

DOC.HEAD: Darwinism in Retailing
DOC.TEXT: The increasing likelihood of leaner times for the rest of the year will pile more problems on retailers struggling to stand out in a crowded pack and maintain market share, analysts say. Laggard performers, like Sears, Roebuck and Co., will have tough jobs boosting profitability if consumer spending continues to slow. By contrast, powerhouses that have managed to motor along strongly despite a difficult economic environment are poised to go forward without a blip in their balance sheets. In other words, the Wal-Marts of this world will prevail. In an application of Darwin's theory of evolution, the efficiently run retailers will survive and prosper while the weak ones could be headed for extinction, says Edward A. Weller of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. No one wants to put Sears on the endangered species list. It is clear, however, that the nation's largest retailer has more than a few things in common with the proverbial dinosaur. This past week Sears posted a 39 percent drop in second-quarter earnings. Although high insurance payouts by its Allstate Insurance Group took a heavy toll on the company, analysts were more concerned by the retailing results. The drag on earnings caused by Allstate was considered a one-time event. The problems within the Sears Merchandise Group, which reported a 32 percent decline in operating income, indicates something might be rotten at the core of the company. Long gone are the days when the retail giant was an industry standard bearer. An effort begun last year to regain its glory by revamping merchandise strategy still hasn't borne fruit. Sears' double-pronged program involving the introduction of more national brands, from General Electric appliances to Pirelli tires, and a switch to an everyday low pricing policy appears to be sparking little buying enthusiasm among customers. Analysts say the moves may have been made too late. Or, maybe it just takes an extra long time to change the course of such a mammoth operation. Indeed, it will take a lot to influence the bottom line of a company that annually reels in more than $30 billion in revenue. ``Sears, K mart are working like hell to get efficient but there isn't much evidence that they're accomplishing it yet,'' said Weller. ``I think it's going to be tough for them.'' Sears, and to a lesser extent its nearest rival K mart Corp., are playing catchup _ even though they outrank all their competitors in terms of nationwide sales volume. This leaves room for nimbler competitors, such as Wal-Mart Stores Inc., to maneuver in building up marketplace clout. Wal-Mart, which is pursuing an aggressive expansion campaign, is widely expected to eventually unseat Sears and K mart from their top two positions on the national retail roster. How soon _ or whether _ the Nos. 1 and 2 retailers get knocked from the top of the heap may depend on how they fare in the near future. An unprecedented run of robust consumer spending in the '80s has waned, replaced by an era of frugality, economists say and consumer surveys confirm. People are putting away more money in anticipation of lean times, which reduces disposable income. Mindful of the forecasts, store operators have kept close tabs on inventories to minimize costs and protect profitability. Orders have been flowing into stores for the important back-to-school season and analysts expect to get a reading on how well merchandise is moving out the door by late August or early September. Sluggish back-to-school business could be a harbinger of a ho-hum Christmas season, a time on which retailers rely for the bulk of their annual revenue and income. ``It's sort of a gloomy outlook for spending,'' says Karen Sack of Standard & Poor's Corp. in New York. ``It looks pretty rough for retailers.''

DOC.HEAD: Metropolitan Cathedral Sinking Like a `Dried Souffle'
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: A torrential rain came right through the roof of the Metropolitan Cathedral during a news conference last year on preserving it and Mexico's other historical treasures. ``We had to leave the table because we were getting wet,'' said Efrain Castro Morales, cultural secretary of Puebla state. ``It was a big scandal.'' A subsequent study found the leaky roof to be a minor problem compared with others that might cause North America's oldest and most important cathedral to collapse in 30 years unless major repairs were made. Sergio Zaldivar Guerra, an architect who conducted the study for the secretary of urban and ecological development, said Metropolitan Cathedral has been sinking since construction began in 1573. The cathedral houses an impressive collection of religious paintings, sculptures and altarpieces. It has four identical domes, five altars and 14 chapels with Baroque and neo-classical touches, but structurally, everything is askew. Outside, the buckling earth has broken the concrete of the plaza, forming waves around the cathedral. Windows and doorframes tilt to left or right. Repaired cracks scar the walls. Metal patches and clamps mark and measure newer fissures that zig-zag around the building. Inside, thick crevices _ one about 66 feet long _ run along the marble floors and up the columns. Scaffolding blocks off areas where workers are repairing damaged domes. The ceiling is dotted with water stains. Most of Mexico City also is sinking because it is built on the swampy beds of Lake Texcoco, over the ruins of Tenochtitlan, the Aztec capital. The spongy subsoil's instability has damaged several important buildings, including the adjacent National Palace, the Palace of the Fine Arts and the Basilica of the Virgin of Guadalupe. Zaldivar said the problems in the other structures were not as severe because the buildings were smaller and lighter than the cathedral, which weighs an estimated 130,000 tons. He said the worst part is that the cathedral is sinking unevenly, ``like a dried souffle.'' The Metropolitan Cathedral took 250 years to complete and sits on the largest plaza in the Western hemisphere, second in the world only to Red Square in Moscow. During his 14-month investigation, Zaldivar found fractures in domes and column bases, and other damage to arches and walls. Acid rain has eroded the outer surface. The area between the main altar and western tower has sunk about 8 feet and continues to drop at a rate of .05 inches a month. Construction of a drainage system in the 1960s also weakened the ground under the cathedral, as did excavation of the Aztec Templo Mayor, or Great Temple, subway construction and digging wells for drinking water. ``They did not know what would happen,'' Zaldivar said of those decisions. Castro, the state official, said economic problems forced previous administrations to neglect Mexico's important monuments, ``but it did not have to reach this grave situation.'' Work was done, but Zaldivar said the scope of the problem was not known at the time. He said the sinking cannot be stopped, but the cathedral can be made to subside more evenly by digging pits under the higher parts and removing mud and sediment to lower them. Underground steel supports will be used to prop up sagging areas, Zaldivar said. ``Whatever is necessary'' will be spent and the government has made an initial allocation of $3.9 million for the restoration, Zaldivar said. The work, which began three months ago, will take at least 6 years and the cathedral will remain open. Zaldivar said the work would have to be repeated periodically over at least the next century, until earth stops compressing and solidifies. ``It is safe for the next 30 years, but the sooner we complete the work the better,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Aug. 6

DOC.HEAD: Unprecedented Indictment of Eastern Not a Nail in Coffin
DOC.TEXT: It's already flown through more than a decade of staggering losses, relentless competition, a difficult takeover, management-labor feuding, an emotional strike, bankruptcy court and blasts of bad press. So the last thing Eastern Airlines needed was a criminal indictment for doctoring maintenance records, an unprecedented event in the airline business. Nonetheless, industry analysts and travel agents don't view the 60-count indictment handed up this past week against Eastern and nine managers as a fatal bullet for an airline that has demonstrated its ability to survive. Some say Eastern could handily ride this one out, partly by cutting its already-discounted fares further in order to woo skeptical passengers. ``If Eastern is going to charge less, with no restrictions on the tickets, people are still going to fly them no matter what,'' said Jack Bloch, owner of JB's Travel World, a New York travel agency. ``Everyone who's on a budget thing will fly them.'' William Cooper, head of Adventure Travels of Pompano Beach and Boca Raton, Fla., said he believed many passengers already have a thick skin about flying in general and quickly will forget the Eastern indictment. ``I know passengers who will say, `If the pilot's willing to get into the airplane and risk his life, why shouldn't I?,''' Cooper said. ``I think Eastern has had enough of a public relations problem anyway, so how much more damage can this do?'' The indictment was the result of a 10-month probe by federal prosecutors into the airline's maintenance practices at airports in New York and Atlanta and Eastern's headquarters in Miami. It portrayed a pattern of violations that included installing faulty cockpit instruments and ignoring water buildups in fuel tanks, as well as tinkering with maintenance records to show all work had been done properly. The indictment also depicted Eastern as coercing maintenance crews to flout safety guidelines at all costs for sake of keeping airplanes flying and passenger-ticket revenue flowing. None of the alleged infractions caused accidents or injuries and all were said to have taken place between July 1985 and last October. A federal grand jury in Brooklyn delivered the indictment after plea bargain talks between the airline and U.S. attorney Andrew Maloney collapsed. The indictment posed an acute challenge to Martin R. Shugrue Jr., an airline veteran appointed to run Eastern three months ago by a federal bankruptcy court. The court has been overseeing Eastern's affairs since March 1989, when a crippling strike forced the airline to seek protection from creditors. In appointing Shugrue, the court took control of Eastern from Frank Lorenzo, the head of Eastern's parent Continental Holdings. Lorenzo bought Eastern in 1986 and subsequently was accused by Eastern's unions of nearly bleeding the carrier to death to cut costs and make Eastern profitable. Shugrue had been in the midst of orchestrating an aggressive campaign to put the Lorenzo legacy behind and convince the flying public that Eastern and its workers are exuberant, efficient _ and safe. He sought to minimize the indictment's impact by announcing it before Maloney did. He also took out advertisements in leading newspapers nationwide, asserting that the Federal Aviation Administration had fined Eastern 16 months ago for the same problems and everything had been corrected. ``Today if Eastern weren't meeting the highest government standards of safety we would not be flying,'' Shugrue said. Industry experts familiar with Eastern's past problems agreed with him. ``I think Eastern reacted intelligently with the ads. They drove home the fact that this is stale bread,'' said Morten Beyer, chairman of Avmark, an aviation consulting concern in Arlington, Va. ``No airplanes were delayed, no airplanes crashed, nobody was hurt. It was a victimless crime,'' he said. ``So I don't think it's going to have a protracted effect.'' Still, the indictment could compound an already difficult financial situation for Eastern. It came only a few months before the airline industry's slowest part of the year begins. That means an already strapped Eastern is facing the prospect of cutting fares to woo business. ``A lot of people realize that for Eastern to survive, the present structure can't continue,'' Cooper said. ``They've got some fares that are so low now, in certain markets they're losing their shirts. How much lower can they go, how much are other airlines going to allow them to go?'' In other business and economic news this past week: _More evidence emerged that showed the economy has fallen to near-recession levels. The government said gross national product grew at an anemic 1.2 percent rate in the April-June quarter and it revised estimates of earlier growth downward. Major automakers reported slumping car sales, while leading companies such as Sears, Digital Equipment and McDonald's reported slumping earnings. The stock market fretted and took a sharp plunge early in the week. _Two of the most economically desperate countries followed unusual strategies to market their raw materials. The Soviet Union, starved for hard currency, appeared to reduce its support for black African nationalism by agreeing to sell uncut diamonds through a powerful cartel run by De Beers, South Africa's best-known company. In the Middle East, Iraq threatened two OPEC neighbors with military force unless they quit pumping excessive amounts of crude, which the Iraqis claimed was depressing the price. Shortly thereafter, the oil cartel reached an agreement to cut production and raise the price. _Michael Milken and Ivan Boesky, the best-known white collar felons of high finance, were granted congressional immunity from additional prosecution in exchange for their testimony about Wall Street corruption and shady junk-bond dealings.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for weekend editions July 28-29

DOC.HEAD: Analysts See Gains From Credit-Squeeze Pain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf, ``Increasingly it's... to fix typos.
DOC.TEXT: With all the problems posed by a squeeze on credit, some Wall Street analysts still believe the U.S. economy can withstand the pressure without much widespread, long-term damage. Indeed, they contend, the pain occurring now for the banking business and its customers holds out the promise of future gains in stability and the potential for growth. ``As lenders cut back, many worry that a credit shortfall might stop the economy in its tracks,'' says Maureen Allyn, chief economist at the New York investment management firm of Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc. ``We think the pluses will continue to outweigh the minuses, and the economy will avoid recession.'' To many an armchair economist, the sight of a clampdown on lending immediately evokes visions of a looming slump for workers, consumers and businesses. In the 1980s, the reasoning goes, business and financial activity was pumped up by a rapid expansion in the use of borrowed money. Now that a restricted diet of credit has been prescribed, belt-tightening would seem to be the order of the day. That certainly has been the case for the depressed home-building and real estate markets in many areas of the country. But on an overall basis, Ms. Allyn maintains, a slowdown in credit does not by itself guarantee an exactly parallel pattern in economic growth. ``Some parts of the economy use more credit than others,'' she points out. ``Real estate, for example, is voracious. ``During the last half of the 1980s, mortgages devoured over 40 percent of all new loans. Yet home and office building produced only about 6 percent of the gross national product. ``On the other side of the ledger, exporting _ 14 percent of GNP _ uses only a smidgen of borrowing now and then to finance inventories or procure a letter of credit. ``The rising parts of the economy depend less on credit than the slowing parts.'' Government statistics made public on Friday showed growth in output struggling along at a 1.2 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, in the second quarter of the year. That gave investors scant encouragement about the prospects for improvement in corporate earnings, which lately have provoked more than a few problems in the stock market. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed Friday at 2,898.51, down 62.63 from the week before. On Monday, the indicator plunged sharply, falling more than 100 points at one time before recovering, partly due to skepticism about economic and corporate earnings prospects. The New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 4.33 to 193.32; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 12.68 to 442.59, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 4.96 at 355.49. Volume on the Big Board averaged 171.72 million shares a day, against 166.96 million the week before. ``Increasingly, it appears that the ongoing story for the 1990s will be that of shrinkage of financial empires built on excessive debt,'' said Vincent Agnew of the investment management group at Chicago Title and Trust Co. ``So far, the negative impact of this trend has been more pronounced in some areas of the country than others. But the economy is now beginning to make some modest progress despite the frugality that appears to be transforming the banking system. ``Our guess is the worst may be over and the short-term dislocations may in fact enhance chances for a more upbeat economic story in 1991.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions

DOC.HEAD: Business Week Reports `Best Companies For Women'
DOC.TEXT: A half dozen U.S. corporations ranging from a leading cosmetics maker to the parent publisher of USA Today are among the best companies for working women, according to a business magazine. Business Week magazine's cover story in Aug. 6 editions released Friday said Avon Products, CBS, Dayton Hudson, Gannett, Kelly Services, and US West Communications were leaders in corporate efforts to promote what the magazine called ``woman-friendly cultures.'' The magazine also listed 12 companies in the next-best category of ``Up-and Comers:'' American Express, Baxter International, Corning, Honeywell, IBM, Johnson & Johnson, Merck, Monsanto, Pitney Bowes, Reader's Digest, Security Pacific Bank and Square D. It also listed an additional six in the No. 3 category of ``Late Bloomers:'' Digital Equipment, Du Pont, Hewlett-Packard, Olin, 3M, and Xerox. Business Week said it based the selections on several criteria, including the numbers of women in key executive positions and on the boards of directors, efforts to help women advance, and sensitivity to family issues, such as child care and parental leave. The magazine is not the first publication to produce a best-companies list for women. Working Woman and Working Mother magazines also have done their own rankings in recent years. In 1988, two researchers, Baila Zeitz and Lorraine Dusky, produced a widely quoted book called ``The Best Companies for Women,'' a compilation of 50 companies with details on their recruitment, promotion opportunities, salary, commitment to equality, flexibility toward parental obligations and policies on sexual harassment.
